IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative SARS-CoV-2 is the virus responsible for the severe respiratory disease named as coronavirus disease 19 (COVID-19), which has been declared a pandemic in March, 2020. While susceptibility to COVID-19 infection doesn't show any sex specificity, clinical outcomes show that males experience both a higher severity and mortality upon SARS-CoV-2 infection compared to females. Here we describe a COVID-19 mouse model mirroring pathological alterations in coagulation, endothelial activation, and platelet function associated with the human infection, allowing in vivo studies to explore the molecular mechanisms responsible for the sex-specific difference in severity driving the coagulopathy associated with the infection and new therapeutic options for the treatment of severe viral infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The proposed project aims to address the limitations of current cardiac imaging techniques by developing a wearable ultrasound imager for continuous, non-invasive monitoring of the heart. This technology has the potential to revolutionize the field of cardiac imaging by providing direct and real-time assessment of cardiac functions, which may lead to early detection and improved management of cardiovascular diseases and acute conditions. The development of this wearable technology has the potential to greatly benefit the field of critical care and expand the possibilities for cardiovascular disease management.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative We investigate in this proposal key neural circuits that control food intake and body weight in the mouse. We apply approaches from systems neuroscience to understand how these circuits are dynamically regulated during a meal and the motivational mechanisms they use to influence behavior. This will reveal basic mechanisms by which hunger and satiety are controlled in the brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Repetitive Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (rTMS) administered at a frequency of 10 Hz to the left dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (DLPFC) is an effective treatment for Major Depressive Disorder (MDD), yet many patients do not obtain significant benefit. This study aims to develop an innovative personalized- medicine approach to rTMS using a novel “interrogation” procedure, which examines electroencephalogram (EEG) signals recorded from the scalp following different stimulation frequencies to identify the frequency that is most likely to engage brain circuits associated with rTMS antidepressant response for each individual. Results will lay the foundation for a future clinical trial to investigate the efficacy of this customized stimulation approach to treating MDD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In vivo delivery of messenger RNA encoding multivalent immunogenic antigens is an effective measure for counteracting emerging/re-emerging virus threats. The proposed study will further our understanding of how muscle-localizing RNA vaccines elicit adaptive immune responses in a multivalent vaccine application by focusing on innate immune responses. We will use antigens of four important human pathogens, SARS-CoV-2, RSV, Influenza, and EV-D68, that are currently causing tripledemic and re-emerging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sickle cell disease (SCD) afflicts almost exclusively African-Americans in the US and is associated with significant morbidity, poor quality of life, and a shortened life expectancy. Hydroxyurea is the only disease- modifying agent that is FDA-approved for SCD with a mechanism of action to block sickle cell formation through increasing fetal hemoglobin expression; however, hydroxyurea is not highly utilized by SCD patients. This proposal will study the safety, tolerability, and efficacy of an alternative therapy, panobinostat, which also increases fetal hemoglobin, and will explore biomarkers of drug treatment response as a novel and promising disease-modifying agent for SCD.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: OTHER PROJECT INFORMATION – Project Narrative This research will investigate the impacts of a variety of influential early childhood interventions on health, mental health, and health-promoting behaviors of the original participants and their children. We investigate dynamic mediators and moderators that promote health, including cognition, and socioemotional skills through midlife. We assess the contribution of health benefits to the quality of life, health costs, and cost- benefit analyses.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: In this project the investigators seek to understand molecular mechanisms underlying the crosstalk between Hippo and Wnt signaling, two signaling pathways that are critical for tissue homeostasis and tumorigenesis. Our study is focused on the gastrointestinal tract, and the proposed studies are essential to gain mechanistic insights into the functional and signaling interactions of these two pathways in regulation of intestinal stem cells and will have important therapeutic implications for GI disease and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Depressed, exaggerated, or dysregulated motivation is characteristic of many mental illnesses, including addiction. This project will expose the neural circuits responsible for ensuring homeostatic and cognitive control over motivation induced by reward-predictive cues to understand both adaptive motivation and how it can become maladaptive.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) affects approximately 1% of the population and can lead to significant morbidity, increased mortality, and substantial health-care and societal costs. This project will explore the formation and clearance of neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) in the lung, which may be a factor leading to the generation of RA-related autoimmunity during the early stages of RA development. Ultimately, these findings can lead to novel approaches for RA prevention that target NETs and immune dysregulation in the lung.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol use disorder is a debilitating disease, affecting nearly 16 million people in the United States, for which medication treatment is available but underutilized. To support alcohol use disorder medication treatment, this study will utilize multiple data sources, including clinical trial and real-world data, outcome measures, and methodology to identify patient subgroups that are most likely to benefit from each medication used to treat alcohol use disorder. The goal of this award is to clarify uncertainties among clinicians and patients about whether and for whom treatment may work, which can inform clinical practice and increase the adoption of alcohol use disorder medications.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Disorders of the brain and nervous system, including those resulting directly from injuries incurred during military service, are of immediate relevance to Veterans Health. In part because of the complexity of the nervous system, people who have disorders such as spinal cord injury, stroke, post-traumatic stress disorder, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or limb loss lack adequate rehabilitation therapies to regain their independence. Through rigorous translational and clinical research conducted by a multidisciplinary team of scientists, engineers, and clinicians, the VA RR&D Center for Neurorestoration and Neurotechnology develops and tests novel device-based approaches to improving the health and lives of Veterans. An explicit goal of the Center is to translate neurotechnology and its applications into clinical practice in service to our Veterans and civilians throughout the US.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Pain-related stigma is a significant and understudied psychosocial factor among adolescents with chronic widespread musculoskeletal pain (CWMP), that has been implicated in impairment in health outcomes and quality of life. This project aims to: 1) develop a novel pain-related stigma framework that is useful in assessing outcomes in adolescent CWMP; and 2) develop and validate the Pain-Related Stigma Scale for Adolescents with CWMP (PReSS-A). This study will lay the foundation for understanding pain-related stigma and developing clinical interventions that will target social factors and improve health outcomes in this population.

PHR: Project Narrative This research will contribute to fundamental knowledge of the molecular mechanisms required to specify hematopoietic stem cells. The proposed research is relevant to public health because these findings will inform the development of in vitro protocols for the generation of patient-derived hematopoietic stem cells to treat blood disorders such as leukemia, anemia and hemoglobinopathies, enhancing these patient's treatment options and success rates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Human Leukocyte Antigen (HLA) and Killer-cell Immunoglobulin-like Receptor (KIR) genes are highly complex and varied when compared to the rest of the human genome, but are central for understanding the genetic basis of disease and for improving human health. The system of tools, standards and services that we are building will maximize the use of current and future forms of data for the HLA and KIR genes, facilitating clinical therapies and giving clinicians easier access to research findings. The expanded HLA|COVID-19 Database will serve as a community resource for studying the relationship of HLA and KIR gene variants with many human diseases.

PHR: Successful completion of the proposed studies will significantly advance our knowledge regarding molecular mechanisms that govern human oligodendroglia-specific circRNA landscapes and may identify human oligodendroglia circRNAs that promote myelin lesion repair, which will have a significant impact on myelin disorders. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE ETS transcription factor gene fusions occur in approximately 50% of prostate cancer patients. This application is designed to elucidate the molecular mechanisms of prostate cancer pathogenesis induced by the cooperation between overexpression of putative oncogenic ETS-related gene (ERG) and inactivation of the p53 tumor suppressor. Findings from the proposed studies will shed new light on prostate pathobiology and lead to identify new targets for development of novel therapeutics for the effective treatment of this subtype of the disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Recent reports suggest opioid-related deaths reached record levels in the past 12 months, highlighting the risk of relapse to high-potency opioids and the need to provide ongoing medical treatments for those with opioid- use disorder. More convenient imaging tools and sophisticated statistical approaches are needed to capture important neuro-information underlying drug-taking behaviors and to better identify those at increased risk of relapse. A promising clinical tool, functional near-infrared spectroscopy, together with novel computational approaches (e.g., deep learning) may aid in identifying key drivers of relapse vulnerability, thus revealing appropriate treatment approaches to decrease relapse and increase treatment adherence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Determining the mechanisms by which myosin II-based contractile systems assemble has promise to provide a mechanistic understanding of force-dependent pathological processes leading to diseases, such as cancer and cardiovascular disease. Identification of therapeutic targets to modify the forces driving disease could have health benefits for the public at large. The research proposed here aims to develop a molecularly detailed and predictive model of how contractile systems generate force to drive cell division, cell movement, and muscle contraction, with the ultimate goal of distinguishing mechanisms used by normal vs. aberrant cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Multidimensional immune correlative analysis revealed a striking negative association between CD8 expression on donor NK cells and treatment response in a clinical trial of relapsed/refractory AML patients treated with memory-like NK cells. This proposal aims to explore molecular mechanisms driving a proliferative defect in the CD8+ NK population, and to interrogate the function of the CD8 molecule itself. These findings will provide insights into fundamental mechanisms of human NK cell biology and will have broad implications across the fields of cancer, infection, and autoimmunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Relevance Autism spectrum disorder is an early onset, life-long disorder that affects approximately 1% of the population and is defined by fundamental impairments in social communication and restricted or repetitive behavior or interests. This work focuses on understanding how dysfunctions in the autism-linked gene SCN2A, which encodes a neuronal sodium channel, affects neuronal function. This project will shed light on the cellular and circuit mechanisms that contribute to the disorder, and potentially identify developmental timepoints for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Given past health messages that strongly promoted mammography screening, recent revisions to guidelines that promote informed choice constitute a health message reversal that can be difficult for many women to accept. This research will employ nationally representative and longitudinal surveys of women 40-49 that aim to understand women’s affective reactions to screening evidence and the consequences of those reactions for screening preferences and shared decision making with a primary care provider. This research will directly inform how to more effectively communicate about breast cancer screening to maintain credibility and trust when health messages change.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Despite the enormous clinical, societal and economic challenges for patients with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) and the predicted increase due to a growing aging and diabetic population (the two largest risk factors), there have been no new therapies in the past 15 years. By focusing on the genetics of X-linked Alport syndrome, the most common inherited glomerular disease leading to renal failure, and identifying the modifier genes that affect the age-of-onset and severity of the disease, our studies will lead to a better understanding of the initiation and progression of the disease process in general and will help to reveal novel therapeutic targets to combat ESRD in patients with Alport syndrome as well as patients with other forms of kidney disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The dopaminergic system is hypothesized to underlie the NIMH Research Domain Criteria construct ‘Reward Learning’ and its subconstructs ‘Reward Prediction Error’ and ‘Probabilistic and Reinforcement Learning.’ Impulse control disorder, which is induced by dopamine receptor agonist medications, consists of increased risky behavior including increased problem gambling – a DSM-V recognized behavioral addiction. The proposed experiments aim to investigate individuals with and without impulse control disorder symptoms to determine the role sub-second dopamine signals play in ‘Reward Learning,’ ‘Reward Prediction Error,’ and ‘Probabilistic and Reinforcement Learning’ in humans and how these constructs and the dopamine system may be altered in patients predisposed to problem gambling and impulse control disorder.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In RAS-mutated pediatric non-CNS solid tumors, WT RAS signaling underlies therapeutic resistance to therapies targeting either MEK or mutated RAS. This proposal takes a rational approach to assessing combination therapies to designed to treat RAS-mutated pediatric solid tumors that is based on first-principles of inhibiting both mutated RAS and WT RAS signaling to downstream effectors. Hence, this research will inform novel therapeutic approaches designed to prolong the therapeutic window for current targeted therapies and potentially enhance patient survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  There is considerable interest in approaches that capture time-varying connectivity, however existing ap- proaches suffer from three major limitations: 1) extraction of networks and estimation of dynamic features for the most widely used approaches typically makes many limiting assumptions and rely on user defined parameters whose optimality is not guaranteed (e.g. choice of window size, filter settings), 2) methods typically assume relatively simple linear relationships, and 3) most approaches assume the spatial nodes are fixed in time, effec- tively ignoring the possibility of functionally fluid nodes. We propose to address these limitations by developing a family of flexible spatio-temporal models that leverage and blend the concepts of joint blind source separation and deep learning, which we show can reveal important information missed by existing models. We will apply the proposed models to study spatial and temporal aspects of dynamic connectivity across mental illness includ- ing schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, and autism spectrum. 37

PHR: NARRATIVE Research over the last 15 years has revealed that species hybridize more than initially thought, and that hybridization is a common source of genetic variation. This project proposes to determine the environmental and genomic factors that determine the fate of an allelic variant that gets exchanged between species. To do so, we integrate natural collections, method development, and data synthesis to understand the role of hybridization across evolutionary scales.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to human health because damage or disease affecting motor cortical dynamics produces disabling and costly motor disorders, which affect over 40 million Americans. This work will use a new toolbox to study how thalamic inputs carrying information from basal ganglia and cerebellum contribute to cortical dynamics and behavior. This project is relevant to the NIH mission because detailed understanding of motor cortical dynamics is expected to advance neuroprosthetics and other therapies, and thus reduce illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative In this MIRA proposal we seek to continue our work at developing computational methods for population genetic inference from whole genome data. We propose three areas of interest: 1) spatial population genetics, 2) the population genetics of adaptation, and 3) development of community library aimed at improving rigor and reproducibility in the field. We will produce multiple tools and resources that will usher in the next generation of inference for the incredibly rich genomic data currently under collection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Organismal development requires stereotypical and random patterning of cell types, dependent on regulation of signaling, transcription, and chromatin. Disruption of either type of patterning during human development can result in severe congenital disorders. Using the fly eye as a genetic model, we aim to understand how these very different patterning mechanisms are coordinated in a single tissue.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Electronic health records (EHRs) are now ubiquitous in routine cancer care delivery, but their utility for research and quality improvement has been limited by a dearth of methods for integrating the unstructured data in which most key cancer outcomes are encoded within EHRs. I propose to apply recent innovations in deep learning to integrate structured and unstructured data to create a dynamic pre-trained model of cancer patients' treatment trajectories, and to apply this model to identify patients who are appropriate candidates for clinical trials at times when they are eligible. I will then evaluate the effect of trajectory modeling on clinical trial accrual as I prepare for an independent research career focused on clinical cancer data science.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project focuses on improving treatment of a pediatric brain cancer, medulloblastoma, that despite aggressive treatments kills 30% of the children from recurrent disease and often leaves the survivors with severe and lifelong treatment-associated cognitive and motor deficits and at risk of subsequent neoplasms. We will use small-molecule toll-like receptor 7 and 8 agonist, resiquimod, packaged in innovative nanoparticles to deliver resiquimod to the tumor, remodel tumor microenvironment and promote antitumor immune response. This project will determine mechanisms of immunotherapy using our novel therapeutic modality and asses its potential in combination with antineoplastic agents to improve treatment outcomes in medulloblastoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Endocrine therapies, optimized to target the cancer cell intrinsic actions of the estrogen receptor (ER), are currently used to treat breast and gynecological cancers. However, the pharmacology of these agents is also influenced by their cancer cell extrinsic actions in the immune system and in the brain where their actions can either increase or decrease therapeutic efficacy. Understanding ER pharmacology in cancer cells, the immune system and in the brain will inform how best to use existing endocrine therapies, be instructive as to approaches to develop the next generation of modulators, and enable the development of new drug combinations for the treatment of breast cancer and non-reproductive cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We recently found that the human transporter ABCB10 moves the natural antioxidant biliverdin out of the mitochondria. Now our goal is to understand how this protein pumps its substrate using the energy from ATP at the molecular level. This study will reveal the mechanical strategy of this transporter and provide ideas to modulate its activity for therapeutic purposes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE HEALTH SCI CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE: This proposal utilizes a novel model of triple negative breast cancer (TNBC) which has been created by systematically crossing a spontaneous model of TNBC into the BXD family, the largest and best characterized murine genetic reference population, to discover and validate genetic modifiers of tumor aggression and response to therapy. The BXD-TNBC hybrids demonstrate significant, heritable variation in tumor phenotypes which have yielded candidate genes using systems genetics and cross-species comparisons of existing human databases. The generation of this reliable, reproducible, and robust resource will enable the discovery of genetic and environmental modifiers which will be leveraged to further understand TNBC to maximally improve patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Narrative: Understanding the molecular mechanism of how olfactory receptors recognize multitude of odorants lays the foundation to our understanding of the olfactory system. The proposed interdisciplinary research will develop computational methods using machine learning techniques, concurrent with in vitro cell based assays and cryo-EM studies to push this understanding forward by enhancing the in vitro expression of olfactory receptors and enabling the structure-function studies. The combination of computational methods and experiments will provide unprecedented insights into mechanisms of odorant-olfactory receptor recognition and map the residues involved in such recognition events.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this project is to advance our knowledge on the structure, mechanism, interactions and regulation of type IA topoisomerases found in all life forms. The results will facilitate the discovery of much needed new antibiotics leads against bacterial topoisomerase I, a validated drug target for treatment of drug resistant infections. The investigation will also develop tools that can be used in vivo to differentiate the dual DNA and RNA topoisomerase activity of human topoisomerase 3B implicated in neurodevelopment and genome stability.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is a devastating autoimmune disease that is characterized by high autoantibody titers and elevated type I interferon (IFN) responses. Our use of powerful new techniques, including single cell gene expression analysis, has generated data indicating a universal natural safe- guardian pathway that locks the B-cell at a type I IFN quiescent non-responsive status. The loss of this pathway promotes the maturation of self-antigen reactive B cells stimulated by type I IFN. This paradigm shifting hypothesis will be tested using advanced in vivo and in vitro techniques to distinguish the roles of intrinsic B cell defects and environmental signals; test the proposed imprinting of the maturing B cells and its effects on quiescent induction and maintenance; and test if the intrinsic or imprinted B cell defects correspond to B-cell dysregulation in SLE patients at the Birmingham VA Medical Center.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The cellular position of mitochondria is intimately connected to both mitochondrial and cellular function. Central to mitochondrial positioning are molecular tethers, which exert spatial, temporal, and contextual control over the position of the organelle and anchor mitochondria to other organelles forming sites of contact that facilitate interorganelle communication. The goal of the proposed project is to understand the mechanism and regulation of mitochondrial tethers and the multifunctional interorganelle contact sites they create, providing insight into ways regulated mitochondrial tethering can be harnessed to influence mitochondrial function and overall cellular homeostasis and fitness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE:  Therapies aimed at unleashing the immune system to attack cancer have demonstrated remarkable effectiveness in recent years for some patients but fail to benefit many others. This project builds on the recent discovery that targeting an RNA editing protein called ADAR1 can trigger anti-viral immunity and markedly improve responses to these immunotherapies. Specifically, it aims to better define the mechanisms by which targeting ADAR1 can make immunotherapy work better and to discover new ways of triggering these mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The treatment of malaria is vitally dependent on artemisinin-based combination therapies (ACTs), yet their continued efficacy is threatened by the emergence and spread of drug-resistant strains of the causative agent, the parasite Plasmodium falciparum. Here we test the hypothesis that the emergence of K13 mutations in Africa will cause artemisinin resistance, but with a fitness cost that is likely to hinder its dissemination in high- transmission settings. We will also define determinants of resistance ACT partner drugs, providing molecular markers to inform regional malaria treatment and control strategies designed to mitigate the impact of multidrug resistance in Africa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  In order to cause infections, bacteria must sense antimicrobial peptides produced by the human immune system and respond by activating resistance and other virulence genes. Here, we will use a cutting-edge genetic engineering technology to reveal how bacteria use a specialized two-component system pathway to detect these antimicrobial peptides and what role those processes play in causing infections. We will also develop new peptides that “jam” this two-component system, and could lead to sorely-needed antibacterial therapeutics. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal describes research to study how ribosomes are assembled in yeast and Hela cells, and how ribosome biogenesis is interconnected with the structure and function of the nucleolus, the cellular compartment where ribosomes are made. As the ribonucleoprotein machines that catalyze protein synthesis in all cells, ribosomes are essential for and closely linked to the growth, proliferation, and adaptation of cells. Consequently, dysregulation of ribosome synthesis or nucleolar structure results in cancers, anemias, neurodegenerative diseases, and a variety of developmental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The mechanisms underlying M. tuberculosis (Mtb) transmission are poorly understood. We recently identified a nociceptive-neuron activating, cough-inducing molecule from Mtb called sulfolipid-1 (SL-1). We will discover the signaling mechanism triggered by SL-1 in neurons and in experimental animals. We also identified a second nociceptive molecule and propose to characterize its activity in parallel to studies on SL-1. Finally, we will develop a safe and effective system for measuring Mtb transmission from naïve to infected animals that will simultaneously determine other factors associated with transmission including Mtb-induced cough and aerosolized Mtb particle production. We will then use this system to analyze the transmission dynamics of Mtb strains lacking cough inducing molecules to determine relationships between Mtb genes and transmissibility. This approach represents the first systematic analysis of cough-inducing molecules in mycobacterial transmission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chimeric antigen receptor T-cell therapy targeting CD19 (CAR19) has revolutionized the treatment landscape for children and young adults with relapsed or refractory B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Unfortunately, however, approximately 50% of children relapse after initial response to CAR19 and their subsequent survival is dismal. This proposal aims to optimize outcomes after post-CAR19 relapse through two mutually informative approaches: 1) A phase 1/2 clinical trial testing the delivery of a novel, dual-antigen targeted CAR designed to overcome the primary mechanisms of CAR19 failure; and 2) An advanced comparative effectiveness study to determine optimal existing salvage treatment approaches for post-CAR19 relapse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal outlines nickel-catalyzed carbon-carbon bond-forming strategies to synthesize hindered stereocenters with α-heteroatom functionality. These motifs are abundant in drug scaffolds and biologically active molecules but can be challenging to efficiently prepare through current methods. Expediating their syntheses will broaden the accessible chemical space in the development of novel pharmaceutical candidates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  A group of marine snails (Conus) have evolved complex venoms that allow them to catch fish; this project aims at understanding how the diverse venom components act to change the physiology of fish and other vertebrates, including humans. Because each individual component of the venom acts like a drug,these individual venom compounds have great biomedical potential; one has become an approved drug for pain, and two others reached human clinical trials (for epilepsy and spinal cord injury pain). By greatly increasing the number of defined venom components, and having insight into how each acts, many more therapeutic and diagnostic uses should emerge.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) has transformed the treatment of pancreaticobiliary diseases in the United States (US) but outcomes of the procedure, and it’s most dreaded complication, post- ERCP pancreatitis, can vary by the physician performing the procedure. Despite this known variability, there have been no national population-based studies aimed at understanding the patient, provider, and system level factors that influence these variations and whether potential interventions, such as selective referral to high volume physicians, may mitigate these risks. Understanding factors that contribute to variations in care, as proposed in this project, has the potential to improve patient outcomes, reduce the cost of care after an ERCP, and shape future policy initiatives around the practice and delegation of ERCP resources in the US.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cognitive decline and incident dementia are major clinical and public health problems that significantly impact the growing population of older ESRD adults. Secondary hyperparathyroidism (SHPT), characterized by elevated PTH, represents an ESRD-specific modifiable risk factor for cognitive decline and incident dementia in older ESRD adults. We hypothesize that PTH likely causes cognitive decline and incident dementia both directly and indirectly via release of other SHPT biomarkers and can be modified with treatment.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although combination antiretroviral therapy (cART) has significantly improved the life expectancy of people living with HIV infection, cART alone cannot cure the infection and must be taken for life to prevent disease progression. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: When suffering starvation, bacteria produce a universally conserved second messenger, ppGpp, which reprograms cellular physiology, arrests growth, and thereby enhances bacterial persistence against antibiotic treatment. By developing two innovative techniques to identify RNA-metabolite and protein-metabolite interactions, respectively, this proposal will examine the roles of small-molecule metabolites in coordinating various cellular activities in response to ppGpp induction. The proposed research will provide new insights on the mechanisms of ppGpp-mediated growth arrest, and elucidate key regulatory interactions required for bacterial persistence: these interactions may serve as targets for the design of anti-persistence drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK STATE PSYCHIATRIC INSTITUTE DBA RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR MENTAL HYGIENE, INC
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is accumulating evidence indicating that sleep disturbance could lead to Alzheimer's disease (AD) pathology and related cognitive decline; therefore, understanding the effects of sleep interventions on cognition could enhance our understanding of sleep disturbance as a modifiable risk factor for AD. The current K23 proposal aims to examine this important research question by investigating neurocognitive effects of two sleep interventions (cognitive-behavioral therapy for insomnia [CBTI] and acoustic slow-wave activity enhancement [SWAE]) and their underlying mechanisms in individuals with amnestic mild cognitive impairment (aMCI). The overarching goal of this project is to support a research career to study sleep interventions as novel therapeutic approaches to prevent or delay AD progression.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Nearly one in four VA patients is affected by type 2 diabetes, a rate 2.5 times higher than the general US population. T2D is the leading cause of blindness, end-stage renal disease and amputations in the VA population, exerting a significant burden on Veterans as well as the VA health care system. Insufficient release of insulin from the pancreatic islet β cell is a critical defect in the pathogenesis of type 2 diabetes. Recent work has highlighted a key role for the islet vasculature in supporting normal health and function of the islet β cell, while also showing islet vascular pathology in type 2 diabetes. This proposal will investigate novel mechanisms underlying the development of this islet vascular pathology and its effect to impair β-cell function and survival. The findings from this work will also be relevant for the microvascular disease that affects many tissues in T2D. These studies may therefore pave the way for development of new vascular-targeted therapies which could treat multiple aspects of T2D pathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: This project seeks to help people with severe Parkinson disease improve their treatment options and therapy through novel approaches including both dual deep brain stimulation electrode treatment and advanced closed loop medical device technology. The adaptive control of Parkinson symptoms will be based on local field potentials, internal and external accelerometers, and wearable measurement devices. These studies will make important contributions to public health, building upon rapid advances in technology to give subjects improved surgical and symptomatic therapy for a common illness, Parkinson disease. Additionally, this clinical research will also help improve our understanding of how a combination of intrinsic brain signals and wearable device information can be used as part of a novel surgical treatment to provide better clinical solutions to the affected subjects through automatic, dynamic device adjustments.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF SCIENCES, TECH & TECH OF BAMAKO
PHR: Project Narrative The recent epidemics of Ebola in West Africa and the current COVID-19 pandemic highlight the need for a critical mass of well-trained scientists and health research professionals capable of studying and responding appropriately, and in timely manner, to emerging infectious diseases outbreaks. This training program offers high-level training in field and laboratory epidemiology, translational clinical research, public health emergency management and genomic characterization and surveillance of emerging infectious pathogens. This proposed project is a south-south collaborative research training program between the University of Bamako (USTTB) and the University of Conakry in Guinea, supported by Johns Hopkins University and NIAID. It will contribute to a more coordinated cross-border approach of public health preparedness and response to emerging infectious diseases epidemics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: Project Narrative Sickle cell disease (SCD) is a hemoglobinopathy associated with severe bone abnormalities including osteoporosis, yet tragically, there are no effective therapies or confirmed mechanisms for SCD-associated bone disease. Since fibroblast growth factor 23 (FGF23) is increased in human anemia, and serum FGF23 and hypophosphatemia are increased in humanized Townes SCD mice (that are anemic but not in renal failure), we posit that FGF23 cross-talk involving bone, kidney, and blood contributes to osteoporosis in SCD mice. We will investigate the mechanism(s) and therapeutic potential of an FDA-approved FGF23 blocking antibody for treating SCD-associated bone disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it addresses the unmet need for adequate treatment strategies for female genital schistosomiasis (FGS), which causes persistent genital mucosal disease in approximately 70% of women despite treatment with anti-schistosome praziquantel therapy. By identifying genital mucosal immune, epithelial, and viral alterations that persist after praziquantel therapy, we may identify novel therapeutic strategies that could include modifying the host mucosal immune response, promoting epithelial healing, and suppressing mucosal viral shedding. Therefore, this proposed research is relevant to the NIH's mission of fostering “innovative research strategies… for protecting and improving health,” as well as specifically responsive to the NIAID's goal to better understand and treat one of “the world's most intractable and wide-spread diseases,” with potential to improve the lives of millions of girls and women suffering from chronic FGS in Africa.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Project Narrative The national prevalence and mortality due to chronic liver diseases (CLDs) and hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in VA health care users have increased by approximately 3-fold during the last decade. Effective treatment for HCC represents unmet medical needs. Understanding the key mechanisms of liver disease progression to HCC will help develop effective treatments for these devastating diseases. This project will test the hypothesis that doublecortin-like kinase 1 (DCLK1)/β- catenin signaling axis is a key mediator of tumorigenesis and immune dysregulation in the tissue microenvironment of CLDs, which collectively stimulates the transformation of liver cells and modify innate immunity for supporting tumor growth. The proposed work will help define an attractive new anti-DCLK1 approach to prevent and treat HCC in US Veterans including the general public.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Aedes aegypti is the primary mosquito vector that transmits the arboviruses, dengue, Zika, chikungunya and yellow fever in the Western Hemisphere. These studies will identify biochemical pathways that change in the mosquito following infection with these viruses. They will also identify how the endosymbiont Wolbachia used to control virus transmission in Aedes aegypti may be metabolically competing with the virus. Identifying the biochemical pathways that are integral to mosquito biology and to transmission of these viruses provide a novel avenue to interfere with vector transmission of the virus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Despite the prevalence of heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF), existing therapies are ineffective and demonstrate the desperate need for a novel therapeutic target. This project aims to understand how the macrophage anti-inflammatory receptor MerTK may be driving HFpEF, as patients present with elevated serum levels of soluble Mer. Specifically, how MerTK signaling may promote upregulation of fibrotic pathways within cardiac macrophages and how this can be targeted to ameliorate disease will be explored.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Since 1968, there has, on average every three years, been a vaccine mismatch for A/H3N2 due to antigenic evolution between the time of vaccine strain selection and the following influenza season when the vaccine is used. In the proposed work we test the “fitness exchange” hypothesis as the underlying mechanism of seasonal influenza virus evolution. Further we build a prediction framework that integrates empirical and computation data in a way that can directly inform the vaccine strain selection process, offering the possibility to see into the evolutionary future of the virus and make vaccine strain selection decisions informed by this information. This work is not solely judging the relative fitness of existing viruses, but is generating and testing viruses that have yet to evolve.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Children and young adults with T-cell lymphoblastic leukemia (T-ALL) and T-cell lymphoblastic lymphoma (T- LL) are usually treated the same. We have new data from clinical trials showing that T-ALL and T-LL patients respond differently to glucocorticoids and proteasome inhibitors. We need to understand why they responded differently so we can develop better treatments and cure more patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: There are an estimated 310,000 sudden deaths from heart disease in the United States each year. These deaths are the result of a fatal heart rhythm disturbance most often occurring in patients with underlying coronary artery disease who do not have evidence for severe heart damage. The present study aims to more accurately identify people who are at risk for developing life-threatening heart rhythm disturbances using blood tests and electrocardiograms (ECGs) so that we can intervene and prevent these sudden deaths.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL), the most common aggressive B cell lymphoma, is a significant clinical problem, with only 60% of patients cured; how lymphoma cells evade host defenses is poorly understood. Growing evidence suggests that gut microbiota play important roles in regulating immunity and that diversity and species of gut bacteria may impact the response to treatment. The proposed study is the first large scale prospective and longitudinal evaluation of the relationship between the gut microbiota in DLBCL, systemic immunity, and treatment response; if successful this research will uncover a new minimally toxic therapeutic paradigm, which will profoundly impact clinical care for lymphoma patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neurofibromatosis type 1-associated atypical neurofibromas (ANF) are precursor lesions for a highly aggressive form of soft tissue sarcoma that is uniformly fatal in persons with unresectable disease. Here we propose to develop a robust preclinical-clinical pipeline to accelerate the translation of novel single agent and combination therapies to effectively treat ANF and prevent malignant transformation, while identifying robust biomarkers associated with treatment response. Our integrated and multidisciplinary approach will address the challenges of cancer prevention in an orphan cancer predisposition syndrome and uniquely vulnerable patient population for which no effective medical therapies currently exist.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Novel antimycobacterial agents, including bedaquiline, and combination antiretroviral therapy containing integrase strand transfer inhibitors, newly available in South Africa, have the potential to revolutionize the treatment of drug-resistant tuberculosis (DR-TB) HIV co-infection, but challenges to medication adherence threaten optimal clinical outcomes and emergent drug resistance. Using a Bayesian, adaptive study design, this project will efficiently evaluate the relative contribution of psychosocial and mHealth adherence interventions, separately and in combination, to improve clinical and biological DR-TB HIV outcomes; understand the mechanism of action of the intervention using a socio-behavioral model and the effect of dual DR-TB and HIV stigma on adherence; and use qualitative methods to delineate patient-centered pathways of care. High-level medication adherence improves mortality, treatment outcomes and reduces transmission for TB and HIV; identifying optimal strategies to enhance adherence may benefit individuals and improve population-level TB and HIV control.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Project Narrative Although smoking tobacco is a leading cause of preventable mortality in adults worldwide, there are few pharmacological smoking cessation aids available and their efficacy is limited. The habenulo-interpeduncular pathway represents an understudied brain circuit that has been found to be involved in nicotine withdrawal symptoms and the aversive motivational properties of nicotine; however, the effects of nicotine on this circuit within the context of reward-related behavior is unknown. Results from this project will elucidate specific neurophysiological mechanisms of nicotine reward/aversion balance within the habenulo-interpeduncular circuit in freely behaving animal models which will contribute to the development of precise treatments for nicotine addiction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative With the increase in auto-immune diseases and emerging concerns of compromised immunity in our aging culture and vulnerable children, understanding T cell signaling, metabolic processes, and the resources required for proper immune response and functioning are extremely relevant to public health. This project explores how metabolism is controlled in T cell immune responses at the level of precise biochemical reaction and molecular interactions, which are amenable to pharmacologic manipulation. This proposal will enable developing novel therapeutic interventions by targeting the metabolic and signaling pathways for T cell-mediated inflammatory and auto-immune diseases, which aligns with the NIAID’s mission to conduct and support basic and applied research to understand better, treat, and ultimately prevent infectious, immunologic, and allergic diseases.

PHR: Narrative Eighty percent of children with advanced or metastatic sarcoma will die from disease despite aggressive multimodality therapy. In this proposal we aim to define less-toxic and more effective targeted therapeutic approaches in high-risk RAS-driven Embryonal Rhabdomyosarcoma (ERMS) by using patient-derived xenograft models, omics and novel single-mouse testing approaches. Our focus is inhibition of MAPK signaling as potential therapeutic strategy to treat ERMS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Misinformation about prostate cancer is widely disseminated on popular social networks, and it is unknown to what extent this plays a role in the observed health disparities among Black and Hispanic men. We will study the types of misinformation about prostate cancer being widely disseminated on social media in English and Spanish, its implications for decision-making among Black and Hispanic men with prostate cancer or at-risk for prostate cancer, and whether a brief media literacy intervention or health literacy intervention helps to mitigate the impact of misinformative content. Our proposed work seeks to advance health equity for Black and Hispanic men by identifying and addressing the problem of online misinformation about prostate cancer.

PHR: The Research Symposium in Communication Sciences and Disorders aims to strengthen the scientific base and increase the research capacity of the discipline, which will lead to improvements in the communication health of millions people with communication or related disorders. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE I aim to understand the molecular and cellular mechanisms underlying blood stem cell niche clonal and transcriptional remodeling in myelodysplastic syndrome. I will use lineage tracing, confocal imaging and mosaic mutagenesis to determine and visualize the clonal changes of diseased endothelial and stromal niche cells and evaluate the role of candidate signaling pathways in niche remodeling. These studies will enhance our understanding of the role of the HSPC niche in hematological disorders and will identify new therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Chronic pain is a highly debilitating disorder that adversely impacts the lives of millions of people. Opioid analgesics are commonly prescribed for chronic pain relief because they modulate endogenous opioid signaling in pain-encoding neural circuits; however, these drugs carry substantial abuse and overdose liabilities due to their broad actions on reward- and breathing-related brain regions. For this reason, my proposal will interrogate the critical pain-responsive endogenous opioid circuit of the periaqueductal gray to enhance our understanding of the cell types and neural pathways engaged by opioid compounds and inform future neurocircuit-focused chronic pain therapies that lack the harmful risks of opioid drugs.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: For Veterans with leg amputation, comfort during daily use of their prosthesis is of paramount importance. Comfort can affect the satisfaction with their prosthesis, use of their prosthesis, and ultimately their mobility and independence. There is some limited evidence to suggest that comfort is directly linked to the pressures experienced by the amputated limb while in the prosthetic socket and that these pressures are affected by how forces are transferred from the ground to the amputated limb. The way in which those pressures are applied to the amputated limb can be influenced by the position of the prosthesis, but also by the flexibility of the prosthesis. The aim of this study is to help us better understand the relationships between prosthesis user comfort, pressures applied to the amputated limb, and prosthetic foot flexibility to improve Veterans’ experience using a leg prosthesis. We will use a new robotic prosthesis to study those relationships and test the possibility of using pressures applied to the amputated limb to automatically adjust prosthesis flexibility to improve comfort.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE It is unclear how the long-lasting effects of environmental exposure persist across generations and contribute to chronic diseases in later life. We use inorganic arsenic as a prototype environmental chemical to dissect the epigenetic inheritance mechanisms in animal models. The mechanistic insights from this study will advance our understanding of the cross-generational effects of environmental exposure on metabolic physiology through the disruption of the endocrine system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Despite maximal surgery, radiation and chemotherapy, glioblastoma (GBM) remains invariably recalcitrant, and necessitates development of new therapies. We have developed a novel FDA-IND approved agent (BB-19304, Sayour) utilizing RNA-nanoparticles (RNA-NPs) to reprogram innate/adaptive immunity against GBM. In this proposal, we will explore the mechanistic underpinnings of RNA-NP mediated response in murine/large animal models before pursuing a first-in-human clinical trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Edible sprouts pose a high risk for outbreaks of foodborne illnesses that typically originate in the seeds due to trace amounts of human enteric pathogens, which thrive under the warm, humid conditions needed for sprout production. Ascribe Bioscience is developing a novel sprout treatment product based on a natural molecule that activates plant defenses, offering reliable long-term protection against a broad range of bacterial pathogens. Successful development of this innovation has the potential to dramatically improve the safety of edible sprouts and reduce the incidence of sprout-related foodborne illness outbreaks, by uniquely conferring protection that begins at the seed stage and persists through growth, harvest, and up to the point of consumption.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Cannabis edibles pose unique public health challenges as they are packaged as appealing food products and may be perceived as less harmful than smoking cannabis, despite the greater danger of severe intoxication. Because their psychoactive effects are delayed and longer lasting, it is difficult for users to titrate their dose which can result in the overconsumption of high amounts of tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) and acute adverse consequences. This project will address gaps in our understanding of how edibles package marketing contributes to harm perceptions and risk for overconsumption and how to effectively communicate knowledge about safe consumption through package warnings to guide state policymakers as they establish state regulatory guidelines for cannabis edibles to minimize harms and protect public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The importance of understanding the role of mitochondrial respiration in ulcer healing and determining clinical phenotypes in inflammatory bowel disease has been recently strengthened by major prospective clinical studies in pediatric Crohn’s (Kugathasan et al Lancet) and ulcerative colitis (Haberman) patients. Studies proposed here use a novel genetically-engineered mouse model of mitochondrial deficiency in combination with single cell RNAseq analysis of normal and diseased (CD/UC) patients. We posit this work will identify key mechanisms that underlie the cause of nonhealing ulceration in IBD with the goal of identifying targets for new drug development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Enteroviruses are ubiquitous pathogens causing a number of important human diseases including respiratory disease, hand foot and mouth disease, myocarditis, and acute flaccid myelitis. Outbreaks of non-poliovirus enteroviruses such as EV-D68 and EV-A71 cause severe neuropathology in children. Our contributions will have wide-reaching impacts as the identified cellular genes and molecular mechanisms are likely to provide new targets for therapeutic interventions, in addition to fundamentally advancing the fields of viral neuropathogenic disease modeling and stem cell engineering.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Therapeutic combinations targeting autophagy appear promising for melanoma and other cancers, and we have discovered that alterations in lipid rafts are associated with resistance to autophagy-modulating therapies. This proposal will address a major unanswered question: Can targeting therapy-induced lipid raft assembly enhance the efficacy of autophagy-modulating therapy? Knowledge gleaned from this work will provide a fundamental understanding of how autophagy inhibition can be used most effectively in the clinic and may provide a new combination therapy approach that can improve cancer patient survival in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative (Public Health Relevancy Statement) Obesity trends may be the result of failure to sustain weight loss maintenance (WLM); therefore, there is an urgent need to test new bio-behavioral strategies to prevent weight regain. Time-restricted eating (TRE), reducing the eating window to 6–10 hours per day, is an untested bio-behavioral strategy that may be helpful for WLM. This proposal seeks to develop and TRE intervention and test efficacy for preventing weight regain following successful weight loss in a free-living setting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: 5-methylcytosine (m5C) is an understudied but important RNA modification, often dysregulated in developmental disorders, cancer and more. We propose a comprehensive study exploiting RNA viruses whose genomes are m5C methylated to understand the role of m5C in regulating RNA biology, including the activities responsible for adding and recognizing this modification. In addition to significantly advancing the m5C field, this work will also contribute to the development of antiviral strategies against viruses causing significant human disease such as chikungunya virus and Coxsackie virus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Transthyretin V122I, is a highly penetrant mutation for hereditary transthyretin amyloid cardiomyopathy (hATTR-CM) that is common in African Americans and Hispanic Americans. Recent therapies have been approved to treat hATTR-CM, which have led to decreased mortality; thus, understanding who will develop hATTR-CM, accurate identification of V122I carriers and understanding hidden disease burden is important. In this proposal, we examine the population health impact of V122I using polygenic risk scores, machine learning approaches on electronic health records, and patient recall by genotype, which can lead to new population health strategies for heart failure in racial and ethnic minorities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because understanding the circuit, synaptic and molecular mechanisms by which subcortical circuitry supports wakefulness is ultimately expected to increase understanding of how wakefulness and associated electrographic rhythms are produced and maintained. As such the proposed research is relevant to the part of NIH’s mission that pertains to developing fundamental knowledge that may yield improved pharmacologic approaches and interventional strategies, and thereby reduce the burdens of human disability, in not only arousal-based disorders such as coma, but also in a host of neuropsychiatric and neurodegenerative disorders, including Alzheirmer’s disease, Parkinson’s disease, schizophrenia and the cognitive impairments of normal aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative: Auditory Mechanics and Cochlear Amplification 2020 The ear's ability to discriminate frequencies is fundamental to hearing; this ability is based in the cochlear amplifier, a cell-based, electromechanical engine that is both powerful and fragile. The cochlear amplifier degrades due to aging, illness, from exposure to loud sounds, and following some treatments for infection and cancer. This project uses purpose-built sensors and sensing techniques to probe the constellation of factors that is required for healthy cochlear amplification, and to understand how the amplifier fails -- in order to advance our ability to treat hearing loss and to devise strategies to reduce it.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative The utility of patient-specific pluripotent stem cells (PSCs) for the study of development and disease is compromised by the frequent introduction of aberrant chromatin marks in these cells. The aim of this proposal is to better understand the molecular reasons for these abnormalities and to develop novel approaches that prevent their occurrence. Our work will facilitate the rational design of improved protocols for the generation and propagation of high-quality stem cell lines for a wide range of biomedical applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Developmental patterning is a crucial biological mechanism perturbations of which are related to a plethora of developmental disorders. Developmental patterning in the olfactory epithelium, as manifested by the zonal expression of olfactory receptor genes remains mysterious for decades. Here, we describe genetic and epigenetic factors regulating zonal olfactory receptor expression, and we seek to uncover regulatory principles that are applicable to other systems undergoing developmental patterning.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: 8. Project Narrative The goal of this project is to develop and combine novel 3D UTE MRI techniques to evaluate cortical and trabecular bone offering full insight into bone characterization and correlation with function. In the cadaveric human bone studies the 3D UTE MRI techniques will be compared with reference techniques including µCT, histomorphometry, Raman spectroscopy, and biomechanical testing as reference standard. In the human studies the 3D UTE MRI techniques will be applied to elderly women (age > 70y) with (n = 30) and without (n=30) osteoporosis, with osteopenia (n = 30) and with ROD (n = 30), as well as a group of young healthy women (age < 40y, n = 30), to compare the 3D UTE biomarkers in the different groups and correlate the results with BMD, biochemical markers and fracture history.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the availability of an effective vaccine, epidemiologic data estimates about 2 billion people in the world are infected with hepatitis B virus (HBV) and approximately 350 million people are chronic HBV carriers and at high risk for the development of hepatitis, cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). Current treatment options suppress the virus but do not cure, requiring costly lifetime therapy. The goal of this proposal is to validate our novel class of highly potent Capsid Assembly Modulators (CAM), which, when combined with other modalities (e.g., nucleoside analogs), could provide preclinical “proof of concept” towards a novel therapeutic strategy to eliminate HBV and with potential to reduce treatment duration and eliminate progression to HCC.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will elucidate the fundamental biological processes by which the immune system contributes to maintenance of the mucosal barrier. This essential knowledge is required to understand mucosal surveillance during intestinal homeostasis and in response to pathogen infection. IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative To implant into the mother’s womb and give rise to a viable fetus, the preimplantation mammalian embryo must produce the right number of embryonic and extraembryonic cell types. Using the early mouse embryo as a powerful and accessible model, we will investigate the molecular and cellular mechanisms which ensure that developmental programs are executed in a timely and spatially ordered manner and that an adequate number of cells are generated to build an embryo. Our work will reveal fundamental insights into the regulatory principles of early mammalian development and serve as a basis for understanding how errors in these processes lead to developmental disorders or pregnancy loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Following epilepsy surgery, roughly half of patients will continue to have seizures, and 70-90% will remain on anti-seizure medications. Using data recorded from the brains of epilepsy patients, we propose to develop and validate computerized tools to accurately and objectively identify epileptic brain regions. This will improve surgical decision making, make epilepsy surgery available to more patients, and ultimately improve the lives of patients with the most severe types of epilepsy.

PHR: Narrative: To make breakthroughs against lethal metastatic cancers, we need to identify the molecular mechanisms that allow cancer cells to escape existing line of treatments. In this project, we will develop an automated blood-to-barcode chip that accelerates CRISPR-based discovery efforts to identify druggable targets. Using systematic target validation and testing of drug-like molecules for establishing clinical utility, we provide a framework to expedite the development of new line of effective treatments against metastatic cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Bacterial vaginosis (BV) is characterized by low levels of protective vaginal bacteria (Lactobacilli), is associated with serious sequelae, such as HIV and STI acquisition, and is asymptomatic in 55% of women. It is unknown if risks for adverse outcomes differ between women with asymptomatic (aBV) versus symptomatic (sBV), yet current guidelines only indicate antibiotic treatment for symptomatic women, leaving asymptomatic women potentially at risk. We will leverage a large database of existing data to determine whether behavioral factors and the vaginal microenvironment differ between aBV and sBV, generating data which will inform a better understanding of the entity of aBV, new studies of associations between aBV, HIV, STIs, and, in the long term, studies of aBV treatment in order to improve reproductive health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARATIVE Our proposal aims to analyze the mechanisms by which immune therapies for cancer (checkpoint inhibitors) cause thyroid disease. Our focus is on the intrinsic functions of the checkpoint molecule, PD-L1, in the thyroid, and how blocking it causes thyroid cell stress and thyroiditis. These studies will identify the mechanisms by which checkpoint inhibitors cause thyroiditis and will hopefully help in the development of novel therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Racial-ethnic segregation exists in multiple forms within ambulatory (outpatient) settings in the US. To eliminate structural racism and discrimination from healthcare, we must identify, quantify, and address the factors that contribute to segregated care, and design strategies to eliminate practice segregation. Our study leverages a natural experiment underway as an Anti-Racism Roadmap is implemented across a large health system. First, we will describe the level of segregation in NYC hospital affiliated ambulatory practices and examine the associations between the level of segregation and selected quality measures of care. We will then look regionally, at the relationship of segregation, practice characteristics and perceived racism within the largest academic center in NYC. Finally, we will observe the impact of implemented equity interventions, barriers and facilitators of clinic unification and explore their potential societal impact on health.
PI_NAMEs: BICKELL, NINA A. (contact);HOROWITZ, CAROL R;RICHARDSON, LYNNE D.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: NARRATIVE In the past period, we established mouse MRI is a feasible approach to establish fingerprints for both structural and functional adaptations of the whole brain connectome to alcohol exposure. Here we will expand this methodology and develop new analytic methods to answer three questions: (i) do alcohol fingerprints differ along the drinking trajectory, and between sexes? (ii) can we classify and predict drinking behavior and drug effects for individual subjects from MRI? and (iii) can we bridge MRI data with molecular immune brain mapping (INIA synergy)?

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Deep brain stimulation (DBS) is used for treatment of Parkinson's disease and many neuropsychiatric disorders. Researchers and clinicians have used 3-dimensional computer models of patient brains (based on their MRI) to predict how far stimulation effects spread around DBS electrode with the goal of understanding which brain areas are important in DBS and to improve DBS programming. We plan to test the accuracy of different DBS models variants by comparing their predictions of neural activations to experimental evoked potential measurements and to clinical side effects in patients with Parkinson's disease.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative Body art has experienced a steady increase in popularity in the U.S., leading to many jurisdictions rapidly enacting new regulations. Environmental health professionals are responsible for inspecting facilities to meet regulatory requirements, but there is a proven lack of comprehensive education and training, making inspections a learn-as-you-go process. The proposed Body Art Training Development Workshops, utilizing industry knowledge and regulatory experience, will develop training programs to provide a consistent, informed approach to the inspection of body art facilities.

PROJECT_TITLE: National Environmental Health Association (NEHA) Body Art Training Updates and Delivery

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: The neural crest gives rise to most of the skeletal elements of the face and is implicated in many congenital birth defects. Expanding our understanding of molecular programs controlling neural crest formation will provide insight into the genetic basis of craniofacial disease. Novel mechanisms uncovered in this work may have important implications for the diagnosis and treatment of craniofacial defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The goal of this project is to characterize the neurodegeneration in and determine the mechanism of survival of a new knock-in rat model of the Alzheimer disease-associated L435F mutation in Presenilin 1. The novel report of the survival of these rats, despite a γ-secretase loss of function phenotype, will allow for a more precise investigation of the role of Presenilin 1 in neurodegeneration that is available with current animal models. The findings from our proposed studies will broaden our understanding of the causes of neurodegeneration in Alzheimer's disease.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative NEHA proposes to apply awarded funding towards three projects related to an online workshop series that supports State, Local, Tribal, and Territorial (SLTT) agencies’ Self-Assessment and Verification Audit process, which in turn assists them in their conformance with FDA’s Voluntary National Retail Food Regulatory Program Standards (VNRFRPS, henceforth Retail Program Standards). These projects will serve approximately 900 Retail Program Standards enrollees and will include continuous improvement updates to existing content to align with updates to the Retail Program Standards, development of an entry-level course for professionals new to the Retail Program Standards, and production of a risk-based retail food safety inspection film.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative: ABO(H) blood group antigens were the first human polymorphisms described and corresponding anti-ABO(H) antibodies continue to be the most common immunological barrier to transfusion and transplantation. However, despite their discovery over a century ago, the factors that govern the development of anti-ABO(H) antibody and the consequences of ABO(H) incompatibility remain relatively unknown. Using a series translational studies coupled with a new preclinical model of anti-blood group antibody formation, this overarching program project grant (PPG) will define key factors that govern ABO(H) immunity and incompatibility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative (Core B): Naturally occurring anti-ABO(H) antibodies, which represent the most common immunological barrier to transfusion and transplantation, can vary in titer and specificity, resulting in distinct clinical outcomes. Importantly, formation of these antibodies is directly linked to host interaction with specific microbial strains that express blood group carbohydrate antigens. The overarching goal of Core B is to provide tools that facilitate assessment of the role of microbial populations in driving and shaping naturally occurring anti- blood group antibody responses and their clinical consequences. To this end, we will provide microbial arrays for the high throughput analysis of both innate and adaptive immune interactions relevant to anti-ABO(H) antibody formation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative: ABO(H) blood group antigens were the first human polymorphisms described and corresponding anti-ABO(H) antibodies continue to be the most common immunological barrier to transfusion and transplantation. However, despite their discovery over a century ago, the factors responsible for anti-ABO(H) antibody development remain relatively unknown. Using a series translational studies coupled with a new preclinical model of anti-blood group antibody formation, we will define key factors that influence the development of anti-ABO(H) antibodies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative: Anti-ABO(H) antibodies, which form spontaneously within the first few months of life, represent the most common immunological barrier to transfusion and transplantation. However, these antibodies can vary widely between individuals, with significant differences in the levels and specificity of anti-ABO(H) antibodies that can have direct clinical consequence on ABO(H) incompatible outcomes. This study will define the fundamental role of innate immune factors in shaping the levels of blood group positive microbes and the ability of these microbes to impact the levels, specificity and overall hemolytic activity of anti-ABO(H) blood group antibodies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Degeneration of the retina is one of the leading causes of blindness in developed countries. With defects in more than 280 genes that are known to result in retinal degeneration, there is a critical need to develop therapies that are broadly effective regardless of the gene defect. This study proposes to use a modified arrestin1 protein to directly increase the glycolysis in rod and cone photoreceptors as a mechanism to improve their function and survival, slowing retinal degeneration and delaying the loss of vision.
