IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Mitochondria constitute 30-40% of heart weight and metabolize fats, and proteins and sugars to generate ATP that powers cardiac contraction. Mitochondrial dysfunction contributes to cardiac hypertrophy, heart failure and myocardial infarction. These common heart diseases exhibit a mismatch between metabolic substrate availability and substrate preference: normal mitochondria prefer fats and proteins that most efficiently make ATP, whereas diseased mitochondria reserve fats and protein to repair heart damage and instead metabolize sugars. It was generally accepted that metabolic transitioning in hearts (from preferring fats to sugars or vice-versa) is simply a matter of genetic programming. However, we discovered that the heart must first rid itself of existing mitochondria before replacing them with those having a metabolic preference matching its condition. We identified a key factor responsible for removal, replacement and redistribution of mitochondria during metabolic transitions and developed a new class of drugs to orchestrate and coordinate activities of these factors, matching preferences of the heart’s mitochondria to its available metabolic “menu”. Moreover, by whole genome and exome sequencing we identified rare gene mutations that impair mitochondrial removal and replacement in patients with hypertrophy or heart failure, potentially revealing a new mechanism of heart failure. Our studies provide a fresh understanding of cardiac metabolism and establish the foundation for a completely new approach for managing heart disease by “dialing in” mitochondrial metabolism to optimize cardiac contraction or repair.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Skin-penetrating parasitic nematodes infect over a billion people worldwide and are a major cause of morbidity in low-resource settings. This grant will investigate the behavioral, neural, and molecular mechanisms of gas sensing in the skin-penetrating human parasite Strongyloides stercoralis. Our results will address how these parasites use gas sensing to find and infect humans, which may inform the design of novel anthelmintics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite recent advances, treatment of tuberculosis still requires giving 3-4 drugs for a minimum of 4-6 months. New drug candidates with potential to contribute to shorter, simpler treatments are in various phases of research and development but the most efficient path for research studies to determine which new and existing drugs should be combined to create novel regimens with the highest probability of achieving this goal remains uncertain. The overarching objective of this project is to unite a diverse group of researchers, drug developers, research sponsors and other stakeholders to develop and pursue a research agenda to develop a validated pipeline of in vitro and mouse models that will inform mathematical models to predict clinical outcomes and enable early and accurate selection of the most promising new treatment regimens to move into clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This program is designed to provide recent college graduates from populations underrepresented (UR) in the biomedical sciences with an intensive research experience, related enrichment activities, and academic advising for a period of one year, possibly longer. The goal of the program is to increase the number of students from UR backgrounds who enroll in a biomedical PhD program and pursue related careers. Ultimately, it is expected that UR biomedical researchers will introduce novel ideas and perspectives from their respective groups into the biomedical workforce, thereby aiding in the reduction of health care disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The development and myelination of the central nervous system (CNS) is influenced by the composition of the early cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) environment, which bathes the developing brain in ions and solutes, growth factors, and signaling ligands. The composition of the CSF is controlled primarily by the choroid plexus (ChP), an epithelial-endothelial structure which secretes important enzymes, including Autotaxin (ATX), that instruct the maturation of oligodendrocytes, and therefore, myelination of the CNS. This study will investigate the developmental role of ChP-secreted ATX in regulating myelination and how this may be perturbed in pathologies such as hemorrhage-induced white matter injury associated with hydrocephalus, with the eventual goal of developing a rational intervention strategy for mitigating white matter injury in neonates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The long-term goal of this project is to improve our understanding of the role of sexual and gender minority (SGM) identity-based discrimination, mistreatment, and violence in early life in producing and reinforcing broad physical and mental health disparities among SGM adult populations. To achieve this goal requires 1. development of measures that accurately assess experiences of SGM-specific adverse childhood experiences (SGM-ACEs), with specific attention towards the intersection of sexual and gender identity to account for the ways in which these experiences are similar, as well as different, and 2. continued tests of the relationships between SGM-ACEs and minority stress factors in adulthood, as well the role of interactions between early life adversity (i.e., SGM-ACEs) and minority stress exposure in adulthood contribute to ongoing physical and mental health disparities in SGM adults. As such this project aims to develop the next iteration of a promising new measure created by our team that assesses exposure to SGM-specific childhood adversity, the SGM-ACEs measure, to be more relevant and universal for SGM communities, and further expand the current Minority Stress Model by taking a life course perspective in explaining the existence of health disparities in SGM populations.

PHR: Title: A novel uterine leiomyosarcoma mouse model for therapeutic development PROJECT NARRATIVE: Uterine leiomyosarcoma is a rare disease but with high-risk of recurrence and metastasis leading to poor survival rate. Little is known about the initiation and development of this disease, and currently, effective treatment is by surgery. We have developed an exciting genetic mouse model with metastatic uterine leiomyosarcoma, which will not only allow us to understanding the initiation and progression of this disease but also evaluating potential therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Plants and photosynthetic microbes are the direct or indirect source of most human foods, micronutrients, and pharmaceuticals, therefore plant biotechnology has the potential to provide great value to human health. To contribute effectively to plant biotechnology, the next generation of plant scientists should develop multidisciplinary expertise across plant biology, biochemistry, metabolic engineering, synthetic biology and computational biology. The Michigan State University Plant Biotechnology for Health and Sustainability Program introduces predoctoral students to these fields and provides them with an awareness of a broad range of careers including academia, government and industry.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) affects nearly 50% of adults over the age of 60 and has a profoundly negative effect on speech comprehension, leading to increased social isolation, reduced quality of life, and increased risk for the development of dementia in older adulthood. The studies in our proposal use combined pupillometry and cognitive event-related brain potentials to characterize the effects of listening effort on comprehension and memory functioning in older adults with and without hearing loss. If successful, this project will lead to the identification of objective and reliable neural markers of comprehension and memory processes impaired by SNHL, leading to better future clinical assessment and the improved design of evidence-based interventions to improve speech comprehension and memory in aging.

PROJECT_TITLE: Understanding the effects of listening effort on sentence processing and memory in sensorineural hearing loss: Evidence from simultaneous electrophysiology and pupillometry

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Traumatic brain injury (TBI) and post-TBI neurological and psychiatric problems are a major medical concern for US military veterans. Most neuroprotective therapies against TBI target gray matter and neglect the importance of white matter (WM) injury, the timely repair of which would promote WM integrity and functional restoration after TBI. The proposed study will explore salt-inducible kinase 1 (SIK1) as a novel and promising therapeutic target for TBI. We will investigate whether genetic deletion or pharmacological inhibition of SIK1 improves long- term TBI outcomes by promoting inflammation-resolving and protective microglial/macrophage responses and WM restoration. We will use state-of-the art approaches, comprehensive and long-term assessment of neurological and psychiatric functions, and both male and female subjects to gain novel mechanistic insights into the role of SIK1 in microglial/macrophage responses, brain inflammation, and WM repair after TBI. This information will be valuable for future development of new therapy against TBI for military men and women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative DYT1 dystonia is an incurable brain disease characterized by involuntary twisting movements for which there are no reliably effective treatments. This proposal employs unique genetic strategies to target a specific class of neurons (striatal cholinergic interneurons) that appear essential to the abnormal movements. These advanced genetic studies will establish the role of cholinergic interneurons in dystonia and test a novel approach to prevent or suppress the disease symptoms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Peripheral artery disease (PAD), an atherosclerotic disease of the leg arteries, puts patients at high risk for myocardial infarction, stroke, and ischemic limb events. Recent trials show that an antithrombotic agent helps reduce such events in PAD, but pre-clinical data suggest this drug may be beneficial through additional pathways. We propose to investigate thrombosis and the pleiotropic effects of antithrombotic therapy in PAD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Antibiotic-resistant bacteria, such as vancomycin-resistant enterococci (VRE) and methicillin- resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA), are major causes of hospital-acquired infections and contribute to an escalating healthcare crisis. The research proposed here promises to reveal new insights into the biological processes driving antibiotic resistance that will facilitate the development of new treatments for infections caused by drug-resistant pathogens. In particular, this work promises to define new targets for innovative therapeutics with potentially unique modes of action.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative A distorted sense of time and diminished capacity to anticipate the future are associated with a number of psychiatric disorders including substance abuse disorder, schizophrenia and depression. Distortions in timing and anticipation are both a symptom of the disorders as well as a source of additional problems. The purpose of this grant is to understand the basic brain mechanisms that underlie these capacities in order to discover new treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Narrative Maintaining blood pressure within normal limits requires regulation of the amount of Na in the body and the volume of extracellular fluids. This is accomplished in part through the actions of aldosterone - a steroid hormone produced by the adrenal gland. Understanding how this hormone acts on renal epithelial cells to control the amounts of Na retained vs. the amount excreted in the urine will help to guide management of patients with hypertension and diseases of the kidney and liver that alter the levels of salt and water in the body.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative Cardiovascular complications, such as heart failure and heart attack are some of the most devastating long- term problems faced by hematopoietic (stem) cell transplantation survivors, and are a common cause of premature death for this vulnerable population. To better understand these complications, we plan to measure stem cell transplantation survivors' cardiovascular health over time, using tests of their heart, lungs, muscles, and other organs. We will use this information to one day prevent cardiovascular complications in hundreds of thousands of stem cell transplant survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The goal of the proposed research is to investigate a novel molecular mechanism regulating microtubule-based intracellular transport in axonal morphogenesis and function. Following our recent studies of two members of a family of microtubule-associated proteins in neurons, we will use molecular, genetic, and cell biological approaches to investigate their regulation of intracellular transport and determine their roles in branch development and nociception. Results from the proposed study will provide a better understanding of transport regulation that is critical to development, function, and pathogenesis of the nervous system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Chemotherapy is often ineffective when treating primary brain tumors because the interface between the bloodstream and the brain, which is called the blood-brain barrier, is not permeable to drugs in the bloodstream. Further, even those drugs that are delivered across the blood-brain barrier do not penetrate tissue effectively. In this proposal, we are testing whether the combination of an MR image-guided drug delivery approach that uses focused ultrasound to temporarily open the blood-brain barrier and a controlled- release nanoparticle formulation that penetrates brain tumor tissue can be used to effectively primary brain tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Astrocytes establish a functional network system through conduit proteins, termed gap junctions, to participate in brain function. This proposal is expected to provide novel insights into the physiological operation of this glial network system through crosstalk with neuronal signalings. By examining astrocyte function at a biologically higher hierarchy, a networking system level, the results are expected to shed light on the still mysterious function of astrocytes, and also establish dataset for further examination of the potential etiological link between dysfunctional astrocyte networks and neurological disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The collateral tissue damage that results from an immune response can cause life-threatening maladies that are sometimes more dangerous than the infection itself. Our research proposal sets out to understand the means by which an immune response is set into motion. By focusing our work on the earliest triggers of immune activation (the detection of microbes) we may unravel new means by which we can control the activation or inactivation of immunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Long-term immunity and the formation of protective memory B and T cells are necessary to survive deadly pandemics, as currently evidenced by COVID-19. Several transcriptional and epigenetic factors have been discovered that control the formation of diverse types of memory T cells, but we know very little about how these factors are targeted within the genome to control gene expression and specify T cell differentiation states. This proposal seeks to discover how BAF complexes, critical nucleosome remodelers, control the transcription factor networks that underlie effector and memory T cell development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Microtubules constitute a major cytoskeletal network required for many diverse and critical cellular functions such as structural support, molecular and vesicle trafficking, etc, that is coordinated from specific organizing centers that vary according to cell type and which serve the unique functions of those cell types. The goals of this proposal are to determine the mechanisms by which one specific and critical microtubule-organizing center (MTOC) functions, and to define new paradigms for microtubule assembly that have emerged from this project and are expected to broadly impact physiology, disease, and development.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS AFFAIRS MED CTR SAN FRANCISCO
PHR: When Veterans miss clinic visits, or `no-show', this is considered a type of access failure. A major challenge in improving no-shows has been identifying and intervening on Veterans who frequently miss scheduled clinic appointments. Previous interventions (e.g. reminder phone calls, etc.) have not substantially improved no-show rates. This research will first develop and test the use of a prediction tool that uses patient-level characteristics to assess Veterans' propensity to miss clinic visits. Then, after obtaining feedback from Veterans at-risk of missing clinic appointments, we will use VA Video Connect (VVC; a newly developed telemedicine-based application that allows Veterans to interact with their VA health care providers using their smartphone, tablet, or computer) as an alternative means of obtaining primary care. This proposal aims to improve access by making it easier for at-risk Veterans to have clinic visits with their VA providers using VVC. The use of VVC in at-risk sub-populations aims to improve no-show rates, patient and provider satisfaction, and clinic efficiency.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: This study will test whether a hand hygiene-based mindfulness intervention can improve provider hand hygiene adherence, improve provider well-being, and enhance Veteran outcomes. Given the importance of hand hygiene adherence and the increasing levels of provider burnout and stress, this work directly aligns with multiple priorities of the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) and will enhance Veteran safety. Our findings will shed light on how to more effectively prevent infections through the use of a novel mindfulness intervention focused on increasing hand hygiene adherence and provider well-being.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Diffuse Optics for Pediatric Hydrocephalus Management Project Narrative Surgical treatment of elevated intracranial pressure (ICP) in hydrocephalus patients is the most common operation performed by pediatric neurosurgeons in the United States. Decision-making about when and if to intervene is hindered by a gap in knowledge about how ventricular enlargement relates to changes in ICP and cerebral blood flow. This research will validate the capabilities of a novel diffuse optical approach for non-invasive detection and prediction of elevated ICP and ischemia in children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Narrative This proposal takes advantage of the ability of pluripotent stem cells (PSC) to uniquely produce differentiated somatic cell types in large quantities. We have developed methods, based on the conditional expression of Pax3 and Pax7, to induce the muscle program in early mesoderm, and thus derive muscle progenitors with great efficiency for regenerative medicine and disease modeling. Our investigations will focus on understanding the effect of the environment on the engraftment of PSC-derived myogenic progenitors, and the molecular signature and long-term regenerative potential of control and gene corrected FKRP mutant PSC-myogenic progenitors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Emerging data suggest that β cell extracellular vesicles (EVs, or membrane bound nanoparticles that carry and transfer molecular cargo) may affect other cells in the islet. The goals of this project are: 1) to define how inflammatory stress is linked to changes in the cargo of β cell EVs; 2) determine functional effects of changes in β cell EV cargo on surrounding β cells; and 3) determine whether β cell EV cargo are altered in humans with or at-risk for diabetes. This work will address a critical gap in knowledge regarding β cell EV biology and has the potential to inform novel diagnostic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The synthetic lethal interaction of BRCA deficiency with PARPi is being exploited therapeutically in diverse clinical contexts (breast, ovarian, pancreatic, and prostate cancers); however, PARPi resistance has emerged as a vexing clinical problem for the treatment of BRCA1/2-deficient carcinomas. Analyses of PARPi resistance in BRCA1-mutant tumors suggest that loss of genes involved in blocking end resection during HR leads to the partial restoration of HR in the absence of BRCA1 activity. This proposal seeks to evaluate the regulation of these end resecting factors and how they can be exploited to identify and develop novel cancer therapeutics to lessen the burden of disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose using a wide range of information from 2379 girls in National Growth and Health Study, 1421 children studied in the Section on Growth and Obesity at the Eunice Shriver Kennedy National Institute of Child Health and Human Development (NICHD), and the 16,850 youth in the Growing Up Today Study to identify subgroups of children and adolescents with obesity. We will then examine whether the subtypes are predictive of weight change in adolescence and young adulthood, the development of hypertension before age 35, or have a differential pattern of association with obesity- related genes and whether the subgroups or their relationships vary by sex or race.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Developmental dysplasia of the hip dramatically increases the risk for early hip osteoarthritis in adolescents and young adults, and is usually treated surgically with a periacetabular osteotomy. The current project will rigorously investigate how periacetabular osteotomy changes hip biomechanics and how those changes are associated with patients’ activity levels and self-reports of function, pain, and quality of life during the first year after surgery. Determining the longitudinal effects of surgery on biomechanics and how they relate to patients’ own perceptions of their recovery will inform new strategies to increase the proportion of patients with DDH who experience better quality of life and delayed osteoarthritis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project is focused on the pathogenesis of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), a chronic autoimmune disease of unknown etiology. The proposed research is relevant to public health as SLE affects 0.1% of the US population, mainly women of child-bearing age, with 10% mortality in 5 to 10 years. There is an unmet medical need as current treatments are only partially effective and carry significant side effects. Development of new therapies has been hampered by gaps in our understanding of pathogenesis. Metabolic pathways that control the production of energy in the form of ATP and generate reactive oxygen intermediates (ROI) have emerged as essential regulators of immune responses and contributors to lupus pathogenesis. Comprehensive metabolome studies indicate that SLE profoundly impacts the utilization of glucose through the pentose phosphate pathway (PPP) eliciting changes that mimic deficiency of a rate-limiting enzyme, transaldolase (TAL). In turn, TAL deficiency elicits activation of the mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR), which has been recently identified as a key sensor of oxidative stress and driver of inflammation in SLE. The results of the proposed studies will bring new breakthroughs in our understanding of how metabolic pathways control oxidative stress during development of autoimmunity that can be harnessed for safe and effective treatment of SLE.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The MU PREP, because of the departments and faculty research mentors involved, will have a natural focus on research training in areas that will address major health problems in the U.S. (e.g., cancer, cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and obesity). Of particular interest are health problems that disproportionately affect portions of the U.S. population. This will hopefully lead to greater interest in and research on those health problems at MU, and to a larger number of biomedical researchers working on those problems when our PREP Scholars, and the colleagues they influence, join the biomedical workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Recurrent herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV-1) infections are significant human health problems that can lead to encephalitis, serious recurrent eye infections, and perhaps an increase in the incidence of Alzheimer's Disease. The ability of HSV-1 to latently infect neurons and then reactivate from latency is required for virus transmission and recurrent disease. Studies in this proposal will characterize the mechanism by which stress and activation of the glucocorticoid receptor disrupts latency and directly stimulates viral gene expression during reactivation from latency.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to develop and establish a novel compressed sensing-based diffusion MRI technique, diffusion dictionary imaging (DDI), to non-invasively and reliably image neuroinflammation in Alzheimer’s disease (AD). By leveraging the established infrastructure of the Knight Alzheimer’s Disease Research center (P50AG05681, P01AG026276, P01AG003991) and Dominantly Inherited Alzheimer Network (DIAN, U19AG032438), we will cost-effectively develop DDI and use it to study the role of neuroinflammation in the sporadic AD and autosomal-dominant AD. The successful development of a quantitative, endogenous DDI biomarker of neuroinflammation will represent a significant technological leap forward and holds significant promise to improve our understanding of the role of neuroinflammation in AD pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We are proposing to take advantage of recent developments in PET imaging technology and algorithms to characterize, optimize, and harmonize cancer detection with PET imaging. This will use new artificial intelligence methods and our recent technical developments to provide more accurate measurements and phantoms for translation across multiple systems and imaging sites. This will lead to a roadmap for multi-site and multi-vendor implementation approaches that improve early-stage cancer detection and diagnosis, and thus improved patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative/Relevance African Americans continue to have poor outcomes after a cancer diagnosis and few African American cohorts exist to support studies of the determinants of cancer prognosis and progression, survival, quality of life and post-treatment outcomes. The proposed continuation of follow-up of this cohort of population-based, African American cancer survivors will provide longer-term outcomes data and biospecimens for a research agenda driven by priorities in the African American community and aimed at understanding and improving cancer outcomes in this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Parkinson’s disease, dementia with Lewy bodies, and other synucleinopathies are neurodegenerative diseases that affect over 10 million people globally, a number that is only expected to increase as the world’s population ages. Numerous, complex interacting genetic and environmental risk factors are involved in the severity and outcome associated with synucleinopathies, making it unclear why some people develop signs of disease while others do not. I will employ novel approaches to study how multiple genetic factors implicated in synucleinopathies interact in an epistatic manner to trigger and amplify neurodegeneration pathology, which will lead to new mechanistic insights and open therapeutic opportunities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Epithelial cells are the primary targets of influenza virus infection and we recently demonstrated significant heterogeneity in the levels of replication and antiviral responses of these cells during initial infection and virus spread in vivo. This proposal will uncover the mechanisms of differential replication and the dynamics of virus tropism during spread in vivo. Together this research will aid our understanding of complex virus-host interactions in vivo.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research project should help us better understand how general anesthetics work, in particular, how they remove consciousness in the anesthetized patient. The knowledge gained should help develop novel approaches to determine the presence or absence of consciousness during general anesthesia and in patients with disorders of consciousness. Using anesthetic drugs as investigational tools, the project should also help understand how nerve cells in the brain collaborate to create human and animal consciousness.

PHR: Project Narrative Dysregulation of mTORC1 signaling is often found in various types of health problems. Our study is designed to test the hypothesis that BASP1 functions as a key activator of mTORC1 acting downstream of NPC1 and upstream of GATOR1 in vitro and in vivo. This will provide new molecular connections between cellular lipid metabolism, anabolic processes, and many human health problems such as obesity, diabetes, lysosomal storage diseases, neurodegenerative diseases, and cancer development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will study the specific causal impact of three modifiable family processes—parental monitoring, parental warmth, and family conflict—on substance abuse and delinquency during adolescence in a diverse, population-based cohort. This knowledge will improve the accuracy of etiological models and guide the refinement and personalization of (preventive) interventions to reduce the burden of these problems on adolescents, their families, and society.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Vocal fold (VF) scarring is one of the greatest challenges in the field of laryngology, with devastating effects on communication and quality of life. VF scarring is the outcome of dynamic, reciprocal processes in multiple cell types that are not well understood. The goal of this proposal is to understand the subpopulations, location, and proximity of cells that contribute to VF injury response and repair in vivo using a bioinformatics approach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) is involved in 200,000 hospitalizations per year in the United States with has high mortality rates due to impaired right ventricular (RV) function. The prognosis is very poor with five-year survival <50%, and there are no available therapies to prevent right heart failure. The goal of this research is to investigate the tissue mechanisms by which remodeling of the collagen extracellular matrix in PAH alters RV myocardium stiffness initially to compensate and how in the progression of the disease this stiffening reverse leading to RV dilation in a well-established rat model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative The timing of sleep depends upon the coordinated action of two different systems in the body, the endogenous circadian system that imposes a 24 hour rhythm and the homeostatic system that ensures an organism gets enough sleep. This proposal will determine how, on a cellular level, the circadian and homeostatic systems interact to control the timing of sleep. It will allow us to understand why misaligned sleep cycles, which are common in modern society (e.g. due to shiftwork or jetlag), are associated with severe health consequences, including neurological disorders.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: This study examines two novel ways to improve functioning and recovery among Veterans with serious mental illness (SMI). It will assess the effectiveness of established psychosocial interventions based on cognitive- behavioral therapy (CBT) and stand-alone social skills training (SST) when delivered by Peer Specialists— Veterans with SMI trained to use their own experience and recovery to help other Veterans with SMI. The project will compare outcomes of Veterans with SMI receiving one of three treatments: Cognitive Behavioral Social Skills Training-Peer (CBSST-Peer), stand-alone Social Skills Training-Peer (SST-Peer), or a peer-led, manualized goal setting group. This work is responsive to national calls for Veterans with SMI to receive support that is evidence-based, improves functioning (not just symptoms), and is tailored to individual needs. If successful, CBSST or SST could be adopted by the 1100 Peer Specialists working in VA, greatly increasing the delivery of evidence-based services to these Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although both HIV and injury are immense global problems, there is a paucity of research on their intersection in high HIV burden African regions; where those most likely to seek treatments for emergent injuries, young adult males, are also a difficult to access group which require novel and effective HIV engagement approaches to contribute to ending the epidemic. This research will generate robust data on the intersection of HIV and injury to address knowledge gaps in HIV care among those seeking emergency treatments in Kenya, and investigate the implementation of an innovative emergency department-based HIV self-testing program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will investigate the potential of the commonly prescribed antibiotic, Azithromycin, as an immunomodulatory agent to speed recovery and reduce injury-exacerbated Alzheimer’s disease neuropathological changes following an acquired brain injury. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fragile X-associated tremor/ataxia syndrome (FXTAS) is a severe, progressive disorder of aging caused by “premutation” expansions (55-200 CGG repeats) of the FMR1 gene on the X chromosome. Knowledge of key phenotypes and their neural substrates is severely lacking for females with FXTAS, limiting progress in clarifying mechanistic pathways and advancing more targeted therapeutics. The proposed R21 will identify quantitative motor and cognitive phenotypes associated with FXTAS in women, determine their neurophysiological correlates, and test associations with select gene and molecular markers implicated in FXTAS degeneration in females.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although antiretroviral therapy (ART) is now widely available, people with HIV continue to have shorter life expectancy compared to the general population. We previously found that gut barrier dysfunction predicted mortality in persons with ART-suppressed HIV and a history of AIDS. Cytomegalovirus (CMV), a common coinfection in HIV, disrupts the gut barrier, and a recent clinical trial showed that a drug active against CMV reduced harmful immune activation in HIV-infected participants. In this project, we will study the role of CMV in gut barrier dysfunction and immune activation. We predict that treatment for CMV infection will help restore gut barrier function and improve outcomes for HIV-infected individuals on ART.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: We propose to establish how meningeal lymphatic vessels mediate neuroimmune communication in the developing brain, and how they can be harnessed to enhance early T-cell education in a mouse model of pediatric brain tumor. We will use unbiased approaches, based on new mouse genetic models and cutting-edge molecular and imaging techniques that we have established, to manipulate meningeal lymphatic growth, assess their role in the transport of brain-derived molecules and in the traffic of antigen- presenting cells, and investigate mechanisms leading to T cell reponses in the collecting lymph nodes. Our results will enhance knowledge in this understudied area and may lead to novel translational approaches to combat pediatric brain tumors by increasing neuroimmune communication via meningeal lymphatics, and by boosting tumor antigen transport, T cell priming and anti-tumor effector function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cities account for a large proportion of HIV prevalence and incidence, and therefore are the focus of UNAIDS' “Fast Track” approach to ending the AIDS epidemic. Several “Fast Track Cities”, including San Francisco, CA, have achieved significant reductions in new HIV infections, and yet despite this success racial/ethnic and gender disparities in new infections are emerging. The proposed study will use semi-parametric statistical modeling and HIV phylogenetics applied to routinely collected public health surveillance data, paired with primary data collection informed by a minority stress theoretical framework, to identify the residual drivers of HIV infection and offer novel targets for intervention to achieve zero new infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Experimentation protocols are not always capable of deeply probing the mechanisms of complex biological systems. We have developed a free, customizable, open-source software system, known as Real-Time eXperiment Interface (RTXI), that enables experimentalists to perform reproducible innovative protocols that are adapted on-the-fly to optimize information acquisition and experiment control during the course of an experiment. This project, which aims to expand the functionality of RTXI in multiple critical ways, will further the abilities of biological scientists to use such protocols to investigate important questions for biological systems ranging from the heart to the brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Despite treatment, a significant proportion of patients with type 2 diabetes (T2D) do not see clinical improvement (i.e., lack treatment response), but we know little about contributing factors and lack tools to prospectively identify likely treatment responders and non-responders. Circulating microRNAs may reflect or predict treatment response at the level of the beta cell and can serve as candidate biomarkers of treatment response. Biomarkers of treatment heterogeneity will help to prospectively identify likely treatment responders and will facilitate development of precision medicine interventions to prevent or delay the progression of T2D.

PHR: Narrative Using inexpensive CT exams that are suitable for screening, we will analyze fat around the coronary arteries, a tissue which has been implicated in biological studies of atherosclerosis. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the context of the largest pandemic in a century, emergency department staff have been called to provide care for a previously unknown disease and therefore have been rapidly innovating to deliver effective care, protect frontline workers, and ensure a sustainable supply of personal protective equipment, with little known about which of these innovations are safe or effective. This project will explore how emergency department staff learn about emerging innovations and make decisions about implementation and de-implementation in a crisis. Through interviews, surveys, and focus groups with clinicians such as physicians, nurses, and respiratory therapists; practice leaders; and information disseminators in emergency medicine, in coordination with organizations representing the field, we will analyze the dissemination and implementation of innovations in care for COVID-19 and identify strategies and lessons learned for optimizing the diffusion of care innovations during COVID-19 that could be relevant for other rapidly evolving pandemics and public health emergencies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative  Microsporidia are unicellular,  fungal  parasites with a wide host-range, from insects to humans;  they are emerging pathogens, classified as NIAID Category B opportunistic pathogens, and cause microsporidiosis in immunocompromised patients.  To gain entry into a target cell, microsporidia employ a remarkably unique and specialized harpoon-like invasion machine called the polar tube, which is conserved among microsporidial species. Here we will focus on understanding the mechanism by which microsporidial parasites use this unique organelle to initiate infection, which may provide broader insights into infection mechanisms used by other eukaryotic parasites.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: Project Narrative Globoid cell leukodystrophy (GLD) is an incurable genetic disease of the central nervous system that is recognized by profound white matter loss (demyelination), neurodegeneration and inflammation. Using genetic profiling technology, we have determined that this disease is distinguished from healthy, non-disease nervous tissues by a prominent CD8 T cell population which has an untested contribution to this disease. Based on our strong preliminary data which demonstrate that blocking these T cells we can effectively prevent disease, this project will interrogate the role of CD8 T cells, by applying advanced genetic tools including transgenic animals and unbiased RNA sequencing approaches, to determine how these adaptive immune cells with strong pathogenic potential are involved in GLD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE: Corneal neovascularization (CoNV) is a sight-threatening condition affecting more than 1.4 million people per year. The objective of this proposal is to investigate the role of Angiopoietin- like 4/Neuropilins, alone or in combination with VEGFs, as regulators of hemangiogenesis and lymphangiogenesis in CoNV. The ultimate goal of our investigations is to design better therapeutic modalities for the prevention and treatment of this blinding disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Signaling through the bacterial second messenger c-di-GMP is subject to exquisite control, especially in bacterial pathogens, which often simultaneously express a multitude of signaling components for setting cellular and local c-di-GMP levels and triggering distinct physiological responses, for example, controlling the expression of multiple adhesins critical for establishing a biofilm. The proposed studies will elucidate both intra- and inter-molecular modes of regulation of bacterial c-di-GMP signaling, explore the role for adhesins and their sub-domains in biofilm formation, and extend our work to a new and unusual Lap-like system in a human-associated microbe.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will identify the principal zoonotic sources of human campylobacteriosis and highly drug resistant Campylobacter infection in a low income country where genomic epidemiology has not yet informed our understanding of disease transmission. It is relevant to the NIH’s mission to control and prevent infectious diseases that affect humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Children with fatty liver are at higher risk for poor long-term health outcomes and early death in adulthood. This study will identify molecular factors associated with fatty liver in children with obesity, determine what happens to these factors following interventions resulting in decreased liver fat, and characterize mechanisms by which these factors contribute to fatty liver. Results from this work will lead to an improved understanding of how fatty liver develops in children and may identify new diagnostic and therapeutic targets for this health condition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Surgical site infection (SSI) is a major public health problem with devastating perioperative outcomes, affecting as many as 1 in 20 patients undergoing instrumented spine surgery. The development of more effective strategies for SSI prevention in spine surgery is significantly limited by a lack of fundamental understanding about the origins of causative bacteria, the basic pathogenesis of spinal wound infection, the microbiome of the back, and the role of antimicrobial resistance to surgical prophylaxis. The proposed research will use bacterial genomic methods to define these key mechanisms, including the roles of the patient microbiome, sex, and anatomy, and will be used to develop new, scientifically informed strategies for SSI prevention in spine surgery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: –––– Project Narrative ––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––– Disrupted sleep is one of the most universally reported outcomes of active alcohol use and recovery from alcohol use disorder, and the harmful influence of alcohol on sleep is well-characterized but remains difficult to treat. To develop better therapies for alcohol-induced sleep effects, we must understand the genetic and molecular mechanisms underpinning the relationship between alcohol use and poor sleep. Utilizing Drosophila’s behavioral similarities with humans, many genetic tools, and high economy of scale, this work will identify genes and neural circuits regulating alcohol-induced sleep disturbances, thereby offering mechanistic targets for treating these disruptions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PSC is a complex cholestatic liver disease with limited treatment options and dismal prognosis and biliary senescence induces mast cell (MC) migration which promotes PSC progression, in vivo. IL-33/ST2 signaling is upregulated in cholestatic injury and induces MC migration/activation. Melatonin therapy decreases PSC phenotypes and inhibits MC activation through changes in IL-33/ST2 signaling and NFB translocation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Myeloid cells are major cell types that harbor HIV in the brain during HIV infection. Eradication of HIV in these cells is critical for a cure of HIV-caused neurological disorders in the central nervous system. We will test a novel CRISPR-based genome editing technology in a non-human primate model to eliminate the viruses that inserted in the genome of myeloid cells for a cure of HIV infection in the brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative TERRA (telomere repeat containing RNA) is overexpressed in telomerase-free cancer cells that use an alternative lengthening of telomere (ALT) pathway for telomere maintenance. The effort to use TERRA for ALT cancer diagnosis and therapy is hindered by the lack of tools to visualize TERRA accurately in fixed and live cells. Based on our initial success in detecting TERRA with gPNA probes, we will design gPNAs that can bind to TERRA with high selectivity and low background and will deliver gPNA to live cells to monitor TERRA dynamics in real time. Our tools can be adapted to study other RNAs to determine their roles in various cancers and provide a molecular basis for targeting RNAs for cancer therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Zinc deficiency increases the risk for infections during pregnancy. Perinatal bacterial infections often originate in the vagina, where asymptomatic bacterial colonization leads to ascending intrauterine infection followed by preterm labor, stillbirth, or neonatal infection. As part of a long-term goal to identify novel approaches to prevent and treat of perinatal infections, this proposal will investigate how zinc alters the ability of a common perinatal pathogen, Group B Streptococcus, to colonize and infect the female reproductive tract.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: CALIFORNIA POLY STATE U SAN LUIS OBISPO
PHR: NARRATIVE Maternal sensitivity and contingent responsiveness to infant behavioral cues is an important contributor to infants’ developing capacities to self-regulate. During early infancy, feeding interactions comprise a significant portion of mother-infant dyadic interactions and high-quality feeding interactions provide both nutritive and socioemotional benefits; recent data from our laboratory suggest that, for many dyads, mothers’ sensitive responsiveness during feeding interactions is routinely impacted by the omnipresence of portable technology. The objective of the proposed research is to better understand the development and possible impacts of maternal technology use on infant feeding interactions, emotion and intake regulation, and sociobehavioral and growth outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The malfunction of chloride ion channels and transporter (CLCs) – proteins critical for human physiology – has been linked to musculoskeletal, cardiovascular, and neurological disease. Although the functions of some CLCs are well understood, others remain poorly described, in large part due to the lack of selective 'tools' for analyzing the mechanisms of these proteins in regulating cellular processes. We are advancing high-precision chemical agents to study CLC-2, a chloride-selective ion channel expressed broadly throughout the brain and implicated in epilepsy as well as other disorders of the central nervous system.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This Stimulating Access to Research in Residency program is designed to provide clinical residents with the tools, mentorship, and support necessary to conduct high-impact research at a time when their emerging patient care responsibilities may be awakening a new appreciation for the need for clinically-relevant scientific investigation. As such, it addresses the need for clinician scientists who combine first-hand perspective on the diagnosis, prevention, or treatment of heart, lung, and blood diseases with the methodologic, collaborative, and leadership skills necessary to make important scientific discoveries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: One of the most important mechanisms by which nerve cells communicate with one another is signaling at chemical synapses, junctions between nerve cells where a released neurotransmitter is detected by neighboring cells, initiating electrical and chemical signaling pathways. This mechanism of signal transduction at chemical synapses not only underpins genetically encoded messaging pathways, such as those involved in breathing and cardiac function, but it is also central to learning and memory. The research supported by this proposal is focused on elaborating the molecular mechanisms of signaling at chemical synapses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Viruses that infect developing fetal tissue can cause major birth defects in the process of replicating. Zika virus is one such virus that coopts a host protein to promote its replication, and in doing so disrupts brain development. Studies aimed at unraveling the molecular mechanisms linking Zika virus replication and neuropathogenesis will provide insight into an important human pathogen, and shed light on rare hereditary disease involving the same developmental pathway.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Race-based pain treatment disparities are well-established, existing across pain types and treatment contexts. Alongside patient-level and system-level factors, clinician-level biases have been implicated in disparate pain care; however, we do not yet understand the specific race-perception mechanisms that may serve as antecedents to biased care, and current intervention strategies have achieved limited success in mitigating bias. The current work tests an integrated account of race perception processes theorized to underlie race disparities in pain care and offers an initial examination of a psychological intervention targeting race perception as a route to more equitable care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Isolates of the fungal pathogen Cryptococcus can vary greatly in their propensity to cause morbidity and mortality. This research will advance public health by identifying dif- ferences in genes and gene networks that underlie variation in disease related traits for three species of Cryptococcus. A deeper understanding of how genetic variation inﬂu- ences virulence traits may lead to new approaches for the treatment and prevention of cryptococcal disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Overall Goal of this Centers of Biomedical Research Excellence Phase I proposal is the creation of an Integrative Center for Precision Nutrition and Human Health at the University of Hawai’i at Manoa. Precision nutrition is a new component of medicine that considers differences in how nutrients are absorbed and converted to energy, resulting in widely varying dietary and nutrient requirements. Genes, environment, culture and customs, dietary preferences and economics all contribute to nutrition and overall health. Through culturally-sensitive collaborations between academic researchers and the community, our goal is to promote better nutrition and health widely throughout the community, state and beyond.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVES In order to understand the fundamental human oligodendrocyte development, pathology, and ultimately to discover drug candidates with higher confidence, it is necessary to develop protocols in human-based platform. Single-cell RNA sequencing comparing mouse and human oligodendrocyte precursor cells (OPCs) revealed a compelling unique sub-population in human OPCs that express signature genes associated with synaptic development, organization, and transmission, suggesting neuron-oligodendrocyte communication during synaptic development. This proposal will establish concrete evidence for human-specific OPC sub- population and its role in synaptic development using single-cell RNA sequencing, spatial transcriptomics, high-resolution histology, and electrophysiology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative. From high-resolution spatial cell transcriptional profiling in glioma tissue slices with intact biological architecture and direct assessment in vivo to cell-specific targeted gene knockdown in a mimicked glioma microenvironment in vitro and back to assessments in glioma models in vivo, we propose to characterize mechanisms of cell fusion/TNT formations as the sources of glioma heterogeneity and intercellular gene transfers. Prognostic profiles of established and novel biomarkers of cell-fusion/TNT formation in the context of a complex glioma microenvironment will be established for different glioma subtypes. The HuR-dependent axis in the regulation of cell fusion/TNT formation at different environmental stress modalities (to include hypoxic, mechanical, metabolic, and cytotoxic stress) will be explored; the quantitative values of HuR inhibitors, including the newly developed and recently patented by our group inhibitor of HuR dimerization SRI4212, in the suppression of the cell fusion and glioma heterogeneity will be provided.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this project is to generate novel probes to visualize how tubulin, a molecule that is the basic unit of the axonal cytoskeleton, is delivered to axons and is later removed. This is important to understand how neurons maintain the cytoskeletal mass of their axons. Since reduced cytoskeletal mass is a hallmark of several neurological diseases, results from this study may provide important insights into disease mechanisms.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is a high genetic risk for asthma that changes sphingolipid production, and sphin- golipids may play an essential and yet unknown role in developing this common disease. We will study how rhinovirus, the most common trigger for asthma attacks, affects sphin- golipid production in children with asthma, and this will help us understand critical factors of the disease that can be useful for new therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Antibiotic resistant Staphylococcus aureus infections remain a major global health problem. S. aureus infect their host by adapting their physiology to the environment found at sites of infection. The main objective of this proposal is to determine the mechanism(s) by which the SrrAB signaling pathway regulates the ability of S. aureus to adapt to the host environment and infect humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Chlamydia is a major cause of sexually transmitted infections in the U.S., and more cases of chlamydial genital infections are reported to the CDC than any other infectious disease. This project will develop a novel protein knockdown method in C. trachomatis that is based on the use of a reprogrammed small RNA to selectively deplete levels of a target protein. This method will provide a new genetic tool for studying the function of chlamydial proteins.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Our immune system’s ability to differentiate self from non-self nucleic acids is critical for combating pathogens and cancer. The goal of this project is to better understand the mechanisms cells use to detect foreign nucleic acids with sensitivity while avoiding aberrant activation by self molecules. The results may change our understanding of autoimmunity and cancer and provide new knowledge helpful for treating these debilitating medical conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Celiac disease is an important health problem mediated by ingestion of gluten antigens found in wheat, barley, and rye, has an estimated prevalence of 1% in the general US population and results in excessive health care costs. In this study we deploy non-pathogenic gut protists as a tool to boost oral tolerance to gluten, thereby suppressing adverse inflammatory responses to gluten that result in the development of celiac disease. This novel concept will have a positive impact on human health because it is probable that the identified protist- immune regulatory mechanisms will provide new protist-based therapeutic interventions to prevent and revert immune-mediated food sensitivities that include celiac disease and food allergies and has the potential to impact broadly on biomedical research and gut health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bacterial pneumonia causes severe inflammation of the lungs that can result in organ failure and even death if left unchecked. This proposal utilizes a cutting-edge genetic engineering approach to develop a biomimetic nanocarrier that can specifically deliver anti-inflammatory steroids to inflamed infection sites. If successful, the project will help to establish a new paradigm for addressing pathological inflammation that can be applied across a wide range of diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: HIV-infected children who initiate ART in the first week of life may have both low viral reservoir and limited  viral diversity, and are therefore an ideal population to evaluate strategies other than ART for maintaining  viral suppression. This study will determine whether the broadly neutralizing antibodies VRC01LS and 10- 1074 can maintain viral suppression in early-treated children for a period of 24 weeks off ART, and will  characterize changes in viral reservoir and immune responses during and after the intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Individuals with stroke often have chronic walking impairments that limit physical activity, quality of life, and community involvement and lead to increased healthcare burden and the development of secondary disabilities. The proposed work seeks to understand whether neural pathways from the non-lesioned side of the brain have enhanced use and contribute to the recovery of walking after stroke. Results from this work will provide insight into the role of novel neural pathways and may lead to a paradigm shift in lower limb rehabilitative strategy after stroke that reduces chronic walking impairment and healthcare burden.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nicotinamide N-methyltransferase (NNMT) is a likely master regulator of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) gene expression through its hypomethylating effect on DNA, histones and mRNA; however, a link between NNMT expression and mRNA hypomethylation has not previously been established as a mechanism contributing to cancer progression. In my dissertation project, I am testing the hypothesis that NNMT activity in TNBC cells results in 1) reduced m6A mRNA modification associated with altered protein expression of pathways mediating cellular stress response and 2) cancer stem cell-like traits associated with survival, metastatic potential and increased in vivo tumor-forming capacity. As accumulating research has been highlighting the biological relevance of RNA modifications both in terms of normal physiology and pathology including cancer, I plan to pursue my post-doctoral research on the biological and cancer-associated role of epitranscriptomic gene expression regulation with a translational focus as an endpoint to develop novel modulators of RNA modifications as potential cancer therapeutic agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Understanding ADHD – a neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by impulsivity, hyperactivity, and exceptional difficulty with paying attention – is critical to help the increasing number of children diagnosed with ADHD each year as well as the sixty percent of diagnosed children who retain symptoms into adulthood. We aim to study one aspect of ADHD – cognitive control – using a brain activity monitoring with electroencephalography (EEG). This work will help us develop quantitative, objective ADHD diagnostics and better understand the brain science of attention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: Narrative Arthropod-borne rickettsial species are a major cause of emerging febrile illnesses with significant public health and economic impacts; however, our understanding of the genetic bases for rickettsial pathogenesis, vector transmission, and protective immunity is limited. This application aims to generate kkaebi transposon mutant libraries for two model organisms of pathogenic Rickettsia species belonging to the spotted fever and typhus groups, enabling investigators to identify essential genes for Rickettsia. Further, this application will characterize virulence genes and their biological functions, specifically focusing on those genes involved in O- antigen biosynthesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although neurotrophins, such as brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF), play an essential role in neural circuit development and function, little is known about how neurotrophin-regulated transcription influences experience- dependent plasticity in the brain. This study seeks to characterize the genomic mechanisms by which BDNF regulates the maturation of inhibition within the mouse visual cortex. By identifying specific transcription factors and target genes that mediate the genomic response to BDNF in the brain, this proposal will provide novel insights into the etiology of neurological disorders that display a loss of BDNF production, including Alzheimer’s and Huntingtin’s disease.

PHR: Project Narrative The Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center Summer Research Fellowship Program is a ten-week research- training program developed for medical students hailing from diverse backgrounds. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: This project combines the expertise of the Cotter and Doyle laboratories to determine the first structure of the Bordetella TpsB transporter (FhaC) in complex with its cognate passenger (FhaB) and to identify novel compounds that inhibit TpsB transporters. To date structural information is limited to individual structures of FhaC and FhaB which provide limited information about how TpsB proteins secrete their passengers. TpsB transporters play key roles in the pathogenesis of important Gram-negative pathogens and TpsB inhibitors have the potential to act as both targeted and broad-spectrum anti-virulence agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) is a thrombotic disorder that develops when patients anti-coagulated with heparin develop anti-PF4 antibodies that stimulate platelet activation and thrombosis; however, the platelet surface molecules that recruit PF4 to the platelet surface to elicit the epitopes recognized by anti-PF4 antibodies remain unknown. This paucity of knowledge has resulted in the low accuracy of frontline diagnostic assays and ineffectual treatment options for HIT patients. This proposal aims to identify the platelet surface molecules that recruit PF4 and to correlate differences in the expression of these PF4-interactors based on age, sex, and ethnicity to better risk stratify patients and identify candidate molecules for improving the diagnosis and treatment of HIT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Dendritic cells (DCs) play key roles in orchestrating immunity to pathogens. Multiple subsets of functionally specialized DCs exist, but DC function can also be modulated by microbial and tissue-derived stimuli. We have recently demonstrated a major role for the metabolic sensors mTOR and GCN2 in regulating DC development and function, and the underlying mechanisms of this “metabolic imprinting” will be explored.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative – Public Health Relevance Statement Dr. Tanya Laidlaw is a recognized patient-oriented investigator in the study of respiratory diseases, in particular severe asthma and chronic sinus disease, which collectively afflict up to 10% of the US population and have high morbidity and few available treatments. This project aims to determine which immune pathways are important causes of these inflammatory respiratory diseases, and how new biologic drugs that treat them can work to improve patients’ respiratory health but may also cause other systemic immune consequences. Dr. Laidlaw is a very engaged research mentor, and this grant will support her ability to mentor and train the next generation of clinical scientists in patient-oriented allergic and airway disease research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE This project will generate novel immunotherapeutic drug candidates against ovarian cancer based on lectikines, which are recombinant fusion proteins consisting of the tumor glycobiomarker-targeting lectin Avaren and an antitumor cytokine. We will design and produce several lectikine constructs and evaluate them in in vitro assays and in a mouse ovarian cancer model. Successful completion of this pilot project will establish an important proof-of-concept data package justifying further preclinical development of our first-in-class immunotherapeutic candidate for ovarian cancer.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The size and shape of the external-ear structures (e.g. pinna, concha, ear canal) amplify and attenuate certain frequencies, which affects the way individuals naturally hear sound - each with a slightly different spectral profile. Unfortunately, the majority of audiologists automatically program hearing aids using an average amount of external-ear amplification (up to 20 dB of error) rather than directly measuring the patient’s unique external ear amplification, which results in under-amplification (poor audibility) or over-amplification (noise-induced hearing loss). In this project, we will test the hypothesis that average estimates of external-ear amplification will improve if they are normed using body height, pinna size, and ear canal size, instead of body age.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: 8. Project Narrative Training a new generation of investigators to understand how behavioral and environmental risk factors impact cardiovascular and metabolic diseases, and how to cost-effectively and sustainably modify these factors, is among the most important scientific tasks of our time. These are global challenges, as changing behaviors and environmental risks are rapidly increasing cardiovascular and metabolic diseases worldwide and widespread use of costly new drug- and device-related treatments may not be practical or cost-effective.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Dr. Floor Backes is exceptionally passionate about improving outcomes of all patients through participation in clinical trials with equal access to care and research. This award would support Dr. Backes to work within NRG Oncology continue to design, develop, and support novel paradigm shifting clinical trials as principle investigator, mentor, Co-Chair of the NRG Oncology Developmental Therapeutics (DT) committee, member of the Uterine Corpus Committee, and NCI Uterine Taskforce. Local institutional goals are to support the Ohio State University and James Comprehensive Cancer Center to develop a comprehensive system for multidisciplinary collaboration and molecular matching increase enrollment to NCTN trials and especially to disease agnostic molecular driven trials, streamline trial implementation and to increase the referral and accrual of racial/ethnic minorities to NCI’s National Clinical Trials Network (NCTN) prevention/control and treatment trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) are a major and growing public health concern, but their life course social determinants have been difficult to study because most studies lack data on the full life span. This project will build a synthetic cohort from three component datasets that, together, cover the full life course to investigate the life course impact of financial wellbeing on later cognitive decline, ADRD risk, and disparities in these outcomes. In addition, we will examine whether accelerated biological aging acts as a mechanism through which these relationships operate and identify hypothetical age-specific interventions on financial wellbeing that could reduce ADRD burden and disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative  Human papillomavirus (HPV) causes 5% of cancers worldwide, including a growing number of oral cancers. In the United States, HPV-associated oral cancers, most often arising in the tonsils, are considered an epidemic but are poorly understood. To contribute to fundamental knowledge and address the oral health burden caused by HPV, this project will determine the host factors regulating oral HPV infection and carcinogenesis using three-dimensional epithelial models and computational approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Early-onset Alzheimer’s disease (EOAD) is a critically understudied form of AD compared with its late-onset counterpart, with little evidence regarding the mechanisms underlying disease progression. By combining longitudinal multimodal in vivo neuroimaging acquired in patients, graph theory, and brain transcriptome analysis, the current project will characterize the contributions of brain network connectivity and specific genetic factors to the spread of tau pathology. Results will help elucidate drivers of the pathological cascade in EOAD and contribute to the development of patient-specific approaches to monitor disease progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Epilepsy, a debilitating neurological disorder characterized by unpredictable and abnormal electrical discharges and recurrent seizures, affects more than 65 million people worldwide, with one third of cases not being adequately controlled with existing therapies. In this study, we will carry out IND-enabling studies and the first-in- human clinical trials to move pluripotent stem cell-derived human cortical interneuron transplantation into clinical reality. This work will be pivotal in bringing this novel and restorative therapy to patients with epilepsy who have limited options.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative A steady stream of new researchers is necessary to continue the fight against cancer, the primary cause of death in the U.S. Critical to the success of training the next generation of scientists is promoting a diverse workforce; this is not only key aspect of this proposed training program but is also an inherent mission to our minority serving university. The goal of this Epigenetics, DNA repair and Genomics (EDGe) Training Program in Cancer is to train 4 PhD students per year in multidisciplinary cancer research, building on our institutional faculty's strengths in DNA repair and epigenetics – key areas that impact cancer development and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal aims to quantitatively evaluate effects of opioid drugs on post-surgical pain relief and risk of opioid-related adverse drug events using patient-level clinical and genetic information. Statistical and machine learning models will be developed to recommend optimal opioid prescription dosage (oral morphine milligram equivalents). Polygenic risk score will be built to represent patients' genetic susceptibility to the given post- surgical opioid prescription-related outcomes and identify high-risk patient populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Self-inflicted injury (SII) commonly emerges in adolescence and is associated with severe psychopathology and increased suicide risk. Although we have evidence-based interventions for youth SII, biosocial mechanisms of change are underexplored and we lack vital data on how adolescents apply and retain therapeutic skills in daily life. The proposed study will directly compare the influence of two core intervention skills among self-injuring adolescents across neural, cardiovascular, and behavioral levels of functioning; and investigate skill uptake, use, and retention in daily life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Medication errors or adverse events are a major public health problem causing thousands of deaths annually. This proposal aims to build wearable cameras with real-time computer vision algorithms to identify medications when initially selected by an anesthesiology provider during drug preparation or before injection to potentially prevent accidentally giving the wrong drug. Drug dose will also be determined and recorded in an electronic health record, potentially increasing record accuracy and decreasing manual tasks for anesthesiologists so they can focus on direct patient care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative:  Release probability (P(r)) of neurotransmitter containing vesicles is a critical component of information transfer between neurons and is dynamically regulated by a variety of molecular and circuit mechanisms. Here I combine an array of novel imaging, electrophysiological, behavioral, and pharmacological methods to interrogate the regulation of P(r) in vivo at multiple different scales. This will lead to a novel understanding of how individual pre-synaptic sites are regulated and bridge a wealth of literature in reduced preparations to the awake, behaving brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative There is an urgent need to improve the prognostic classification of patients with neuroendocrine tumors (NETs), a tumor type rapidly rising in prevalence and incidence. We propose that NET progression and aggressiveness is linked with multi-factorial alterations in patient-specific factors encoded within the tumor microenvironment (TME), such as the spatial distribution patterns and cellular interactions of the different macrophage populations that underlie the creation of an immunosuppressive milieu. If identified, understanding these spatial TME characteristics will lead to a more accurate prognosis and may provide a robust foundation for future therapeutic development of novel and holistic approaches that target NETs.
