IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Studies of novel functional genetic variants underlying human disease will provide valuable information to the general scientific community that will have broad relevance across many disciplines. We will systematically characterize the genetic variants in human disease genes in zebrafish to determine the functional consequence of such mutations and develop approaches to test the disease-causing variants functionally. The information and resources generated from our studies will impact a broad spectrum of researchers studying multiple human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To design better malaria vaccines, we propose to learn from nature by studying immune responses against the malaria parasite in people who have developed protection against the disease as a result of life-long exposure. This project will compare antibodies from malaria-protected and susceptible individuals to determine the characteristics of antibodies that a malaria vaccine should elicit. In addition, antibodies that are able to strongly inhibit the parasite will be analyzed in more detail to serve as a blueprint for malaria vaccine design.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hepatitis B virus (HBV) is an important human pathogen. There are approximately 300 million people in the world that are chronically infected by this virus, resulting in nearly 1 million deaths every year. The goal of our proposed research is to produce novel therapeutic agents for the treatment of this important viral disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The neuron-glia switch orchestrating sequential production of neurons and glia from distinct neural progenitors is essential for functional nervous system development and successful regeneration after injury. This proposal aims to identify how factors modulate Wnt signaling to regulate the neuron-glia switch and drive gliogenesis in neural progenitor cells during development and following spinal cord injury. The proposed experiments will provide insight into the molecular mediators of neural progenitor specification and emphasize the importance of the neuron-glia switch during development and after injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: A key feature of substance use disorder is pathological behavioral engagement with rewarding stimuli despite negative outcomes, yet the neural mechanisms driving these behaviors remain unresolved. Consumption of many classes of abused drugs is established to induce maladaptive changes in the endocannabinoid signaling system within the Nucleus Accumbens, a key nodal structure in the neurocircuitry of addiction. In this proposal, we will use cutting-edge in vivo genetic and imaging approaches to dissect how endocannabinoids regulate engagement in reward seeking behaviors through a Paraventricular Thalamus-Nucleus Accumbens circuit to deepen our understanding of substance use disorders and the neural mechanisms of cannabis action.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Systolic blood pressure (SBP) above normal, healthy levels (i.e., ≥120 mmHg) is associated with increased risk for cardiovascular diseases. I recently established the clinical efficacy of high-resistance inspiratory muscle strength training (IMST), a novel form of physical training with minimal barriers to adherence, for lowering SBP in a clinical trial with regular clinic-based, researcher-supervised training. This R03 application seeks to leverage the growing field of digital health technologies to pilot test a smartphone app that independently guides users through a high-resistance IMST program, a key step to translate IMST for widespread use and improving public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Puberty is a critical period for neuroendocrine development characterized by substantial neuroplasticity and changing sex hormone levels, which are poorly understood in humans. Innovative analytic strategies are needed for integrating data from multiple approaches (i.e., large- and small-scale datasets with sparse and dense longitudinal sampling) to better characterize the contributions of long-term pubertal changes, and more short- term monthly variability in hormones as it pertains to structure and function of the developing brain. The proposed study will apply machine learning to assess hormone-related brain structure and functional connectivity, the roles of sex hormones in microstructure-function coupling across the brain, and the impact of hormone variability and sampling design on identified neuroendocrine phenomena.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: CENTER NARRATIVE CLiMB’s mission is to preserve, restore, and enhance functional mobility, independence, and participation in Veterans with lower limb loss or other musculoskeletal impairments. To accomplish this mission, CLiMB conducts research to prevent Veterans from developing disabilities from diseases, develops innovative devices to assist Veterans in their mobility, discovers effective treatment and rehabilitation strategies, and creates treatments and clinical tools that allow for an individualized approach to treating Veterans. The Veterans we serve include the hundreds of thousands at risk for limb loss and the tens of thousands who have experienced it, for whom the VA is committed to lifelong clinical management and care. We achieve our mission by conducting rigorous research and development, informing Veteran patients and providers, and translating knowledge and devices to the point of care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Natural products – small molecules from plants and microorganisms – have been a primary source of clinically-used antibiotics, antifungals, anticancer agents, immunosuppressants, and other drugs. This proposal describes new approaches to discovering the biosynthetic pathways for natural products from plant genomes. Identifying these pathways will lead to a greater understanding of the chemistries plants use to synthesize biologically active natural products, ensure ready access to molecules that are currently obtained from difficult-to-cultivate plants, and enable the engineered production of plant natural product derivatives with improved biological properties.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The microbiome is associated with neurodevelopmental phenotypes in many human diseases, including autism spectrum disorder, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, and schizophrenia. Though we know that mode of delivery can determine the initial seeding of the microbiome, we do not know how it may affect neurodevelopment. This work will use a mouse model of Caesarean-section delivery to determine how birth mode changes the pre-weaning microbiome and neurodevelopment in specific brain regions.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Psoriasis increases the risk of cardiovascular disease 50% above matched controls. This study will investigate mechanisms in the development of cardiovascular disease by characterizing vascular endothelial disturbances and platelet reactivity in patients with psoriasis. We aim to identify potential therapeutic targets with the eventual goal of developing therapeutic interventions to reduce cardiovascular disease in this at-risk population.

ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: Veterinary students are uniquely qualified in comparative medicine, a training that is a valuable resource in the biomedical sciences and particularly animal models of diseases. This competing renewal proposal will support the continuation of our Summer Veterinary Student Research Program (SVSRP) at the Virginia-Maryland College of Veterinary Medicine (VMCVM) to train veterinary medicine students in acquiring research skills. The SVSRP is designed to increase the appreciation of research by DVM students, incorporate research skills in their future careers, and to consider research-based careers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Because of the Kentucky's large economically disadvantaged population and the race and gender gap in academia, it is imperative to provide underrepresented students in Kentucky with the tools they will need to apply and succeed in graduate school. The overall objective of this research education program is to recruit and train the next generation of underrepresented scientists in the STEM fields by developing a unique integrated education program among faculty of the Medical, Dental, Arts and Sciences, and Engineering schools at the University of Louisville. This program will provide students from Kentucky and surrounding area underrepresented in STEM extensive research training in various biomedical disciplines, and development of various skills necessary to become successful scientists and of a strong sense of belonging in science.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Deaths from esophageal adenocarcinoma continue to rise, yet factors driving this trend remain poorly understood. We hope to demonstrate that the inter-relationship between gastro-esophageal reflux bile acid composition, Notch signaling activity, and esophageal bacterial composition is key to driving esophageal neoplasia. This knowledge can in turn be translated to future efforts to modify these factors to prevent esophageal cancer.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: .PROJECT NARRATIVE. With aging of our population and growing numbers of persons with disability, rehabilitation research is increasingly essential. However, rehabilitation researcher lags other areas of biomedical research. We propose a vibrant and intensive year-long program to strengthen the rehabilitation research workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health as cancer treatment with chemotherapeutic drugs induces progressive, long-lasting adverse effects on cognitive function in 30 to 50% of patients, yet its pathogenesis is not well understood. Increasing clinical and experimental evidence suggest that chemotherapeutic agents cause cerebral vascular damage, which impairs cerebral blood flow and vascular responses contributing to chemotherapy-induced cognitive impairment. The discovery of the cellular mechanisms responsible for decreased cognitive capacity after cancer treatment is ultimately expected to enhance understanding of the pathogenesis of the disease and will lead to the development of novel therapeutic interventions for prevention; thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of NIH's mission that pertains to developing fundamental knowledge that will help to reduce the burdens of cancer.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Spinal Cord Injury (SCI) is damage to the spinal cord that results in permanent loss of function such as mobility or feeling below injury. There are approximately 300,000 Americans living with SCI, and approximately 20,000 of those injured are Veterans (data from Paralyzed Veterans of America). Thus, care and treatment of spinal cord injured veterans is important to the VA patient care mission. This proposal is to elucidate mechanisms underlying the poor regenerative capacity of the forelimb CST and to test experimental approaches for enhancing forelimb CST regeneration that we hypothesize will further improve forelimb functional recovery after SCI. The success of this project will benefit those veterans and civilians who suffer SCI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: NORTH CAROLINA AGRI & TECH ST UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative: Current 2D cell culture systems do not reliably model nor predict the physiopathology of Alzheimer’s Disease, an irreversible and incurable disorder of multiple tissues in the brain that affects millions of Americans. This project aims to construct a 3D dynamic brain tissue (mini-brain in a dish) integrated with patient stem-cell derived brain cells, to validate AD physiopathology, including extracellular plaques, intracellular fibers tangles, vessel abnormality, and an overactive immune response. This in vitro platform can be used to accelerate drug discovery and screening.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE (PROJECT NARRATIVE) Mutations in the FOXF1 gene locus are associated with alveolar-capillary dysplasia with misalignment of pulmonary veins, a lethal lung developmental disorder with no cure. This project aims to uncover the molecular mechanism underlying FOXF1-mediated abnormalities in alveolar endothelial cell subtypes, and the disrupted endothelial-epithelial interactions during lung development. If successful, the proposed studies will uncover the FOXF gene regulatory network in human lung, and provide new therapeutic targets to re-establish normal alveolar-capillary interface in various lung developmental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bacteriophages (phages) are believed to reduce the density of bacterial pathogens in their environments and therefore transmission of disease, and also to impact the evolution of bacteria, perhaps contributing to the emergence of new strains. Yet, there is scant evidence to support these claims. To reveal if and how phages can play these important roles, we will investigate the impact of four phages that are commonly associated with Vibrio cholerae on bacterial virulence, transmission, and strain evolution.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Perinatal medicine and biology has major public health consequences with the growing recognition that perinatal life is a major determinant of disease in adult life. The PRS Young Investigator Program enhances and accelerates the development of young investigators in the field of perinatal medicine and biology through grantsmanship, communication skills, and networking opportunities. This means we are helping ensure a future pool of outstanding physician-scientists and basic-scientists to improve health and disease during the perinatal period, consistent with the mission of NIH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The Center for Multiparametric Imaging of Tumor Immune Microenvironments (C-MITIE) will define physical and molecular barriers to effective anti-tumor immune responses and therapies. As an integrated team we will advance and develop state-of-the-art live cell and tissue optical imaging platforms and quantitative analyses to define the principal physical barriers that limit effective anti-tumor immunity and immunotherapy. This will facilitate design criteria for novel immunotherapy regimens and next-generation cell-based immunotherapies for cancer patients.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Project Narrative Loud sounds can damage your ears and lead to sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL). Because of the environments in which military personnel operate, they are more likely to suffer service-related hearing losses than non-military populations. The mechanism of SNHL is poorly understood because how loud sounds reach our inner ear, and how the damage they inflict affects our hearing is not well described. We propose a signal- processing approach along the entire auditory pathway to resolve this. Combined measurements in the ear canal, within the cochlea, and at the brain will distinguish between noise-induced sensory and neural HL. This greatly enhances rehabilitation strategies that alleviate the burden of hearing loss. The proposed research will provide basic knowledge on how the ear works and explain what changes due to noise-induced damage. It also contributes to the diagnosis of sensory or neural loss, which directly benefits military personnel, Veterans, and civilians suffering from SNHL.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We have proposed that it is necessary to eradicate disseminated tumor cells (DTCs) in distant tissues like bone marrow in order to prevent breast cancer metastasis. We have shown that DTCs are resistant to chemotherapy because of the niche that they occupy, and found that chemotherapy triggers robust changes within this niche that, paradoxically, actually protect DTCs from therapy. We propose to identify and target this response in order to deprive DTCs of pro-survival signals, thus preventing their ability to cause lethal complications in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Evidence suggests that in sub-Saharan Africa myocardial infarction (MI) is associated with very high mortality, but locally-appropriate interventions to improve uptake of evidence-based care are lacking. This study will identify barriers to MI care, develop a tailored multicomponent intervention to improve care, and assess the feasibility, acceptability, and preliminary effectiveness of this tailored intervention. The results from this study will lead directly to clinical trials to test interventions to reduce mortality from myocardial infarction in resource-limited domestic and global settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ethical, efficient sharing of federated genomic and health related data will transform disease diagnosis and treatment, reveal new patterns in human biology, allow researchers to expand studies of cancer and common disease associations to less common and more detailed analyses, strengthen genomic variant interpretation in rare diseases, and enable more informed clinical decisions. However, lack of interoperability—both technical and regulatory—has resulted in data that is siloed by institution, country, and disease area, locking away their potential to contribute to research and medicine. The Global Alliance for Genomics and Health (GA4GH) will convene the research and healthcare communities to agree on common methods for collecting, storing, transferring, accessing, and analyzing data in order to overcome these barriers, enable broad data sharing that transcends the boundaries of any single institution or country, and fulfill the human right of everyone to benefit from the advances of genomic research, as mandated by the Universal Declaration of Human Rights (Assembly 1948).

PHR: Project Narrative Pulmonary complications are the leading cause of mortality in patients with osteogenesis imperfecta (OI) and the mechanisms behind these complications, specifically reaction to environmental damage, are unknown and not well explored. This proposal will gain insights into the mechanisms causing OI lung insufficiency and completion of the aims will contribute to knowledge regarding the effect of abnormal extracellular matrix secretion and ER stress on lung cell differentiation and damage recovery as well as the effect of in vivo ER stress inhibition treatment. Importantly, our study will identify novel targets for future clinical therapies that could ameliorate OI lung abnormalities, for which there are presently no established treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Advanced non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) accounting for 85% of lung cancer is a highly aggressive cancer with poor prognosis and short survival rate. The goal of this study is to characterize a novel and unique cancer stem cell (CSC) population in NSCLC progression and metastasis and dissect its regulatory mechanisms that can be harnessed for developing a novel effective strategy for targeting progression and metastasis of NSCLC and overcoming the resistance to current standard of care treatments. Our proposal represents a paradigm- shifting concept in that the successful implementation of our proposal will not only reveal new insight into CSC regulation leading to cancer progression and metastasis, but also offer a new strategy for targeting advanced NSCLC with metastasis.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Overall: Translational Hearing Center The Translational Hearing Center will build a broad, critical mass of academic translational researchers to develop therapeutics that preserve or restore sensory function in genomic, medical and environmental settings known to cause hearing loss or vestibular deficits. This will accelerate translation of candidate therapeutics towards clinical trials in an increasingly wider range of etiologies that predispose individuals to a higher risk of hearing loss or vestibular deficits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Overall Narrative Radiotherapy (RT) is frequently used to treat patients with a variety of cancers; however, despite our ability to target RT with sophisticated techniques, it can still lead to high rates of normal tissue toxicity that significantly affect patients’ quality of life. The exciting new modality of ultra-high dose rate radiotherapy (FLASH-RT) could help in alleviating these complications due to its reported ability to spare normal tissues while being equivalent in controlling tumor growth. We will test the overall hypothesis that FLASH RT with particle therapy (protons, carbon ions, or electrons) is superior to the same therapy delivered at standard dose rates, providing for the protection of normal tissues without compromising tumor control; thus, the overall goal of this P01 application is to complete pre-clinical studies, specifically focusing on sarcomas and lung and pancreatic cancers, aimed at addressing key gaps in knowledge regarding FLASH-RT to move it into human clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: IgA nephropathy, the most common glomerulonephritis worldwide, leads to end-stage renal disease in up to 40% of the patients and reduces life expectancy by 10 years. A key feature of the disease is the development of pathogenic immune complexes formed between IgG autoantibodies and aberrantly glycosylated IgA1. In this proposal, we investigate the diversity and structure of these pathogenic autoantibodies with a long-term goal to provide a strategy for the development of disease-specific therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic cancer is a devastating malignancy with poor survival. Proton radiotherapy is a modality used for the clinical management of PanCa; however, its efficacy is limited primarily by incidental dose to critical organs including the small intestine. Project 1 of this P01 will test the ability of a new form of Proton Therapy which s delivered at ultra-fast dose rates (termed “FLASH” radiotherapy) to control tumor growth as well as Standard dose rate radiotherapy, while at the same time spare normal intestine from toxicity, thereby allowing for a higher dose and better control of PanCa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Radiotherapy is generally not used to treat sarcomas in the definitive (without surgery) setting due to the significant morbidity (skin toxicity, lymphedema, second cancers, bone fractures, etc.) associated with the high doses that would be required. FLASH proton therapy, which delivers high doses within less than a second, has the potential to spare normal tissues from injury; hence, our long-term goal is to translate FLASH into the clinic for use in human patients with soft tissue sarcomas. In the context of radiotherapy for sarcoma,this project will elucidate mechanisms by which FLASH spares normal tissues through investigations in mice, and it will determine the safety and efficacy of FLASH when used for treatment of dogs with osteosarcomas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Existing therapies for cardiac electrical rhythm disturbances (arrhythmias) face important limitations, motivating the search for novel therapeutic targets to support a more personalized approach to preventing arrhythmias in human patients. Our interdisciplinary and comprehensive studies are motivated by unexpected preliminary data identifying the two pore K+ channel TREK-1 as an ideal, although understudied, candidate for next generation “precision” therapeutics. We expect this project will define the functional role of TREK-1 in cardiac pathophysiology and open new therapeutic avenues for tuning cardiac excitability and reducing arrhythmia susceptibility in human patients

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Polypharmacy is an increasingly common problem among aging persons with HIV (PWH), particularly since it could worsen toxicity from antiretroviral therapy and the adverse effects of comorbid diseases. This application proposes to systematically evaluate the influence of aging and concomitant drugs on ART neurotoxicity and its effects on cognition and depression and to explore the molecular and cellular mechanisms. The identification and validation of pharmacological factors affecting ART neurotoxicity, cognition, and depression would have substantial public health relevance and could support early intervention and treatment optimization.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Metastatic osteosarcoma (OS) in humans and dogs remains a therapeutic challenge, compounded by a low mutational landscape and absence of clear molecular drivers that limit the utility of immune checkpoint blockade and classic kinase pathway inhibition. Data suggest that OS may be particularly vulnerable to targeting of metabolic pathways; indeed, I have shown that loss of monocarboxylate transporter (MCT) 1 and 4 function in OS cells leads to intracellular lactate accumulation, altering tumor cell phenotype and impairing aerobic glycolysis. Building upon these data, I will employ a comparative cross-species approach to define the regulation and function of MCT1/4 in OS, assess the therapeutic potential of MCT inhibition using zebrafish and mouse models of OS, and explore strategies for synthetic lethality, ultimately creating a blueprint for future clinical translation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Compared to biopsies, serum biomarker measurements eliminate invasive procedures to patients, are less expensive and most importantly, may help identify neuroendocrine prostate cancer (PCa), a lethal variant of PCa, earlier so that new therapies can be started in a timely manner. N-glycoproteomic analyses of sera from patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) represent a new paradigm of protein biomarker discovery that overcomes the most challenging limitation of proteomic profiling based approaches. In this proposal, we will identify human-specific N-glycosylated proteins in a mouse background with high sensitivity using PCa PDX models and validate potential biomarkers associated with tumor volume in PCa patient sera.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE This project will investigate the use of proton pencil beam scanning (PBS) to deliver FLASH enhanced radiotherapy. The approach will examine the complex interplay between spatio-temporal beam parameters and FLASH, optimization algorithms for modeling biological effects and treatment planning, and development of FLASH specific methods for ultra-fast dose monitoring, robotic positioning, image guidance, and quality assurance. The goal is to further optimize the FLASH effect by PBS machine tuning and FLASH delivery with existing clinical proton accelerator technology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Most lung cancers present as pulmonary nodules; so, to improve survival from lung cancer, we need to identify with noninvasive strategies the disease early among a majority of benign nodules. This project focuses on establishing an integrative approach to early detection leveraging repeated measures of chest CT imaging features of lung nodules over time, of the rate of change of a high sensitivity blood biomarker hsCYFRA 21-1, and of longitudinal clinical patterns from the electronic health record. This research will inform the management of lung nodules identified on lung cancer screening CT scans, and should reduce the time to diagnosis and the mortality of lung cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative A critical component of the experimental work proposed across all Projects is the study of preclinical animal models to assess efficacy and toxicity of proton/carbon particle FLASH radiotherapy as compared to standard particle radiotherapy. To this end, Core C will study the pathological changes occurring in the animal model to understand how neoplastic and normal tissues respond to the application of different experimental radiotherapies. This type of assessment will contribute to test the overall hypothesis that proton/carbon particle FLASH radiotherapy is superior to standard particle radiotherapy in protecting normal tissues while the two modalities are equipotent in controlling malignant growth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Our proposal's goal is to develop new approaches for the prevention and treatment of human malaria caused by Plasmodium vivax (P. vivax). This type of malaria, known as vivax malaria, is the most widely distributed type of malaria with 3.3 billion people at risk and at least 15 million clinical cases worldwide each year. The proposal aims to isolate and produce monoclonal antibodies that recognize molecules essential for the parasite to infected liver and red blood cells from individuals who have become immune to vivax malaria. The production and characterization of these human monoclonal antibodies will help in the design and development of vaccines against vivax malaria and provide novel therapeutics to both prevent and treat individuals at risk or infected with this parasite.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative There are no effective chemotherapies for MPNST patients and our understanding of MPNST development from benign precursor lesions is limited. We hypothesize that the three tumor suppressor products of the INK4a/ARF/INK4b locus, the only genes besides NF1 known to be significantly altered in the precursor lesions, serve cooperative functions with other players to suppress the transformation of benign neurofibromas to MPNSTs. These studies, which comprehensively examine the mechanisms and biological significance of INK4a, ARF, and INK4b inactivation in MPNST pathogenesis using mouse and human models, may facilitate earlier diagnosis and future pre-emptive chemotherapeutic interventions targeting the precursor lesions in NF1 patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a critical public health concern with high mortality rates due to increased risks for many major life-threatening pathologies that is largely driven by chronic hyperglycemia. In response to chronic nutrient excess such as hyperglycemia, inappropriate levels of autophagy (organelle breakdown/recycling) are observed and associated with pancreatic β-cell failure through unknown mechanisms. In this proposal, we will study the unexplored interactions between two major nutrient-sensor proteins (O-GlcNAc Transferase; OGT and mechanistic Target of Rapamycin; mTOR), and their downstream contribution to β-cell mass and insulin secretion that are maintained through the process of autophagy, with the long-term goal of generating new therapeutic targets to prevent T2D.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Rare and unnatural carbohydrates play an essential role in the potency and selectivity of over 100 FDA-approved drugs and countless bioactive natural products. However, in spite of their importance to human health, synthetic challenges limit access to these important pharmacophores. The research described in this proposal seeks to develop new catalytic methods for the selective synthesis of diverse carbohydrate structures to enable the study and treatment of human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Plasmodium infections cause more than 200 million cases of malaria each year and more than 3.4 billion people are at risk for contracting this devastating infectious disease. The goal of this research is to understand the differentiation, function and maintenance of parasite-specific memory CD4 T cells that are critical for resistance to blood stage Plasmodium infection. These studies will provide new insight that will be used to develop and enhance immune-based interventions against malaria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Allosteric drug mechanisms promise superior target selectivity, reduced drug toxicity and increased drug safety, but the rational development of allosteric drugs still faces fundamental challenges. In this project, we address these challenges with the development of novel and widely applicable computational methods to predict protein conformational fluctuations that form the basis for allosteric drug mechanisms. We first apply our methods to identify allosteric mechanisms and drug binding sites in matrix metallo-proteinases implicated in inflammatory disease and tumor metastasis, but the proposed methodology is general and applicable to other drug target proteins.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Understanding neuronal subtype-specific function of NAc in cocaine addiction Project Narrative Drug addiction is an urgent social and health problem contributing to the death of more than 90,000 people and incurs a yearly cost of over $700 billion in the United States (see NIDA website). Although the nucleus accumbens (NAc) of the middle brain is known to play an important role in drug addiction, the molecular mechanism and neuronal circuit involved is largely unknown. In this proposal, we propose to use the clinically relevant intravenous cocaine self-administration (IVSA) mouse model and single cell RNA-seq to identify the neuron subtypes and circuits mediating the addictive process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: OTHER PROJECT INFORMATION – Project Narrative The COVID-19 pandemic and associated mitigation strategies have been shown to disparately impact socially vulnerable and under-served minority groups in the US. This proposed study develops an innovative approach to analyzing the effects of COVID-19 mitigation policies on American Indian populations living on tribal lands and in rural areas, by integrating big data and deep learning techniques with primary data collection. Our research efforts seek to improve American Indian health by understanding and evaluating these NPI measures on an NIH- designated disparity community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project narrative:  It has been a long-standing goal of neuroscience to directly “see” electric activities in a complex neuronal network. Existing optical imaging techniques require the incorporation of fluorescent molecular probes into neuron in order to detect electric activities, which is limited by photobleaching and can perturb cellular physiology. This study aims to develop a novel optical technique that detects neuroelectric activities without any fluorescence probes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE — HEALTH RELEVANCE Cardiometabolic conditions, such as type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension, increase the risk for fractures, which is a substantial public health problem in older adults in the United States. The proposed study will utilize 25 years of previously collected data regarding biomarkers and incident cardiometabolic disease from the Coronary Artery Risk Development in Young Adults (CARDIA) study, and add validated vertebral strength data, to further our understanding on how cardiometabolic disorders and hallmarks of cardiometabolic disease over the life span impact vertebral strength, a surrogate for vertebral fracture risk.

PHR: NARRATIVE There is strong evidence for the association between sedentary behaviors and cardiovascular diseases such as coronary heart disease and stroke. Long-term, our findings will inform a large clinical trial that can test whether sedentary behavior reduction can decrease cardiovascular disease risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative IgA nephropathy, the most common primary glomerulonephritis in the world, often resulting in end-stage kidney disease with no disease specific treatment. Although it is known to be an autoimmune disease, the mechanisms that underlie the production of the critical autoantigen that mediates disease progression are unknown. The proposed studies will integrate single-cell RNA analysis with a novel cell-surface glycophenotyping to analyze the specific immune cell populations responsible for autoantigen production.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Studies to date suggest that the sexual and reproductive health (SRH) care needs of adolescents and young adults with disabilities are not well met. The proposed study will generate national, population-based estimates of sexual and reproductive health risks and outcomes among transition-age adolescents and young adults with disabilities, and also examine their unmet needs and barriers to SRH care. The study will produce an evidence-based, accessible sexual and reproductive health education toolkit for adolescents and young adults with disabilities to improve their SRH and healthcare experiences and promote active engagement in their own care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE  Opioids have been abused enormously in our society in the past decade to the degree that it is at present an epidemic affecting our youth. In the current application, we focus on the effect of opioids, namely methadone, on the formation and development of the human brain in the fetus during pregnancy when pregnant women are using or abusing methadone. The idea behind this proposal is to be able to understand the mechanisms by which deleterious effects happen as a result of methadone use/abuse in order to counter them and mitigate the impairment induced by opioids on fetal brain integrity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The growth factor receptor, HER3, facilitates tumor resistance and metastasis, hence the HER3-targeted particle we have developed may mediate therapeutic efficacy to tumors escaping current clinical interventions. This project will test whether current targeted inhibitors used in the clinic shift both HER2+ and triple-negative tumor cells to a HER3-targeted phenotype for entrapment by our HER3-targeted particles. These particles, or nano- capsids, will also be evaluated for targeting resistant tumors that have metastasized to the brain, thus offering improved alternatives for tumor types with few to no current treatment options.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement While tobacco cigarette smoking is well known to cause lung cancer, it is not established if electronic cigarette (e-cig) use also causes lung cancer. Studies will be performed in a chronic mouse model of e-cig exposure to determine the duration and intensity of e-cig inhalation required for initiation of lung cancer as well as the role of vape free radicals and nicotine levels. Longitudinal studies with imaging of lung cancer development will be performed with histopathology confirmation, the underlying mechanisms of cancer onset, and potential approaches to ameliorate/prevent e-cig-induced lung damage will be identified, providing important insights toward defining the cancer risk of e-cigs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ischemia/reperfusion (I/R) injury is a causative factor of morbidity and mortality during liver resection, and transplantation. Steatotic livers has significantly more vulnerable to I/R injury associated with these operations. There are no therapeutic strategies to reduce this I/R injury in steatotic livers. Therefore, our goal of this proposal is to develop novel therapeutic strategies to attenuate I/R injury in steatotic livers.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The human microbiome has been implicated in numerous aspects of health and disease. The goal of this proposal is to determine the functional consequences of bacterial adaptation in the inflammatory intestinal environment. New insights into the contribution commensal bacterial adaptations to early stages of gut inflammation will be a powerful strategy for detecting and treating early stages of IBD and preventing progression into the debilitating chronic phase of IBD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative  With a growing aging population worldwide, Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD) is expected to affect nearly 14 million Americans alone by 2060, contributing to long-term disability, reduced quality of life, and substantial healthcare costs. We will utilize large longitudinal electronic health record (EHR) data from three prominent academic centers and advanced informatics technology to thoroughly investigate the role of bilingualism on age-related cognitive health outcomes. We will develop informatics methods to assist with extensive screening, recruitment, and in-depth analysis of phenotypic information collected from both patient surveys and EHR data, while exploring novel pathways by which bilingualism influences cognitive reserve, or the ability to cope with neurological stress, in elderly bilingual and monolingual adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Public Health Relevance Protein-protein interactions (PPIs) are involved in nearly all biological processes, including cell proliferation, growth, differentiation, and apoptosis. Identification of collagen-protein interaction modulators will aid in the development of novel therapeutics for maladies including cancer, fibrosis, diabetes, and neurodegenerative disease in addition to serving as important chemical tools for elucidating fundamental aspects of human biology and biochemistry. Hyperstable collagen peptides and peptide mimics containing aza-amino acid residues offer the possibility to study previously elusive interactions between collagen triple helices and the myriad proteins that comprise the human collagen interactome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative Dysfunction or loss of endocrine beta-cells leads to diabetes. Pancreatic islets receive neuronal input from sympathetic and parasympathetic nerves and these interactions are essential for hormone secretion. During pregnancy, beta-cells respond to high metabolic demand by increasing their mass and secretory function. The goal of this project is to address the role of sympathetic nerves in regulating the structural and functional plasticity of beta-cells during pregnancy using whole organ clearing, 3D imaging, and nerve ablation studies in mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Mental illnesses such as bipolar disorder and schizophrenia are most often treated with a class of medications called neuroleptics, which block dopamine signaling in the brain. Long-term treatment is often complicated by the development of abnormal movements, such as lip smacking and tongue protrusion, termed tardive dyskinesia. This project will use brain recordings in a mouse model of tardive dyskinesia, to better understand how dopamine and the brain cells it regulates cause involuntary movements.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: 8. PROJECT NARRATIVE Toxoplasma gondii is a parasite and NIAID category B Biodefense agent that chronically infects about a quarter of the world's population, causing recurrent ocular lesions in about 2% of cases and life-threatening infections in immunocompromised individuals. The proposed study will characterize the mechanisms that allow parasites to enter a chronic state that is resistant to all current therapies and acts as a reservoir for reactivation. Our work will lay the molecular foundation for future therapies that can prevent and eliminate chronic Toxoplasma infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our main goal is to provide concrete real-world evidence from large collections of real-world data (RWD) to fill the knowledge gaps in our knowledge of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) risk and heterogeneous progression pathways in the sexual and gender minority (SGM) populations as well as their disparities in AD outcomes. We will leverage our access to large collections of RWD from the OneFlorida+ and INSIGHT networks – two clinical research networks contributing to the national Patient-Centered Clinical Research Network (PCORnet). More importantly, this project will establish a framework for creating RWD-based virtual cohort, which can inform national pragmatic trials across PCORnet for future SGM aging clinical studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Parental substance use (SU) is a leading cause of recent increases in CWS cases, and parental SU is associated with worse outcomes; however, engaging parents in SU services is challenging, as it requires collaboration across multiple systems (e.g., CWS, SU treatment agencies) and there are multiple points where parents can fall out of care. There is a critical need to better identify gaps in service provision in order to inform selection of appropriate EBPs that meet the needs of this population. The proposed project seeks to utilize community engagement and data-driven processes in EBP adoption and implementation in order to improve SU service provision for parents involved in CWS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: This UG1 project will cohere local research strengths in brain imaging and clinical trials to establish a Clinical Laboratory with Integrated Neuroscience (CLIN) for Evaluation of Medications for Substance Use Disorders at the University of Pennsylvania. The initial demonstration project in the UG1 will test whether cariprazine, a candidate anti-relapse medication with high D3-affinity, demonstrates both target engagement (e.g., blunting of drug cue-triggered limbic activation) and preliminary clinical efficacy (reduced illicit drug use, and improved adherence to life-saving naltrexone) in patients with opioid use disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pulmonary tuberculosis including drug-resistant disease is an enormous public health problem responsible for substantial morbidity and mortality worldwide with the number of deaths increasing for the first time in over two decades. This proposal seeks to better understand the host inflammatory response to Mycobacterium tuberculosis in individual human lung granulomas and to map the spatial distribution of newly implemented drugs used to treat drug-resistant disease within granuloma microenvironments. The long-term goals of this work are to provide data that will help guide the 1) development of host directed therapy to limit lung tissue damage and 2) design of optimal drug combinations to improve treatment and long-term outcomes among patients with pulmonary tuberculosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Neurodegenerative diseases and brain cancers are difficult to treat due to the presence of blood brain barrier (BBB), which prevents most of therapeutic drugs from penetrating the tight junctions of endothelial cells in the brain microvasculature and accessing the brain tissues. Ultrasound (US) has been shown to be the most effective and safe method to induce the BBB opening, facilitating the drug delivery into the brain tissue. Here, we propose a novel biodegradable US transducer based on biodegradable, flexible and highly piezoelectric nanofiber film of glycine crystals embedded inside a polycaprolactone (PCL) polymeric matrix to facilitate drug delivery through the BBB for the treatment of brain cancers

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Cognitive and affective processes engage distinct but interacting systems in the brain, which are important in decision-making but disrupted by stress. This proposal will use innovative approaches to identify the functional contributions of specific circuits and neuromodulation in frontal brain regions to cognitive-affective interactions during decision-making, and the effects of stress on these circuits. Elucidating these neural mechanisms will not only provide fundamental knowledge about the circuit mechanisms underlying higher brain functions, but also identify potential therapeutic targets for alleviating the detrimental effects of stress and psychiatric illnesses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative. The main objective of this proposal is to understand the structure, function, and regulation of two biologically related enzymes, PTEN and USP7. Protein semi-synthesis strategies will be used to install site- specific and stoichiometric post-translational modifications (PTMs) and non-hydrolyzable mimics in order to evaluate the substrate selectivity of USP7 and how PTMs influence enzyme structure and function. Results from these studies can pave the way to new therapeutics to treat a variety of human disorders including cancer.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Narrative Non-Communicable Diseases are an emerging global pandemic with disproportionately higher rates in developing countries. Uganda with a large rural based population, requires development and implementation of evidence-based interventions to address real-life problems and provide sustainable solutions. The proposed Building capacity for Implementation Science research in Non-Communicable Diseases (BImS-NCDs)” training hub at MUST, will provide leadership, best practices, research support, mentoring and training in epidemiological, prevention, and implementation science approaches in NCDs across the lifespan to the partner institutions in rural Uganda.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
ORG_NAME: MAKERERE UNIVERSITY COLLEGE OF HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative Despite the very high burden of rheumatic heart disease (RHD) in Uganda and most sub-Saharan African countries, there has been very little investment in research training and research. The proposed plan, the Impact Mentored Training Program, will train multidisciplinary health professionals at Makerere University College of Health Sciences to conduct RHD-related research with a special emphasis on clinical trials capacity building. Additionally, Impact will address the “double gender gap” in RHD research including (1) under-representation of women in research in Africa and (2) the dearth of sex- and gender-based analysis in RHD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE This renewal proposal will continue to develop and expand a model program to recruit, train, and sustain a growing cadre of diverse/disadvantaged (including under-represented minority) high school students and progressing undergraduates in biomedical research broadly targeting neurosciences, neurological disorders, and stroke. Using our inquiry-driven curriculum, we will energize a diverse career pipeline to promote networking, retention, and career progression, thereby contributing to NIH's strategic plan of creating the diverse research teams of the future and NINDS's mission of advancing translation of medical discoveries in the neurosciences from bench to bedside to community.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on identifying the alterations in the im- mune system that impact amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and also focuses on identifying whether these altered immune profiles are influenced by sex- and age-specific factors. The development of such strategies will greatly advance the ability to develop personalized treatment approaches for persons with ALS based on immunomodulatory drugs. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to part of the NIH’s mission that pertains to developing the fundamental knowledge about the nervous system and using that knowledge to reduce the bur- den of neurological disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cortical spreading depolarizations (CSDs), or “brain tsunamis” are waves of electrical activity that occur in 60% of patients with traumatic brain injury (TBI) and are associated with poor outcomes. In this proposal we test the hypothesis that CSDs have remote effects on hippocampus after TBI. Successful completion of this project will help determine how CSDs cause poor outcomes, and hence can identify treatment targets.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed United States-Zambia Addressing Risk Factors for Non-Communicable Diseases in Zambia (US-Zambia Risk-NCD) program will enhance capacity for research, training and policy direction on the long-term health and economic consequences of major risk factors for NCDs, which are large contributors to Zambia’s burden of disease. Applying transformative capacity development model for Zambians by Zambians with US technical assistance, we will address the major gap in chronic disorders by focusing on key risk factors and establish mechanisms to ensure long-term sustainability for a strong research enterprise in Zambia. The program aims to develop trainee researcher skills; create a sustainable platform for discussion among researchers, practitioners, policy makers and donors; and further strengthen the research enterprise around NCDs at UNZA by establishing a unit to support such research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: RELEVANCE Genetically programmed degeneration of photoreceptor cells and the retinal pigment epithelium is the underlying cause of blindness in nearly all inherited retinal diseases, many of which have no or only minimally effective treatment options. Thus, additional therapeutic approaches are urgently needed to diminish vision loss associated with these disorders. Using novel genome- editing therapeutic interventions, we aim to slow or halt the development and progression of retinopathies in animal models as a prelude to clinical evaluation of these therapies in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The circadian clock controls 24-hour rhythms in the body, and is an important regulator of brain function. We hypothesize that disturbances in circadian function, which are common in our modern society, can promote neurodegenerative diseases, in particular Alzheimer’s Disease. We will investigate the functions of a certain set of “clock proteins”, termed REV-ERBs, which control circadian rhythms in the brain, and determine molecular mechanisms by which they may influence neuroinflammation in Alzheimer’s Disease. We hope to use novel therapies to directly activate or block the function of these REV-ERB proteins to prevent Alzheimer’s Disease and other neurodegenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: A limiting factor in understanding gene regulation is insufficient knowledge of how regulatory information is encoded in the genome. By studying regulatory elements functionally defined by transcription across evolution, this proposal aims to reveal the key DNA motifs, transcription factors and regulatory networks mediating eukaryotic gene expression. These insights should also be instrumental to better interpret the human genome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Narrative Metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer remains an incurable disease. Alterations in the genes that regulate the body’s processes for repairing damaged DNA, particularly BRCA2, have been linked to treatment failure and poor prognosis for men with prostate cancer. In this project, we aim to comprehensively investigate the role of such alterations in the development of lethal, untreatable prostate cancer with the goal of identifying and developing novel combination treatments, such as targeted immunotherapy and radiotherapy.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The current Coronavirus disease 2019 virus (COVID-19) pandemic has made a serious impact on global public health and economy. The goal of this project is to develop COVID-19 subunit vaccine formulated by a modified porous silicon microparticle and delivered by parenteral and mucosal prime/boost vaccination. This vaccine approach is expected to generate both systemic and mucosal humoral and Th-1 directed cellular immune responses, which will provide long-lasting cross protection against SARS-CoV-2 variants of concern and prevention of future coronavirus outbreaks.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Shigella is a primary cause of moderate-to-severe diarrhea including dysentery in children living in impoverished areas of the world. The current World Health Organization (WHO) guidelines for treatment of shigellosis (in the absence of a rapid, simple and inexpensive diagnostic test) recommends treatment with antibiotics when presence of visible blood in stool, although, majority of the Shigella diarrhea are watery diarrhea in nature and thus the non-dysentery Shigella associated diarrhea (NDSD) cases would not be treated, which might result in an appreciable amount of unaddressed Shigella-associated morbidity and mortality. We aim to study the pathophysiology of NDSD and the impact of NDSD in children to understand if there is a need to change the current treatment guidelines for shigellosis to improve survival and long-term developmental potential in children and we also aim to evaluate our novel, simple, rapid and sensitive diagnostic assay, if capable of identifying the patients with shigellosis who will benefit from antibiotics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative This project is relevant to public health because it will investigate the function of a human enzyme involved in the metabolism of fats. Specifically, the project will elucidate how this enzyme modifies the chemical composition of membranes and how these modifications impact the metabolism of lipoproteins and the regulation of body fat. As a result, the work will provide fundamental knowledge relevant to obesity, the metabolic syndrome, and atherosclerosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance (Project Narrative) International consensus guidelines have a dismal specificity for discriminating benign from malignant intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm (IPMN) (a type of common pancreatic cyst and precursor to pancreatic cancer) and a poor accuracy of predicting IPMN malignant progression during surveillance. The proposed study is expected to develop models that integrate plasma and pancreatic cyst fluid levels and trajectories of protein and metabolites with clinical and imaging features, which are more accurately predictive of IPMN malignant progression and early-stage pancreatic cancer than the current clinical guidelines based solely on clinical and imaging findings. Such expected results are significant because they will lead to an improved clinical management of IPMN and an increased long-term survival of pancreatic cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative: Diabetes-associated gastrointestinal motility disorders are a major public health concern and are more prominent in females than males. The long-term goal of this project is to understand the mechanisms of sexual dimorphism in gastrointestinal motility and how diabetes causes motility disorders in females. The studies may offer insights into the development of new therapeutics for diabetes-associated motility disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A unique feature of Plasmodium vivax biology is that, after hepatocyte infection, a fraction of sporozoites do not initiate genome replication and schizogony but instead form hypnozoites, non-replicating stages that persist within hepatocytes for weeks, months or even years after the primary infection. In this application we will identify the parasite molecular drivers of hypnozoite formation and persistence and host hepatocyte factors that impact hypnozoite formation and persistence. The findings of this application might lead to the identification of new parasite-targeted and host-targeted therapeutics that prevent relapsing malaria infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  The heart's upper chambers, the atria, and its lower chambers, the ventricles, contain fundamentally dis- tinct types of muscle cells, and are affected by different types of disease. One common and severe disease specific to the atria is atrial fibrillation, which occurs in over 9% of older individuals. This proposal will investi- gate the mechanisms that maintain atrial muscle cell gene expression, and perturbation of these mechanisms that cause atrial fibrillation, resulting in new insights into the causes of atrial diseases such as atrial fibrillation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Opioid Use Disorder (OUD) is a debilitating condition for which we have an incomplete knowledge of pathobiological processes. A better understanding of these processes in key affected cell types will lead to the development of better therapeutic targets. The goals of this project are to perform single cell studies across OUD-relevant mouse brain regions under various opioid exposure paradigms, in order to identify candidate OUD driver genes, pathways and cell types, and to test the causal involvement in OUD of the candidates identified.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a common joint disease characterized by loss of mobility and chronic pain, in which currently available therapies remain without effect in 30-70% of the patients, suggesting a critical need for identification of new therapeutic avenues. We discovered that the engulfment and cell motility protein-1 (ELMO1) contributes to disease development in mouse models of RA by facilitating recruitment of immune cells called neutrophils into the joints, where they contribute to inflammation and bone degradation. In this proposal, we will delineate the mechanisms by which ELMO1 regulates neutrophil recruitment into joints, which could lead to the discovery of new targets for therapeutic development in rheumatoid arthritis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Schwann cells are neural crest derived cells whose primary function is the support and protection of neurons in the peripheral nervous system, and abnormal function of specific sub-populations of these cells can lead to abnormal sensory or motor function, or to tumors. Rac1 is a signaling molecule that functions broadly in Schwann cells, and my laboratory has generated a new mouse model in which the protein is abnormally activated in this cell type and interferes with the formation of normal populations of mature cells. In this pilot project, we will perform single cell analysis to begin to elucidate how the unregulated activation of this protein in all Schwann cells alters both the form and function of distinct populations of mature Schwann cell subtypes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Intractable pain is a major clinical challenge that poses a heavy societal burden and is driving a national controversy over the use of potentially dangerous opioid analgesics. This project explores novel endogenous mechanisms by which mitochondrial function regulates sensory neuron sensitization and excitability in preclinical models of acute and chronic inflammatory and neuropathic pain. Experiments proposed here will use mild mitochondrial uncoupling compounds as pharmacological tools to manipulate mitochondrial function in sensory neurons, and will test their efficacy as novel anti-nociceptive agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Advanced breast cancers of the most common type (Estrogen Receptor (ER) positive) initially respond to hormonal therapy, but then become resistant to further therapy. As they invade, breast cancers shed cells into the bloodstream (Circulating Tumor Cells; CTCs), which we have been able to culture repeatedly in the laboratory during the course of therapy, providing an exceptional resource to better understand acquired drug resistance. Using these patient-derived cell cultures, we propose to apply sophisticated functional genomic and chemical proteomic technologies to characterize and ultimately overcome the most common, and least well understood, mechanism of acquired resistance to hormonal therapy, namely the complete loss of ER expression in breast cancers that were initially ER positive.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tuberculosis (TB) remains a major public health burden worldwide. An attenuated live vaccine (BCG) is currently licensed but inadequately controls the TB epidemic. The limitation in protection by this vaccine is still elusive. Therefore, a better understanding of the biological difference between TB bacilli (Mtb) and BCG is essential for generation of a more effective TB vaccine. We have demonstrated that a c-di-AMP phosphodiesterase-deficient mutant of Mtb secretes a large amount of c-di-AMP and induces a strong type I interferon (IFN-I) response in the infected macrophages. In contrast, BCG is unable to secrete c-di-AMP and is defective in IFN-I induction, even when the same gene is deleted. Interestingly, it has been reported that IFN-I links between innate and adaptive immunity, and addition of IFN-I elevates the immunogenicity of BCG. Moreover, c-di-AMP itself has been recognized as a vaccine adjuvant. Based on our understanding of the c-di- AMP-mediated signaling network in Mtb and BCG, we will construct novel recombinant BCG strains that secrete c-di-AMP and induce IFN-I in the vaccinated host. It is very likely that this approach will improve BCG's efficacy. Additionally, the result of this proposal will provide fundamental insights into vaccine strategy against other pathogens. Therefore, the outcomes from this proposal will largely impact public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Lay Summary We have identified a pathway involving a protein termed Notch4 that plays a critical role in asthma by disrupting the function of immune regulatory T (Treg cells) that normally inhibit lung inflammation and we also found that different agents that aggravate asthma including allergens, pollutant particles and respiratory viruses all act to activate this pathway. In this proposal, we will employ genetic mouse models and studies on blood samples of human patients with asthma to examine how Notch4 activation impairs immune tolerance and promotes asthmatic inflammation. These studies will be important in devising new therapies to treat asthmatics.

PHR: NARRATIVE — JHU TRAC OVERALL To make further progress in efforts to achieve the World Health Organization’s END TB goals, additional innovative, cross-disciplinary and impactful research is critical and a new generation of TB scientists must be recruited and trained. The Johns Hopkins University (JHU) TB Research Advancement Center (TRAC) will provide added value to TB researchers at JHU by bringing together highly experienced researchers across multiple disciplines and representing four JHU schools (Medicine, Public Health, Nursing and Engineering) in order to optimize training opportunities for junior investigators and support for new, interdisciplinary collaborations, with the goal of addressing critical knowledge gaps in TB research.

PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: Malfunctioning of protein N-terminal methyltransferases is closely associated with various human diseases. We propose a series of chemical biology strategies to elucidate the mechanism, inhibition, and functions of protein α-N-terminal methylation. This effort is of great significance to understand basic biological processes of protein α-N-terminal methylation, which may ultimately lead to novel therapeutic approaches and targets for cancer, aging, and other diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative The parasite Toxoplasma gondii infects nearly a third of the word population and can lead to severe disease and even death in immunocompromised individuals and those infected congenitally. This parasite possesses a single mitochondrion that is essential for its survival and interestingly changes shape as the parasite goes from cell to cell. Our research aims at identifying the proteins and processes that control the shape of the mitochondrion, which will reveal new ways to target the mitochondrion as a way to combat toxoplasmosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Project Narrative This study is to test the hypothesis that targeting histone demethylase LSD1 to adjust gene expression and ameliorate synaptic defects is a novel treatment strategy for autism. Both Shank3-deficient mouse models of autism and human neurons differentiated from stem cells of autism patient with Shank3 haploinsufficiency will be used to test this hypothesis. This study will provide great promise for the discovery of novel pharmacological agents to treat social deficits and repetitive behaviors associated with autism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite their protective role in infection, dysregulated expression of inflammatory genes can be deleterious to the host. Many patients suffering from the pandemic COVID-19 caused by the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) display overt inflammation, leading to morbidity and mortality. This proposal aims to take an integrated approach to characterize the role of epigenetic factors controlling DNA topology (topoisomerases) in regulating inducible transcription in COVID-19 response, and determining if the anti-inflammatory effects previously observed for Topoisomerase inhibitors in vivo are therapeutic in animal models of COVID-19.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Understanding the relative abundance of beneficial, neutral, and deleterious mutations in different variant categories (e.g., genic vs. intergenic) provides useful guidance and resources for biomedical researchers to prioritize disease-causing mutations and strategize their efforts. To date, however, little effort has been made to study the full spectrum of fitness effects of new structural variants – an important but largely underappreciated genomic variation. The work proposed here seeks to leverage long-read sequencing technologies and develop novel machine-learning approaches to quantify the fitness effects of new mutation, with a focus on structural variants, and subsequently delineate the relative importance among different types of mutations in genetic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Our aging population is expected to develop increased incidences of neurodegenerative disease and dementia, but the molecular mechanisms that underlie these complex processes remain poorly understood. This proposal aims to understand how neuronal activity-dependent gene expression and DNA damage repair can regulate brain aging by leveraging a newly identified neuronal-specific protein complex, NPAS4:NuA4. These experiments will lay critical groundwork for designing targeted strategies to slow or reverse decline in the neuronal subtypes most susceptible to age-dependent diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Project Narrative The purpose of this project is to contribute to increasing diversity, inclusivity, and belonging for those underrepresented in the biomedical workforce that is known to increase productivity of teams in the biomedical sciences. Specifically, this proposal seeks funding for eight PhD trainees who will engage in activities to strengthen their academic skills and confidence, promote their career exploration across biomedical fields, and establish a community of belonging. The proposed activities will improve the overall environment of the graduate school and help our students excel as researchers to propel them to careers of their choice in the biomedical scientific community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Patients with HBV infection are subject to prolonged (often lifelong) treatment due to the lack of curative therapeutics. Thus, multimodal, robust therapeutic strategies are urgently needed to eliminate HBV cccDNA, which sustains viral replication and is refractory to the current antiviral regimens. Recently, we have designed and selected specific and potent gRNA/Cas9 HBV gene-editing drugs using HBV cellular models. We have also developed an exosome-based drug delivery system packaged with these synthetic gRNA/Cas9 HBV gene-editing drugs to specifically target human hepatocytes. In this proposal, we will evaluate the antiviral efficacy and any potential off-target effects of a novel gRNA/Cas9/Cas12/Cas13-based gene-editing regimen targeting HBV DNA and RNA, both in vitro and in vivo. The objective of this project is to lay the foundation for future clinical studies, to achieve our long-term goal of curing chronic HBV infection. If successful, this novel drug design and delivery platform may be utilized to combat existing and emerging viral diseases. It is thus clinically significant, timely, and relevant to public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute kidney injury (AKI) occurs frequently in critically ill children and existing decision support tools designed to improve patient care quality and safety have shown limited effectiveness while simultaneously increasing provider alert burden fatigue. This proposal will develop an integrated pipeline to support validated, shareable, usable decision support tools for subsequent clinical trials. Its success will launch a research program focused on improving the care and outcomes of critically ill children with acute kidney injury while reducing provider fatigue.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Abnormalities in red cell production and/or function can lead to life-threatening conditions. The program proposed in this application focuses on two red cell disorders, Diamond Blackfan anemia (DBA) and sickle cell disease (SCD) filling important gaps in our understanding of the molecular mechanisms leading to the etiology of DBA and the role of the bone marrow niche in both DBA and SCD. Completion of the program will lead to the development of novel therapies based on a better understanding of the pathophysiology of these disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Viruses that jump from animals to humans pose a significant threat to the health and wellbeing of humankind. To defend against the emergence of future viruses in humans, we will focus on an understudied family of animal viruses that are distantly related to coronaviruses – the arteriviruses – and identify molecular determinants of cross-species infection. Understanding the biology of arteriviruses in greater detail will improve our risk assessment of these viruses and will provide a foundation of tools, knowledge, and systems that could be used to combat a novel arterivirus outbreak in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Per- and polyfluoroalkyl Substances (PFAS) are chemicals that are widely used in industrial and commercial activities, and of growing concern due to persistence in the body and environment and emerging evidence of carcinogenic effects. Higher PFAS exposure may increase risk of prostate cancer (CaP), the most commonly diagnosed non-cutaneous cancer and second leading cause of cancer-related death in US men, but few large, population-based studies have tested this hypothesis in a racially and socioeconomically diverse population. This study builds on prior work to examine environmental causes of racial disparities in CaP using registry- based cohort data to link a spatiotemporal model of drinking water exposure to PFAS to estimate impacts on aggressive CaP incidence, and will investigate sources of PFAS exposure and potential influences on biochemical recurrence of CaP in a pilot study of survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Oral cancer is a deadly and debilitating disease that continues to have poor prognosis despite advances in treatment. There is a growing body of evidence implicating the fungus Candida albicans and the bacterium Fusobacterium nucleatum in the development of oral cancer; however, whether the two species interact to promote carcinogenesis is not known. In this application, we employ laboratory and animal experiments to investigate such interkingdom interaction in oral cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative The leading cause of poor outcomes for lung transplant recipients is chronic rejection, but we lack prediction models both for 1) the development of chronic rejection and 2) survival after chronic rejection. Chronic rejection has been associated with changes in the lung microbiome (i.e., the community of bacteria in the lungs), the recipient's immune response, and lung scarring that originates from mesenchymal cells that reside in the transplanted lung. This project will integrate clinical data with biological signals from the lung microbiome, immune response, and mesenchymal cell activation to: 1) Develop prediction models for the development of chronic rejection in healthy lung transplant recipients, and 2) Develop prediction models for survival at the time chronic rejection is diagnosed.
