IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and related dementia syndromes (ADRD) represent an enormous challenge for patients, families, caregivers, and health care systems. Rare cases of autosomal dominant AD (ADAD) offer a unique window into the biologic changes that cause AD and a compelling opportunity to intervene to stop the development of early-onset AD. In My K01 project, I will characterize how the hundreds of different, disease- causing genetic variants in Presenilin-1 (the most common cause of ADAD) are similar and different in their biologic effects, and thereby better understand AD biology, inform drug development, and improve chances for success in ADAD clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Here we will examine the neuronal mechanisms of Neuropeptide S (NPS), a neuropeptide shown to increase drug-seeking behavior as well as inhibit stress-induced behaviors. The orbitofrontal cortex (OFC) is a brain region linked to natural reward and drug-seeking behavior, which I found receives input from hindbrain NPS neurons. This proposal seeks to thoroughly determine how NPS transmission in the OFC and downstream targets is recruited during repeat exposure to high value rewards, ultimately identifying potentially novel treatment targets for treating opiate use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Silence ALS is a partnership between Columbia University and the n-Lorem Foundation to develop antisense oligonucleotide (ASO) medicines for patients with ultra-rare, genetic forms of ALS through a non-profit, precision medicine platform. With support from the URGenT Network, Silence ALS will develop nine ASOs targeting a variety of ultra-rare ALS gene mutations through investigational new drug (IND) clearance. The completion of the proposed work will establish Silence ALS as a model for therapeutic development in ultra-rare disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overarching goal of this proposal is to gain a deeper understanding of OPC phagocytosis in both health and disease and determine how phagocytosis alters their differentiation capacity. These results will have implications for neurodegenerative disease as lack of OPC differentiation is observed in multiple neurodegenerative states. This data will lay critical groundwork for future investigation into the diverse functions of OPCs in disease and will provide novel insight into new mechanisms that may alter OPC differentiation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Currently, no methods exist to prevent the onset of retinal tears and subsequent rhegmatogenous retinal detachments except to caution patients of new floaters, flashes of light and curtains in their vision. In spite of these warnings, patients may present late after the onset of symptoms resulting in poorer visual outcomes even after detachment repair. In this proposal, Dr. Cassie Ludwig aims to determine whether the use of clinical structured and unstructured variables in the electronic health record in addition to ultra-widefield color fundus photography can aid in improving prediction of risk of tears and detachments in myopic and non-myopic patients and thereby allow physicians to consider early prophylactic treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Voltage gated sodium channels (VGSCs) are critical gatekeepers of nociceptor excitability that mediate acute and chronic pain. We discovered that VGSC modulatory proteins that evoke resurgent sodium current are expressed in human, but not murine, nociceptors, strongly suggesting that human nociceptors display resurgent sodium currents. This study will exclusively use human dorsal root ganglia and, focusing on resurgent current in nociceptors, characterize sensitization- and pain-dependent alterations in VGSC expression, modulation, and function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The specialized properties of blood vessels in the central nervous system (CNS) facilitate proper neural function by exerting tight control over molecular transport and targeting blood to active regions. Mural cells, which line the outside of blood vessels, contribute to these specialized functions through tissue-specific gene expression, yet we do not know how this genetic program is activated during development. This project will improve fundamental knowledge of these developmental mechanisms, which may illuminate new strategies to prevent CNS mural cell dysfunction in neurological diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project is relevant to public health given that environmental insults and oxidative stress drive telomere damage and promote cardiac dysfunction. Here, we will investigate how oxidative damage at telomeres affects mitochondria and metabolism to drive cellular senescence. Deciphering the molecular interactions governing telomere status in response to environmental insults is expected to uncover therapeutic targets that could prevent the progression of cardiac diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rigorous consideration of sex and gender have not been routine in data science, Network Medicine, and Patient Oriented Research in lung disease. Addressing COPD through a sex and gender lens will promote translation of big data to actionable clinical innovations for women and men; investigation of association between mosaic chromosomal alterations of X and loss of Y chromosomes with COPD phenotypes, integration with Omics data and with gene regulatory networks will support advancing this goal. Mentoring and dissemination of sex and gender approaches to data analytics will inform strategies for Precision Pulmonary Medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  An effective and long-lasting vaccine will be essential to eliminate and eradicate malaria, a disease that afflicts more than 200 million people every year. The proposed research delves into humoral immunity to the PfSPZ vaccine, the only malaria vaccine with >90% protective efficacy, and how protective immune responses may differ in people who have already been infected with malaria. These insights will help us design the next generation of malaria vaccines that will be highly effective in the United States and Sub-Saharan Africa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Microtubules of the mitotic spindle orchestrate equal segregation of chromosomes during cell division. This work will reveal how mitotic spindles are generated during mitosis in animals and trypanosome parasites. By determining how different species make their spindles, we will better understand not only mitosis, a critical event in the lifecycle of the cell, but also can develop new treatments for parasitic infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Transcription factors are proteins which play key roles in a variety of biological processes and many human diseases, including cancer. Most transcription factors are expressed not as a single protein, but rather as a series of distinct protein “isoforms”, yet the vast majority of transcription factor isoforms—thousands of proteins—remain entirely uncharacterized. The proposed project will develop approaches to probe the roles of thousands of transcription factor isoforms at once in breast cancer cells, which will uncover novel disease- relevant biology and lay the foundation for studying isoforms more broadly, genome-wide and in other cellular contexts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research is relevant to public health because a lower insulin-stimulated glucose disposal by skeletal muscle is linked to many of the most prevalent and devastating age-related disorders in older people. It is crucial to understand how to improve the insulin sensitivity in skeletal muscle of older individuals. The new knowledge from this project has the potential to inform and inspire the development and optimization of strategies to improve the health of older people.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed studies will investigate the mechanisms that govern immune response to the brain tumor, glioblastoma. These mechanistic insights will help to inform the development of potential new combination therapeutic strategies for manipulating the specific immune cells, macrophages, in order to enhance anti-tumor immune response. This career development award will provide the applicant with high-level training and thereby allow her to launch an independent research career aimed at improving outcomes for patients suffering from brain tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The use of opioids in the US has created an opioid crisis that killed over 80,816 people in 2021. To aid in opioid cessation and opioid use disorder (OUD) treatment retention, new therapies are needed to both monitor and treat opioid withdrawal symptoms. Spark Biomedical proposes the combination of physiologic sensing and transcutaneous auricular neurostimulation (tAN) to deliver tailored opioid withdrawal treatment. In this proposal, we will collect wearable sensor data from adults with opioid use disorder entering detox treatment to develop a closed-loop machine learning algorithm that detect opioid withdrawal and cravings and triggers delivery of tAN.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are ~ 1 billion human influenza virus cases worldwide each year that cause up to 650,000 deaths. Influenza virus infection remains difficult to treat because the antiviral drugs available are usually limited to preventing influenza virus infection early in the infection and increasing drug resistance limits their effectiveness. We have identified an E3 ligase MARCH10 that targets an influenza virus virulence factor for degradation and propose in vitro and in vivo studies with the ultimate goal of developing new therapies to combat influenza virus infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Emergency Medical Service (EMS) systems aim to provide safe, high-quality care to sick children in ambulances as a national priority. This proposal leverages existing data from a K23 award to develop a simulation-based patient safety assessment toolkit and intervention training that are needed to test if EMS providers using video technology (teleconsultation) from ambulances to communicate with pediatric expert physicians in hospitals can provide safer care when compared to usual care. If this strategy is acceptable, feasible, and produces measurably safer care in a realistic simulated environment, it would support future clinical trials of this innovative intervention with real children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is currently an incurable and debilitating disease whose pathologies begin to accumulate in the brain decades before cognitive symptoms appear, indicating the importance of identifying individuals who are at risk of developing AD earlier in the aging process when they are still cognitively unimpaired. The current project aims to characterize brain connectome-based biomarkers of cognitive changes in aging and vulnerability to AD in cognitively unimpaired individuals, and examine the role of social disadvantage in contributing to risk for cognitive decline and AD. Findings from this project would benefit public health by informing not only risk prediction of AD, but also the development of targeted intervention and therapeutic treatment to promote healthy aging and prevent AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Bone disease is a concerning complication of cystic fibrosis (CF), since related fractures are associated with worsening pulmonary function and might contraindicate transplantation. Whereas genetic mutations leading to CF contribute to development of bone disease, diabetes and nutritional status are also theorized to be major contributors. Determining the effect of an anti-diabetes diet on bone health in people with CF, including underlying biological mechanisms, will help expand the evidence-base to support updated nutrition standards- of-care for reducing the burden of CF-related metabolic complications, namely diabetes and bone disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Rare diseases affect 30 million individuals in the United States and are a serious public health concern. Due to low awareness of and lack of effective treatment options for rare diseases, patients undergo protracted journeys toward diagnosis and therapy, i.e., rare disease odysseys, that have significant medical, psychosocial, and economic consequences. The objective of this study is to develop statistical machine learning models aimed at shortening rare disease odysseys and a framework leveraging REDCap for implementation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Studies have shown that non-invasive focused ultrasound thermal therapies can induce immunogenic cell death in breast cancer, although the mechanisms are not well understood. This proposal will characterize focused ultrasound thermal therapies in a breast cancer mouse tumor model by quantifying the immune response and correlating this response to a magnetic resonance image-derived thermal dose biomarker. The results obtained by this study will provide critical information that will be immediately utilized to inform future clinical trials that investigate combining MRI guided FUS with immune checkpoint inhibitors for local and systemic tumor control.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative By elucidating a molecular pathway contributing to fibroblast pathogenicity in rheumatoid arthritis (RA), we hope that our research will impact patient care both diagnostically and therapeutically. First, our findings will provide therapeutic benefit by examining the potential role for targeting the Wnt pathway in RA and by helping to build a foundation for a new class of therapies that directly addresses stromal populations. Moreover, our investigation of Wnt signaling among early RA patients and patients who fail to respond to conventional therapies may lead to innovative strategies to categorize and identify patients who could benefit from targeted treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative In clinical trials of drugs and other therapies to treat blinding diseases of the retina, the FDA’s official recom  mendation is to use functional assessment, as it is likely to provide earlier indications of their efficacy. In my lab we have discovered a novel way to measure neural function at the cellular level in the living, human retina (the optoretinogram), which may prove to be faster, less invasive, and more sensitive to neural dysfunction than existing methods. The goal of this grant is to study and improve the technology, and then demonstrate its ability to measure disease related dysfunction in patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE Current antiretroviral therapy has failed to eradicate HIV-1, partly due to the persistence of viral reservoirs including CD4+ T lymphocytes, cells of the monocyte-macrophage lineage, and other central nervous system cells. We propose to use state-of-the-art gene editing technology to extend the field’s general knowledge and specifically improve our ability to develop broad- spectrum CRISPR-based treatments to target the vast spectrum of HIV quasispecies as an important next step in the development of strategies to potentially cure for HIV disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE MOFFITT CANCER CENTER SUPPORT GRANT Moffitt Cancer Center (Moffitt) is a free-standing 501(c)3 not-for profit institution that was founded by legal statute to address cancer needs in the area, the State of Florida, and beyond, with the singular mission “to contribute to the prevention and cure of cancer.” Fully informed by the cancer burden in our community and catchment area, guided by highly effective, driven and synergistic senior leadership and a rigorous research strategic plan, supported by outstanding institutional funding, and cultivated by its five research Programs that span the basic, population, data, and clinical sciences, Moffitt fosters exceptional cancer research that spans discovery to translation to the clinic, and that has the momentum to accelerate its scientific impact for decades to come. More specifically, Moffitt’s research has provided paradigm shifts in our understanding of the cancer ecosystem, has discovered and advanced new means to prevent, treat and cure some forms of cancer that have led to changes in clinical practice and national health policy, and which over the next award period will be further accelerated by investments in research focused on: 1) our catchment area; 2) health disparities; 3) immuno-oncology; 4) metabolism; 5) data science; and 6) cancer care, delivery, and implementation science.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: AMERICAN ASSOCIATION FOR DENTAL, ORAL, AND CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative The American Association for Dental Research (AADR) aims to develop a national and sustainable mentoring and mentor training network with educational and interactive opportunities across the network, between mentors and mentees within and beyond the home institutions to support the development of a diverse cadre of dental, oral and craniofacial researchers. The AADR Mentoring an Inclusive Network for a Diverse Workforce of the Future (AADR ‘MIND the Future’) will engage mentor and mentees with the goal to guide individual career development as well as to improve the quality of mentoring at the home institution through dissemination of the lessons learned by mentors and mentees in the network to facilitate a diverse cadre of early career investigators in dental, oral and craniofacial research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Relapse is the major cause of death in patients with acute leukemia. We have developed the total marrow and lymphoid irradiation (TMLI) regimen to precisely direct radiation to areas of disease while sparing healthy organs; however, relapses are still common. This project is designed to provide improved tumor control and safe outcomes by discovering optimal dose escalation strategies and by developing methods to limit damage and destabilization to surrounding tissues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Autoimmune encephalitis is an increasingly recognized cause of neuroinflammatory diseases that present with a wide range of signs and symptoms ranging from ataxia to psychosis. This project leverages an innovative and high-throughput pipeline for identifying and regenerating autoantibodies from a cerebrospinal fluid biobank collected from a large and diverse cohort of patients with idiopathic encephalitis which will lead to improved diagnostics for autoimmune encephalitis, better understanding of its pathogenesis and insights into neural mechanisms that underly complex brain functions ranging from coordination to maintenance of mood and personality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROGRAM NARRATIVE Tumor metastasis to the liver is a leading cause of cancer death in the United States, and it is known to be associated with the increasing prevalence of obesity and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease. This Program represents the only coordinated, multi-investigator effort nationwide to focus on the causes of and approaches to address liver metastasis from cancers of the prostate, pancreas, and colon. Successful completion of the Program will lead to new targets for treatments for patients with liver metastasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The liver is the most common site of metastasis of solid tumors after the lymph node, with no curative intervention. We found that intake of a high-fat diet, even for a relatively short period of time, is sufficient to increase the incidence of liver metastasis in mice. Our project examines whether inhibiting a central pathway elevated by high-fat diet in both cancer cells and liver hepatocytes will limit liver metastasis of colon, pancreas and prostate cancer. The findings could suggest therapeutic targets for the greater solid tumor patient population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The extent of liver metastasis is a major survival determinant for patients with colorectal and pancreatic cancer, as well as for those with prostate cancer, and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease is a serious health concerns that increase the risk of both primary cancers and liver metastasis. Project 2 will investigate the role of hepatic stellate cells, extracellular matrix hyaluronic acids, and hepatocyte-derived extracellular vesicles in supporting metastatic liver tumor growth in a fatty liver environment. Successful completion of Project 2 will provide new insight into the molecular mechanism underlying metastatic liver tumor growth in different liver conditions, which leads us to consider different therapeutic strategies for liver metastasis in patients with or without non- alcoholic fatty liver disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this project is to define the diversity of the macrophage compartment of human lung tumors at the cellular and molecular level, and to determine the function of different macrophage subsets in tumor growth, remodeling, immunity, and response to immunotherapy. To achieve our objective, we will take advantage of unique immunotherapy trials in lung cancer, high-dimensional mapping techniques, including CITE-seq, and innovative culture systems and animal models of lung cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We have designed a chemical entity that inhibits two key enzymes overactivated in pancreatic, colorectal, and prostate cancer cells, histone deacetylase (HDAC) and glycogen synthase kinase- 3β (GSK-3β), and preliminary results show that it has significant effects on cancer cell metastasis to the liver in animal models of pancreatic cancer. Based on these results and our knowledge of the interactions of cancer cells in the microenvironment of the primary cancer, we hypothesize that the two enzymes play a critical role in developing a microenvironment in the liver to promote cancer metastasis progression. The results of this project, in collaboration with others in the Program, will provide essential information to develop therapeutics for the prevention and treatment of metastases to the liver, a serious unmet medical need.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis and frontotemporal dementia (ALS-FTD) is a disorder that can cause progressive paralysis, dementia or a combination of these motor and cognitive symptoms. What determines whether or not a patient with ALS-FTD will have cognitive symptoms is currently poorly understood. This proposal uses novel genomics methods to understand what molecular pathways contribute to the development of cognitive impairment in ALS-FTD patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Methionine adenosyltransferase 1A (MAT1A) is expressed in normal liver and its expression falls in patients with fatty liver disease, whereas MAT2A and MAT2B are expressed in non-liver tissues and are induced in multiple human cancers. This project examines the hypothesis that while hepatic MAT1A protects the liver against cancer metastasis, elevated MAT2A and MAT2B expression in cancer cells lowers this defense. Successful completion of this project will reveal novel mechanistic insights that may help us to understand the complex interactions between the homing site (i.e., liver) and infiltrating cancer cells, which could lead to new therapies to prevent metastasis across all types of tumor.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Polyploidy is the more than doubling a cell’s diploid genome and arises in response to injury, aging, and disease. Cells exhibit distinct ploidy states (mononucleated or multinucleated), however it remains poorly understood how a cell’s ploidy state affects its physiology. Therefore, the goal of this proposal is to elucidate how ploidy state alters resistance to genotoxic stress and cytoskeletal mechanics, two physiological roles for polyploidy in health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Previous work suggested that normal hematopoietic progenitor cells undergo transient de- condensation of nascent chromatin in order to allow lineage-specific transcription factors to bind to their gene targets and to activate new transcriptional programs, leading to cell differentiation. Lymphoid B-ALL and TCLL leukemic cells lost this ability to de-condense nascent chromatin, which may explain their inability to differentiate and their increased proliferative capability. We propose to overcome these barriers of reprogramming-based therapies of lymphoid leukemic cells through de-condensing their nascent chromatin and by inducing transcriptional reprogramming, which will lead to reduced proliferation, differentiation, and cell death.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Through our efforts nearly 30 years, we have established a new PD genetic locus on chromosome 20, identified TMEM230 as a new PD-linked gene, developed a series of TMEM230 mouse models, and found that synaptic vesicle recycling deficit may underlie the pathogenesis of TMEM230-linked PD. This project is designed to test the role of TMEM230 in synaptic vesicle recycling, and to determine the molecular mechanism in TMEM230-linked PD. Understanding the molecular mechanism may provide a pathophysiological basis for PD therapeutic development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Health disparities by race/ethnicity exist in the prevalence and outcomes of cataract, glaucoma, and diabetic retinopathy, but the impact of social determinants of health on quality metrics for care of these conditions is poorly understood. The Health Disparities in Utilization, Quality, and Outcomes for Three Common Ocular Conditions (HealthDOC) study seeks to understand the association of the social determinants on National Quality Forum and clinically meaningful measures, and mortality for racial and ethnic minority patients using an innovative strategy that incorporates data from the Sight OUtcomes Research CollaborativE (SOURCE). This research will have high impact by providing the health sector and other stakeholders with essential information about the quality of ocular care, which is needed for informed interventions aimed at reducing health disparities and improving quality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sexual minority men (SMM) experience intimate partner violence (IPV) at alarming rates and prior work has linked IPV with sexual risk-taking behavior and increased risk for HIV seroconversion among SMM, but less is known about the impact of IPV on HIV testing, pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) uptake, and the persistence of PrEP use among SMM. The proposed innovative observational cohort study will examine how perpetration and/or receipt of various forms of IPV (e.g., physical, sexual, and psychological; in the context of steady or casual intimate relationships) contribute to HIV risk and protective behaviors among HIV-negative SMM over a 24-month timeframe. This research will advance our understanding of both the risk and resiliency factors relevant to preventing and reducing IPV, reducing HIV risk behaviors, and increasing HIV protective behaviors among SMM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCE CTR
PHR: Project Narrative The advanced prostate cancer (CaP) is initially amenable for androgen deprivation therapy (ADT), and eventually, there is an emergence of CRPC. Next-generation ADT agents (abiraterone and enzalutamide) and chemotherapy are not curative of CRPC. Hence, the overall goal of the proposal is to determine the mechanism by which our small molecules (ASR-600 & ASR-603) target androgen receptor (AR) and androgen receptor splice -variants (AR-SV) in castration-resistant prostate cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Lymphangioleiomyomatosis is a low grade neoplasm that causes progressive lung destruction, lung cyst formation, and respiratory failure due to mutations in TSC2. In this proposal, we will determine whether mutations in other mTOR pathway and/or MITF family genes cause sporadic LAM, second, we will determine whether TSC2 mutations in plasma cell free DNA can be a biomarker of sporadic LAM, and at the same time search for generalized mosaicism in sporadic LAM patients who have singleton features of TSC in addition to LAM and third, we will examine the role of a new LAM gene, NR2F2, in LAM development through a series of genetic and epigenetic analyses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The most common known genetic cause of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and frontotemporal dementia (FTD), two progressive neurodegenerative disorders, is a repeat expansion mutation in an intron of the gene C9orf72. The G4C2 motif is repeated hundreds or thousands of times in affected cells, and the repeat expansion RNA accumulates in the nucleus and contributes to ALS and FTD pathogenesis. Understanding the composition of the RNA that accumulates and the mechanisms that control its degradation will suggest methods to accelerate its decay and perhaps new therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Insulin resistance often reflects an inability of white adipose tissue (WAT) to consistently respond to nutrient demands. The enzyme aspartoacylase (ASPA) is involved in lipid synthesis and is highly expressed in white adipose tissue, though its importance outside the brain remains unknown. My preliminary results suggest ASPA plays a prominent role in adipocyte differentiation and lipid storage within white adipose tissue; thus, this research seeks to define the function of ASPA in WAT and understand how its expression contributes to energy balance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Colorectal cancer (CRC) remains a leading cause of cancer-related death with limited treatment options. We recently identified a major protective role for microRNA, miR-146a, in limiting multiple angles of tumorigenic IL- 17-IL-17R signaling in CRC, and in this proposal, we use in vitro and in vivo experimental models in mice and CRC patient samples to probe the molecular mechanisms by which miR-146a mediates protection against CRC and assess targets for therapeutic intervention in a range of CRC models, including miR-146a mimic overexpression and miR-146a mimic in combination with chemotherapy. Elucidating the mechanisms by which miR-146a limits CRC may reveal novel targets for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ongoing gene therapy (GT) clinical trials employing AAV vectors to treat adult patients with hemophilia A (HA) have established the promise of GT for correcting hereditary bleeding disorders in adults, yet there are many advantages to offering these therapies early in life. The proposed studies will test the safety and efficacy of current and novel GT approaches in the treatment of adult and pediatric patients. If the safety and advantage of this approach is unequivocally demonstrated, these patients could benefit from this important clinical option for treating genetic disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Research Statement Fetal growth restriction continues to contribute to major medical problems for the fetus, newborn, and even the adult, which is highlighted by their higher incidence of Type 2 Diabetes. At present, no effective therapies exist to correct metabolic morbidity cause by sub-optimal fetal nutrition. We plan to investigate new strategies to reduce fetal stress during placental insufficiency that promote normal β-cell development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Allogeneic hematopoietic cell transplantation (Allo‐HCT) is a curative therapy for hematological malignancies, but graft versus host disease (GVHD), particularly corticosteroid resistant gut GVHD (SR‐Gut‐GVHD), remains the major obstacle, because the mortality of SR‐Gut‐GVHD is 70‐90%. The proposed studies will unravel the pathogenesis of SR‐Gut‐GVHD and develop new approaches for preventing and treating the disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Poxviruses are an important global public health issue, with concerns for orthopoxviruses ranging from a clandestine release of smallpox to outbreaks of epizootic infections such as monkeypox. Understanding the biology of poxviruses is still a priority not only for preventing epidemics but also for the creation of next- generation poxvirus-based vaccines and oncolytic poxvirus platforms. This project will investigate the molecular mechanisms used by poxviruses to envelope new progeny virions, exit from the cell, and infect new hosts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Excessive drinking and smoking promote the development of acute and chronic pancreatitis, two related inflammatory disorders of the pancreas lacking effective treatments. The mechanisms underlying alcohol and smoking toxicity to the pancreas are not fully understood, but recent evidence indicate that these factors alter the endoplasmic reticulum (ER), a cellular compartment needed to maintain pancreas function and the production of proteins to digest food. Using recently developed mouse models of pancreatitis, we plan to study how excessive drinking and smoking alters ER function resulting in disease onset and progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cataracts, a clouding of the natural lens, is treated by the surgical removal of the lens and implantation of an intraocular lens (IOL). The proposed work seeks to develop a superior IOL with a new material that will reduce post-surgical cell growth, eliminating the need for a 2nd surgery (laser capsulotomy) and improving vision outcomes.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite current biologic and other therapeutic agents, inflammation-induced bone loss continues to be a significant clinical problem for patients with inflammatory arthritis. This grant will determine the potential of a novel inhibitor of bone formation, Schnurri-3 (SHN3), as a target to prevent or treat inflammatory arthritis-induced bone loss. Additionally, bone-specific recombinant adeno-associated virus carrying a SHN3 silencer will be tested for the treatment of systemic bone loss and/or healing of articular bone erosion in this setting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Therapeutic intervention for fetal alcohol spectrum disorder (FASD), a highly prevalent neurodevelopmental disorder in the United States, is most effective if initiated early. The research proposed here will use a nonhuman primate model of FASD to develop in utero and neonatal MRI methods for detecting brain abnormalities and predict the severity of behavioral impairments associated with fetal exposure to alcohol. Studies of neural activity in the brains of ethanol-exposed animals will provide an understanding of the neurocircuitry involved in behavioral impairments associated with FASD, and guide the interpretation of fetal and neonatal MRI findings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The human immune system plays a vital role in our ability to fight infection; however, it can also cause harm in the form of autoimmune diseases, such as Type 1 diabetes, lupus, and multiple sclerosis. A wealth of information relevant to immunological research has been captured in biomedical databases, but this information can be hard to use because it is scattered and recorded in incompatible formats. This project will address this barrier by connecting the Immune Epitope Database (IEDB), a resource that compiles key information about the immune system, to other major resources (e.g., UniProtKB) to assist researchers and clinicians in their efforts to understand healthy and abnormal immune responses.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Psychological stress increases the susceptibility to neuropsychiatric disorders, such as anxiety, depression, and memory loss. The novel insights will help develop therapeutic strategies for mental illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The prevalence of type 2 diabetes (T2D) is increasing by alarming proportions in the US and worldwide. Over the last two decades, the number of new cases of diabetes has almost tripled in the US and current projections estimate that one in three Americans will have diabetes by 2050. This has a tremendous health care significance, as eight out of 10 patients with T2D die from cardiovascular disease. Vascular insulin resistance is an important factor in the pathogenesis of T2D and cardiovascular disease. The proposed study will determine the role that ADAM17 activity has in mediating microvascular insulin resistance in T2D with the goal of elucidating new therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this renewal application we will test a novel, rapid, non-sedate, non-contrast MRI approach to detect brain vascular and parenchymal abnormalities with a short, few-minute acquisition time in children with Sturge- Weber syndrome (SWS); this new approach can be also readily applied in other pediatric brain disorders. We will also study the effects of venous vascular remodeling and structural brain reorganization on neurocognitive outcome of school-age and adolescent children and young adults with SWS, who could benefit from targeted interventions to optimize clinical outcome. Finally, we will use brain tissue from SWS epilepsy surgeries to identify vascular and non-vascular cell types harboring the SWS-associated GNAQ somatic gene mutation and evaluate how the mutation is associated with brain abnormalities and protein changes related to abnormal cell development that could be targeted by pharmacological treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The research program outlined in this proposal is relevant to public health because it will utilize detailed electronic health record, clinical trial, and biomarker data combined with machine learning to improve the identification, risk stratification, and discover important subphenotypes of sepsis to improve patient outcomes. This work will result in novel algorithms that can be implemented to deliver early, personalized care to decrease preventable morbidity and mortality from sepsis. Therefore, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH’s mission that pertains to enhancing health, lengthening life, and reducing illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative  We have identified a new subset of macrophages, which express TGFβ1 on their cell surfaces and are present in high numbers in the bone marrow of aged mice where they appear to inhibit bone formation and interact with T lymphocytes to cause low level chronic inflammation during aging. We plan to further investigate the molecular mechanisms whereby interactions between these macrophages and T lymphocytes cause bone loss and low level chronic inflammation in aging mice and to determine if our recently patented bone-targeted hydroxychloroquine can block these interactions to prevent and reverse age-related osteoporosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this application is to provide additional training for Sharon Singh MD, a Pediatric Hematologist/Oncologist, in the evaluation of hematopoiesis by investigating how ribosomal protein haploinsufficiency alters stem and progenitor cell function. The applicant will be guided by a team of senior mentors with expertise in stem cell biology, erythropoiesis and anemia with the goal of understanding how defects in protein synthesis affect red cell biology. There is a critical need for further work in this field, which has implications for a wide variety of disorders that lead to anemia in children; execution of the proposed aims will mature the development of a pediatric clinician-scientist with expertise in the evaluation of normal and abnormal hematopoiesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Obesity and the associated metabolic syndrome present an enormous public health burden. Although behavioral (dieting and exercise), pharmacological, and surgical approaches exist for weight loss, many individuals who lose weight are unable to sustain this weight loss due to compensatory behavioral and neuroendocrine pathways promoting rebound weight gain. This proposal aims to characterize the utility of MC3R inhibition as a novel therapeutic approach for obesity, primarily via the ability of MC3R antagonism to prevent weight regain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The current understanding of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) beyond amyloid β (Aβ) depositions and tau tangles remains incomplete. Our proposed study will address the role of astrocytes, the most abundant cell type in the brain, in regulating AD pathogenesis and progression. Successful accomplishment of our study will pave the way for future development of novel therapeutic strategies to diminish the detrimental astrocyte response in AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narratives The goal of this proposal is to determine the role of estrogen and its receptors (estrogen receptor 1 and G protein coupled estrogen receptor 1) in regulating eye pressure by affecting the different parts in the anterior chamber of the eye. Eye pressure is the primary and only treatable risk factor with glaucoma patients in the clinic. The successful completion of this project will help uncover critical information on the specific roles of estrogen and its signaling pathways in regulating eye pressure and identify new treatment targets to lower eye pressure more effectively in glaucoma patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Remarkably, the changes in microtubule and actin networks as a function of aging have not been thoroughly characterized. Our studies will address fundamental questions related to the role of the nuclear-cytoskeletal linker protein, SUN1, and tubulin modifications in nuclear shape changes and in physiological and pathological models of aging, and we will determine whether these alterations are a cause or consequence of aging. Our studies will also provide insights into the changes in chromatin topology sustained by cells that age through normal or pathological mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Understanding the mechanisms of protein and organelle function and dysfunction in disease requires a detailed and dynamic analysis of molecular structures and interactions in live cells. The long-term goal of my laboratory is to develop tools that reveal these functional elements and apply them to discover significant biology and/or design molecules with useful properties. This application seeks support for three of the four areas we investigate, all of which depend the development and application of novel fluorescent tools.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Persons with HIV (HIV+) have a higher risk of developing metabolic diseases, such as type 2 diabetes or high cholesterol, compared to HIV-negative persons with similar age and body weight, but the reason for this difference in risk is not clear. Recent studies show that HIV infection and antiretroviral treatment can cause changes in subcutaneous adipose tissue (fat) which reduce its ability to store energy and lead to the accumulation of adipocytes (fat cells) around the internal organs, in the liver, and in other tissues. The goal of this study is to understand the factors leading to energy storage defects in subcutaneous adipose tissue and the excessive accumulation of fat in other organs, which could lead to therapies to reduce metabolic disease in both HIV+ persons and the general population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (RELEVANCE) This R01 proposal aims to develop a complete, diamond-based neural implant system that will consist of up to 256-channel recording electrodes in mm3-size volumes for combined electrophysiology and dopamine sensing from large-scale neuronal networks, with significantly enhanced sensitivity, specificity, and stability over existing technologies. The objectives of this proposal are consistent with the mission of the NIH, and will have a significant impact on public health by providing a novel neural interface tool for neuroscientists and clinical researchers to reveal the mechanisms underlying many brain disorders and diseases that are dopamine-dependent, such as Parkinson’s disease, schizophrenia, and drug addiction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Adiponectin is a protein that circulates in high levels in the blood and which has known protective effects on the cardiovascular system. Aging impairs vascular function, but late-life exercise can reverse much of the vascular dysfunction related to advancing age. The overall goal of this application is to determine whether adiponectin plays a role in 1) the vascular dysfunction that occurs with advancing age, and 2) the ability of exercise training to promote vascular resiliency and reverse age-related vascular dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Many infectious complications following craniotomy are attributed to Staphylococcus aureus (S. aureus) biofilm, which are debilitating due to their chronicity. We will examine how T cells that enter the infected brain promote the antibacterial activity of innate immune cells to contain S. aureus growth. In addition, we will examine how T cells cause S. aureus adaptation to escape immune-mediated clearance and establish craniotomy infection. A better understanding of how biofilms regulate inflammatory activity will guide the development of future immune- based strategies for the treatment of craniotomy infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because the identification of genetic risk factors for outcome and medication response in childhood epilepsies is ultimately expected to translate into personalized medication choices and early identification of patients at risk for refractory epilepsy or a poor developmental outcome, and will increase understanding of biological mechanisms underlying childhood epilepsies. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the purpose of the NIH Independent Scientist Award and mission of the NINDS by providing a tailored program to enhance the applicant’s skills for electronic medical record data analysis and large-scale genomic studies in order to use this knowledge to reduce the burden of neurological disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Suicidal thoughts and behaviors and non-suicidal self-injury are disproportionally high among justice involved youth (JIY). This study aims to collaborate with community mental health agencies who serve JIY to enhance the implementation of effective system-level interventions for detecting and treating non-suicidal self-injury and suicidal thoughts and behavior in justice-involved adolescents. This work has the potential to better understand what agency-specific factors facilitate the successful implementation of evidence-based assessment and treatment for suicidal JIY living in the community and will yield practice-relevant information regarding scalability, implementation, and dissemination of treatment in the community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Prevention of HIV-associated neurocognitive impairment (HIV-NCI) remains as an elusive therapeutic goal in HIV treatment because even early introduction of combined antiretroviral therapy (cART) gives incomplete protection to the brain. Brain injury can begin soon after initial HIV infection, and inclusion of a rapidly-acting neuroprotective agent with cART initiation as soon as possible after HIV infection is likely necessary for maximum brain protection. We have shown that dimethylfumarate, an FDA-approved drug used in the treatment of multiple sclerosis, shows promise as a suitable neuroprotective agent in the rhesus macaque model of early brain injury caused by immunodeficiency virus, which could lead to future neuroprotection studies in persons living with HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative HSV-1 infection is a known cause of secondary glaucoma and the only treatment options for the disease include reducing elevated pressure and inflammation in the eye. However, patients are sometimes resistant to current established treatments, and it is crucial to develop new treatments that can lower pressure and prevent recurrent HSV-1 reactivation. This study will examine the role of elevated intraocular pressure and damage to the drainage structures in the eye initiating the reactivation of HSV-1 and will provide a molecular understanding of recurrent HSV-1 reactivation in the eye, which may lead to better treatments for uveitic glaucoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The age-associated decline in physical function increases the risk of frailty and chronic disease and shortens the healthy lifespan. Several clinical studies have demonstrated strong associations between elevated kynurenine levels and frailty/physical function in older adults. Using modern genetic models in rodents, this proposal will examine a direct causal link between elevated kynurenine, the aryl hydrocarbon receptor, and exacerbated age-dependent decline in physical function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Mutations in dozens of different genes cause photoreceptor degeneration and blindness, but there is currently no effective therapy for these disorders. In this proposal we will develop a novel strategy to prevent blindness which utilizes CRISPR-Cas9 technology to knock out a key photoreceptor transcription factor, thereby suppressing photoreceptor degeneration. We believe that this new therapy will be applicable to multiple genetically distinct forms of blindness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Calcium entry via voltage-gated calcium channels controls many aspects of neuronal function, and precise coupling of calcium signals to effector mechanisms maintains homeostasis. The alpha2delta family of voltage- gated calcium channel subunits is required for normal brain function, however the cellular mechanisms underlying the functional roles of these proteins in neurons remain poorly defined. This proposal will investigate the role of these subunits in mediating the functional coupling of calcium entry to effector mechanisms across the brain, and help define a central role of this protein family in controlling neuronal signaling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative This prospective epidemiologic study is identifying novel factors, including plasma proteins, that contribute to increased risk of venous thromboembolism, i.e., blood clots in veins that may travel and block the blood supply to organs. This information will have important implications for the prevention and treatment of this common and significant cardiovascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE One major goal in human health is to understand the complex processes that permit regeneration of whole organs. A common approach is to employ a simplified model to address complex problems like regeneration. The proposal uses plants, which are highly adept at regeneration, as a tractable model to decode the signals that lead to complete organ repair.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The matrisome consists of glycosylated extracellular matrix and cell surface proteins that surround cells and support normal physiological activity. While it is known that glycosylation changes during disease processes, it has not been possible to quantitatively compare glycoprotein structure among biological samples. We aim to develop technologies to meet this need.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Inflammation is a double-edged sword, with the ability to rid the body of invading microorganisms and to cause collateral tissue damage when these mechanisms are out of balance. Oral bacteria such as Porphyromonas gingivalis, one of the main causative agents in the progression of periodontal disease, employ different strategies of subverting or enhancing the immune response to facilitate their own survival. Elucidating these methods of survival will ultimately lead to novel therapeutic targets to prevent bacteria-induced inflammation and to treat periodontitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Several neurodegenerative diseases are associated with the formation specific protein aggregates that form as a result of protein misfolding. We will use a yeast model to study such proteins, focusing on TDP-43 because its aggregates are associated with many neurodegenerative diseases. As yeast models have successfully identified human misfolding disease risk factors, it is likely that insights gained here about aggregate genesis, causes of toxicity and methods to rescue from toxicity will be applicable to human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Current treatments for FTD mitigate some behavioral changes, but there are no therapies that prevent or slow the progression of the disease. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aged-related bone loss, as seen in diseases such as osteoporosis, is a major global health problem that is characterized by a decline in skeletal stem and progenitor cell (SSPC) number and function. Therefore, it is imperative to maintain a sufficient pool of SSPCs for differentiation into osteoblasts for healthy bone homeostasis and bone regeneration during injury during aging. I hypothesize that Notch signaling is essential in maintenance of the skeletogenic stem cell pool during adulthood and aging through the induction of Ebf3 expression in SSPCs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To identify new treatment targets, the genomics of Alzheimerʹs disease (AD) has been examined primarily in non-Hispanic White populations. We propose here a genomics study of AD in Hispanic populations with Amerindian and southern European ancestry. We will use whole-genome sequencing in these populations together with information about ancestry and ethnicity to identify genetic variation influencing AD and to generalize existing AD genetic discoveries to this underrepresented groups.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Despite the prevalence and huge societal costs of Alcohol Use Disorder (AUD) – and in particular, binge drinking – few viable treatments exist, in part driven by the lack of mechanistic understanding of the disorder. This project will use advanced technologies and well-founded methods to investigate the involvement of a specific population of neurons and peptides in the prelimbic cortex in binge drinking behavior. This work will provide key insights into the neurobiological underpinnings of binge drinking, and support efforts to develop treatments for reducing AUD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: RV-C is a major contributor to wheezing illnesses and exacerbations of asthma in young children. Vaccination to prevent RV-C infections, especially in infants with genetic polymorphism in RV-C cellular receptor CDHR3 (rs6967330), could have major public health impact. The goals of this study, that include identification of host and viral determinants of neutralizing antibody responses, determining antigenic cross-reactivity between RV-C types, and mapping major neutralizing immunogenic epitopes, could enable formulation of a broadly protective multivalent RV-C vaccine. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Sexual minority youth experience pronounced mental health disparities in terms of depression and suicidality. These disparities may be related to circumstances associated with the sexual minority identity development process, which primarily occurs during adolescence; however, these processes and relations are poorly understood. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will advance our understanding of sexual minority identity development and mental health, and the findings will inform the development of evidence-based interventions to support sexual minority youth during challenges that arise during identity development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: The proposed studies address an important and under-investigated area of childhood developmental stuttering pertaining to neural network development. The results from this research are expected to have an important positive impact, by identifying neural network markers apt to predict eventual persistence versus recovery during early phases of symptom progression up to adolescence. This may, in turn, guide clinical practices in terms of prioritizing intervention and as well as provide developmentally appropriate areas to consider in preventive and therapeutic interventions for childhood stuttering.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: High-grade gliomas are a common and incurable form of brain tumor in both children and adults. We have recently discovered that high-grade gliomas utilize an extracellular regulated protein for survival and this protein can remodel the tumor microenvironment to sustain glioma growth. The proposed work and experiments will seek to deepen our understanding of the unique functions and the role of this protein in brain tumors. This study will extend our knowledgebase on how this protein promotes glioma growth and to identify a beneficial therapeutic strategy for brain tumors and all other cancers that utilize this protein.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Cells use a diversity of chemical nucleotide modifications to regulate genes, and scientists use them to create potent RNA vaccines and drugs, where such modifications often exert their effect by altering RNA folding to trigger additional changes. This underscores a need to determine how modified RNAs fold, but while computational folding is widely used, accounting for the effects of modifications warrants revising its many parameters via a multitude of costly and laborious UV melting assays. We will develop computational methods for rapid estimation of these parameters from alternative, high-throughput structure probing assays, to advance studies of the roles of modifications in cellular function and to accelerate engineering of efficacious RNA medicines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hazardous alcohol use (HAU) is associated with gut microbiome dysbiosis and separately, an increased risk of cardiovascular disease (CVD). Gut microbiome-derived metabolites, like trimethylamine-N-oxide (TMAO) have been linked as a diagnostic and prognostic indicator of CVD. The goals of this project are to evaluate the relationship between HAU-induced alterations in the gut microbiota and its’ metabolites (i.e., TMAO), changes in the host metabolome, endothelial dysfunction and CVD severity while investigating the potential therapeutic efficacy of gut microbiota-targeted therapies to improve cardiovascular health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: Project Narrative Acute pain accompanies invasive surgical procedures and is often difficult to control, despite the use of analgesics such as morphine and cyclooxygenase inhibitors. Moreover, opioids present additional risks to surgical patients that cause complications, delay discharge, and can lead to addiction. This proposal will characterize the contribution of endocannabinoid metabolism toward postoperative pain and may lead to the development of novel opioid sparing analgesics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) is a chronic condition that emerges early in life yet is rarely identified or treated during early development. Current preschool ADHD treatments are limited by barriers to access, inconsistent impact on core ADHD symptoms, and a primary focus on daytime behaviors, when ADHD may be best understood as a 24-hour disorder. The proposed project evaluates the effectiveness of PASS (Preschool Sleep and Attention Support), a behavioral telehealth intervention, in enhancing attention, behavior, and sleep among preschoolers identified as high risk for ADHD in the pediatric primary care setting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE High-mobility group box 1 (HMGB1) has a recognized role in platelet activation and thrombosis formation, but its mechanism of platelet activation in sickle cell disease remains unclear. I propose that circulating hemoglobin oxidizes HMGB1 to trigger an intracellular platelet signaling cascade that potentiates platelet mitochondrial reactive oxygen species (mtROS) and platelet activation. Investigating this novel mechanism of platelet activation will improve our understanding of the mechanisms linking hemolysis and inflammation to platelet activation and thrombosis, and establish a foundation for developing and applying HMGB1-inhibitors to prevent thrombotic complications in sickle cell disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Organelle dysfunction and compromised membrane protein quality control are hallmarks of neurodegenerative disorders. This proposal investigates the molecular mechanisms that collaborate to ensure high-fidelity membrane protein localization and topology. Molecular-level insights into these fundamental protein biosynthetic and quality control processes are necessary to understand how neurodegenerative diseases develop and identify effective treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  The recent advances in high-throughput sequencing technologies enable cost-effective characterization of the immune system and provide novel opportunities to study adaptive immune receptor repertoire (AIRR) at the population scale. In this study, we will develop robust and scalable bioinformatics tools and databases to leverage the largest dataset covering individuals of various ancestries composed of over half a million NGS samples. The availability of large and ethnically diverse sets of samples will allow us to discover novel population- specific immune alleles and clonotypes and will enhance our understanding of human adaptive immune responses across heterogeneous and admixed populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Racial and ethnic minoritized youth with prior juvenile justice system contact experience significant health and legal inequities that persist into adulthood, but the impact of structural factors on these inequities is unknown. Project EPICC-2 examines the impact of structural racism and discrimination and interaction with individual, familial and extrafamilial influences on longitudinal health and legal inequities among ethnoracial youth with prior justice contact. Leveraging an existing adolescent longitudinal dataset, pre-existing relationships with justice-impacted families, an intersectional lens and intergenerational approach, this study will inform public health and criminal justice interventions to dismantle structural racism and reduce health and legal inequities for justice-impacted youth and families.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because our ability to diagnose and treat drug abuse and addiction is critically dependent on fundamental understanding of brain networks altered by drugs of abuse and associated signaling pathways. The research described in this proposal will establish a new system to study how cannabinoid signaling impacts intact brains at cellular resolution that culminate in affecting elemental motivated behavior. If successful, it will pave a way to uncover principles of neural circuit development and dynamics, bridge a critical gap between molecules and systems impact associated with drugs of abuse, and shape policy and treatment strategies for drug abuse disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to develop a culturally tailored, web-based obesity intervention training for promotores. Comadres Saludables is a highly scalable training approach that will provide promotores with the self-efficacy, knowledge, skills, and tools needed to effectively implement an obesity intervention for Hispanic women in the community. The proposed training is designed for use by community health centers, large metropolitan health centers, and community organizations that employ promotores to address Hispanic health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Kidney transplant can be a valuable treatment option for older adults with kidney failure; however, the prerequisite physical and psychosocial evaluation process can entail substantial burdens for older adults and many will not ultimately receive a kidney. To ensure that the approach to care during this evaluation process aligns with the values and goals of individual patients, we propose a research agenda that will strengthen shared decision-making for older adults considering referral for kidney transplant evaluation. Together with an integrated career development plan, this work will also support Dr. Catherine Butler's transition to becoming an independent physician scientist whose research focuses on making the kidney transplant evaluation process more person-centered and equitable.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Novel strategies are urgently needed to shorten the duration of tuberculosis (TB) treatment in HIV-infected and uninfected individuals. The current proposal will test the ability of a novel vaccine to boost T-cell immunity against the key TB stringent response factor RelMtb, which is needed for the bacteria to become less sensitive to antibiotics, with the goal of shortening treatment and preventing relapse in a standard mouse TB infection model. In order to transition our findings to the clinical setting, we will test the vaccine’s ability to induce antigen-specific T-cell responses in rhesus macaques, and measure RelMtb-specific T-cell responses using clinical samples from a longitudinal cohort of HIV-infected and uninfected patients receiving treatment for pulmonary TB in South Africa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Understanding how chemical exposure affects organisms provides insight into understanding basic cellular metabolism, as well as paving the way for the treatments of neurological diseases and metabolic disorders. The glyphosate’s (the active ingredient in a popular herbicide) effects on cellular metabolism have hinted at mitochondrial targets but the mechanism is not known yet based on how it’s imported into cells it’s likely affecting enzymes that use glutamate and aspartate. Using S. cerevisiae, brewer’s yeast, as a model, we will determine how pure glyphosate and commercial preparations change mitochondrial function allowing for future studies on affected organs in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research and career development award proposal is relevant to public health because it examines strategies to prevent chronic lymphedema, a condition which impacts up to 5 million cancer patients in the United States. I will elucidate mechanisms underlying pathologic fat tissue deposition in lymphedema, and develop strategies to prevent this condition. Through this career development award, I will engage in formal training, workshops, and conferences to further my career as a physician-scientist with the goal of performing translational research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Glioblastoma (GBM) is a uniformly fatal disease with very few clinical options and is driven by abnormal signal transduction, originating from oncogenic drivers and loss of tumor suppressors, resulting in heightened glycolytic flux that can be therapeutically targeted for exploitation. We hypothesize a combination of standard of care 18F- FDG PET, which measures glucose uptake, fast pH- and oxygen-sensitive amine chemical exchange saturation transfer spin-and-gradient-echo echoplanar imaging (CEST-SAGE-EPI), a molecular MRI technique that can estimate acidity from lactic acid and oxygen utilization, as well as perfusion and diffusion MRI to account for the effects of blood flow/volume and cell density can be used to create a “glycolytic index”, or GI, that will allow us to accurately quantify glycolytic flux within heterogeneous tumors on widely available clinical imaging systems for use in studying glucose metabolism and response to a variety of targeted therapies in human GBM. The current study will (Aim 1) confirm the association between tumor tissue measures of glycolysis and the “glycolytic index”; and (Aim 2) quantifying changes in the “glycolytic index” and correlation with glycolytic signaling alterations through perturbation of glycolysis using a brain penetrant EGFR inhibitor specifically designed for GBM (i.e. ERAS801).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Schools represent a source of exposure to respiratory viruses, yet the magnitude of risk that schools represent is unknown. The proposed research is relevant to the part of NIH’s mission to promote healthier environments by describing the molecular epidemiology of circulating respiratory viruses in schools compared to homes, identifying potentially modifiable factors or interventions in the indoor school environment that impact respiratory virus exposure, and identifying the contribution of respiratory virus exposure to asthma morbidity in students. We urgently need research to identify practical and evidence-based strategies to create safe indoor school environments for students.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic stress plays a significant role in the development of neuropsychiatric illnesses such as depression and anxiety. Studies defining how the brain changes throughout chronic stressful experiences will be important steps towards identifying novel treatments for these disorders. This study will focus on how inhibitory circuits within the brain’s reward circuitry change during chronic stress.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project seeks to expand and pilot a status neutral online-linked mobile HIV/STI testing and care linkage strategy for Black gay, bisexual and other men who have sex with men (MSM) at high risk for HIV acquisition or transmission. This project is relevant to public health because Black MSM are disproportionately impacted by the HIV epidemic, but rates of HIV testing, care linkage to HIV pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) and treatment remain disproportionately low in this priority population. Our proposal aligns with the goals of the Ending the HIV Epidemic federal initiative by developing an innovative, strategic and tailored approach to effective HIV diagnosis, treatment and prevention for high risk Black MSM and has the potential to inform public health strategies prioritizing Black MSM by reaching both those at high risk for acquisition and transmission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Human papillomavirus (HPV)-associated oropharyngeal cancer (OPC) treated with a high dose of radiation (70 Gy) has an excellent chance to be cured, but the high radiation dose has significant side effects. The goal of this proposal is to evaluate how well a significantly reduced dose of radiation (30 Gy) can control and cure cancer in certain patients with HPV-positive OPC. These patients will be selected based on the level of oxygen in their tumors, as tumors with low levels of oxygen (hypoxia) often do not respond as well to radiation treatment as those with higher levels of oxygen; and in patients without hypoxic tumors, evidence has shown that the reduced dose of radiation may work just as well and without the severe side effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Hypertension affects over half of black adults in the United States – more than any other group – and unhealthy diet is the primary determinant of disparities in hypertension among black adults. While the DASH diet is a proven strategy for lowering blood pressure in black adults, diet disparities are increasing in urban food deserts due to poor access, high cost, and cultural dissonance related to DASH meals. Our proposed clinical trial will establish the efficacy of a scalable, patient-centered solution: dietitian-assisted, DASH grocery delivery via an online, vir- tual grocery store (AmazonFresh) to black adults in urban food deserts; we include a dedicated post-trial obser- vation period to determine facilitators and barriers to sustained effects among this high-risk population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: NARRATIVE BRCA1-BARD1 and BRCA2 are involved in DNA double-strand break repair and replication fork preservation by homology-directed DNA repair (HDR). Our research project strives to elucidate the functions of these factors and their associated HDR partner proteins in the execution of key HDR stages. This is now possible because we have developed robust systems to obtain highly quality protein preparations for mechanistic workup. As such, we are well positioned to leverage our expertise in biochemistry, biophysics, structural biology, and cell biology to fill knowledge gaps regarding HDR mechanisms and regulation in human. The information that will emanate from our work has strong health relevance, as DNA repair deficiency is associated with aging, neurological disorders, infertility, and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: RESEARCH INST OF FOX CHASE CAN CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Management of gastrointestinal stromal tumor has been transformed by the identification of activating mutations in the receptors KIT and PDGFRA, and the clinical application of imatinib mesylate (IM) and other tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs) in the advanced disease setting. The success of these TKIs for advanced GIST has been tempered by the reality that treatment only increases the median time to tumor progression by two years in most patients. This proposal uses a multi-pronged approach to leverage impressive preliminary data towards the goal of delivering improved treatment of GIST, specifically in both preventing and/or overcoming therapeutic resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE: The proposed research study will develop and implement novel methodologies to analyze DNA methylation risk scores (MRS) of time-varying childhood adversity using primary data from a large population- based cohort (the Avon Longitudinal Study of Parents and Children; ALSPAC) and summary statistics from the largest meta-analyses of time-varying childhood adversity and DNAm. Specifically, the proposed research will identify and test a set of epigenetic biomarkers that can be used to quantify prior exposures to childhood adversity and predict future risk for depression. Ultimately, findings from this study will provide a framework for the implementation of time-varying paradigms in MRS studies, as well as highlight novel biological signatures that can be used to explain and predict risk for mental illness across the life course.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Premature birth is a major cause of neonatal morbidity and motility and lung immaturity in these babies is a major cause. Dendritic cells (DC) are critical for surveillance of the lung against threat and we have identified previously underappreciated heterogeneity within the newborn lung dendritic cell compartment. The proposed research will perform a detailed analysis of the newborn dendritic cell compartment, focused on revealing the ontogeny and function of early-life lung DC. These studies will provide a greater understanding of the role of DC in neonatal lung diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative CD4 “helper” T cells are an important part of the immune system, but little is known about what role they play in immune treatments of cancer patients. We have identified CD4 T cells that specifically target cancer cells by recognizing common cancer mutations found in multiple patients. We propose to treat patients by transferring CD4 T cells that recognize this mutation, and in the process learn more about how CD4 T cells might work in fighting cancer.
