IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite an increase in home specimen self-collection for bacterial sexually transmitted infection (STI) screening in studies conducted with diverse populations, and the demonstrated promise of telehealth in managing mental health and improving antiretroviral therapy adherence in people living with HIV, no studies have combined home specimen self-collection with live audio/video (AV) conferencing to deliver motivational interviewing (MI), a client-centered, strengths-based counseling approach. Our sequential explanatory mixed-methods study seeks to explore the feasibility and acceptability of a novel MI-based telehealth intervention to engage sexually active gay, bisexual and other men who have sex with men living with HIV (GBMSM-LWH) in gonorrhea (GC), chlamydia (CT) and syphilis screening. Our intervention is a package of 3 components: (i) a pre-test live AV conferencing session involving an MI-guided discussion to elicit awareness of bacterial STIs and fill any knowledge gaps, bolster the perceived importance of regularly screening for GC, CT and syphilis, and improve self-efficacy for specimen self-collection, (ii) self-collecting at home and returning by mail a finger-stick blood sample (for syphilis testing), a urine sample (for GC and CT testing), a pharyngeal swab (for GC and CT testing) and a rectal swab (for GC and CT testing), and (iii) a post-test live AV conferencing session involving an MI- guided discussion to prepare participants for receiving test results and formulate personalized action plans for seeking treatment (if warranted) and repeat testing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Reductions in kidney blood flow can lead to permanent damage to the kidneys, known as chronic kidney disease, which can progress to complete loss of kidney function and can shorten life span. We propose to investigate whether information about kidney blood flow that we will obtain from contrast enhanced ultrasound will help identify which individuals with chronic kidney disease are at high risk of experiencing progressive loss of kidney function. The high-risk individuals can then be included in future clinical trials to test new treatments for chronic kidney disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Neighborhood context may play an important role in shaping existing inequities in obesity and diabetes. This study leverages a $50 million housing experiment to examine whether low-income adults given support to move to a lower-poverty neighborhood experience reductions in obesity and diabetes risk compared to similar adults not given these moving supports and explores potential mechanisms through which these reductions may occur. It further investigates whether children whose families are given the support to move experience changes in obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE KRASG12D inhibitors are currently entering clinical testing for various malignancies including non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC), but the development of resistance to these treatments—and therefore tumor relapse—is anticipated. To address the need for treatments that will produce long- term responses, we will investigate how resistance in KRASG12D-mutant NSCLC tumors is linked to remodeling of the lung cancer tumor microenvironment (TME). Describing these processes in the TME will provide actionable biomarkers and therapeutic targets in relapsed tumors that will inform the development of future treatments with long-term effectiveness for NSCLC patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The intestinal epithelium houses crucial stem cells in crypts that expand during early development and repair after damage in a process called crypt fission. Intestinal stem cells are sustained by a surrounding mesenchyme called “the niche”; what role the niche plays in mediating crypt fission is unknown. The studies will improve understanding of how interactions between the epithelium and niche sustain proper organ growth in development and repair, and help develop future treatments to diseases such as necrotizing enterocolitis and inflammatory bowel disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Oxidative stress emanating from endogenous sources and genotoxic environmental exposures is a causative agent of DNA damage that is linked to inflammation, age-related diseases and cancer in humans. This proposal will utilize a novel tool to induce singlet oxygen mediated base damage in human cells specifically at telomeres, at endogenous gene promoters or throughout the genome, to study the specific impact of 8-oxoguanine lesion processing on the regulation of transcriptional responses to genotoxic oxidative damage. The project is therefore relevant to understand the crosstalk between repair of oxidative damage and gene expression, and their role in human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project leverages a unique longitudinal cohort of over 6 million individuals to examine the extent to which posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD), a psychiatric disorder that can develop after trauma exposure, is associated with incident type 2 diabetes and poor glycemic control in individuals who developed type 2 diabetes during the study period. This study also will investigate the extent to which associations between PTSD and type 2 diabetes differ across sex, race, and ethnicity. This work has the potential to advance our knowledge about factors that contribute to type 2 diabetes risk and ultimately may have implications for tailoring diabetes-related prevention and intervention efforts for individuals with PTSD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The United States is experiencing a crisis in mental health care, with overcrowding and delayed mental health care in emergency departments (EDs) exacerbated by the COVID-19 pandemic and with differential impacts on vulnerable populations. In this study, I will analyze ED visits for psychiatric care in a large regional health system, developing: 1) a transdiagnostic subtyping system to track trends in patient mixes, 2) machine learning models to predict ED utilization and post-discharge adverse events (suicide attempt, overdose, or psychotic episode), 3) a precision treatment rule for primary ED disposition decisions on adverse psychiatric events. By combining a large observational database with data science methods, this project will provide unique insights into modifiable risk and resilience factors, opportunities for personalized treatment approaches, and will inform the effective delivery of mental health services, contributing to mental health equity for vulnerable populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: 8. PROJECT NARRATIVE Complement may be activated by multiple mechanisms, such as ischemia reperfusion injury or anti-donor antibodies, depositing membrane attack complexes (MACs) on the surface of the endothelial cells (ECs) that line the blood vessels of the graft. Graft ECs internalize MACs, triggering a complex and incompletely understood process that results in expression of IL-15 on the EC surface facing the blood where it can boost the activation of circulating host T lymphocytes and result in graft rejection. In this Exploratory/Development (R21) grant, we propose to elucidate the complex regulation of IL-15 cell surface expression in human ECs (aim 1) and optimize a genetic therapy approach (aim 2) that can be adapted to block this process in human organs undergoing pre-transplant ex vivo machine perfusion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Pulpitis, or inflammation of the dental pulp tissue, is a debilitating painful disease and one of the main causes of invasive dental procedures. In this project, we investigate the roles of neutrophils in sensory afferent injury and pain and the role of sensory neurons in modulating innate immune response in pulpitis. The project is relevant to NIDCR’s mission because of its potential to improve dental health by investigating neuro-immune mechanisms driving dental pain and inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nonsense mediated mRNA decay (NMD) promotes the normal gene expression of unmutated messenger RNAs (mRNAs) and destroys mutated mRNAs that produce potential disease-causing proteins. The exon junction complex (EJC) is one key determinant of whether an mRNA undergoes NMD and contains the NMD factor UPF2 or the central cell-signaling protein AKT, the latter of which is promoted by insulin. This work will build upon this recent finding by defining the molecular mechanisms involved in this process, which is important because NMD and AKT signaling are both dysregulated in human diseases like Fragile X Syndrome, some cancers, and type 1 and type 2 diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Although gabapentin has been increasingly prescribed in the older adults as off-label indication, the potential health effects of gabapentin use on older adults are not well studied. This proposal will investigate the patterns of gabapentin use in older adults, and the healthcare-related outcomes associated with gabapentin use. This study will provide healthcare providers and policymakers with a better understanding of the use and potential health outcomes associated with gabapentin use in older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: This study addresses a critical healthcare need of improving the poor survival outcomes of TNBC by inhibiting tumor expansion, tumor recurrence, and metastasis. Our long-term goal is to translate the dual inhibition of PARP and STAT3 using talazoparib and LLL12B combination as a novel therapeutic approach in both BRCA- mutant and BRCA-proficient TNBC into clinical evaluation. If successful, this novel approach can move the field of TNBC therapy forward and has a potential to improve the survival of patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tobacco use is the top preventable cause of early mortality in schizophrenia, and smoking cessation treatments are significantly less effective in schizophrenia than in the general population. I determined that in schizophrenia, nicotine use is linked to disorganization in a brain network (the Default Mode Network) and used pharmacology and noninvasive neuromodulation to show that manipulating this network temporarily changes craving for nicotine. This project will determine if this network can be changed in an enduring way that leads to decreased nicotine use in schizophrenia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chimeric antigen receptor T-cells (CART) have revolutionized the treatment of relapsed or refractory B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (B-ALL) and improved survival rates in this population. However, CART can cause severe immune dysregulation disorders that we do not fully understand. This proposal will define the mechanistic biology of immune dysregulation disorders occurring post CART and test potential novel therapies for the treatment of these disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Human society is supported by neurobiological specializations that enable advanced social cognition and important behavioral phenomena like cooperation and communication. Nevertheless, a mechanistic description of social cognitive networks remains a distant ambition of neuroscience research, despite the potential to enhance public health and support the diagnosis and treatment of nervous system dysfunction. The proposed career development study aims to address this key research gap by investigating the nervous system of a highly social model organism with a simple and tractable brain, the clonal raider ant.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Exposure to anti-cancer drugs at work is dangerous to the health of nurses who handle these drugs. This research focuses on developing and testing an intervention targeted to increase nurses’ adherence to safe practice guidelines when handling anti-cancer drugs. This research is relevant to public health, because it will help prevent the exposure to anti-cancer drugs for nurses and protect them from the health complications that could result from this exposure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Loneliness and social isolation are strongly linked to indices of healthy brain aging, cognitive decline, and dementia. Reducing loneliness/isolation is a potent strategy to promote healthy brain aging and prevent cognitive decline and Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD). This application forms the basis for an evolving program of research on the translational science of loneliness/isolation and its role in brain aging, with the long-term objective to identify and disseminate evidence-based interventions for loneliness/isolation in later life, including determining the mechanisms that account for improved health outcomes—mental health, cognitive health, and physical health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Individuals who possess a genetic deletion of part of chromosome 22 have smaller brains and are predisposed to multiple neurodevelopmental disorders including intellectual disability and autism. The goal of this work is to study how mitochondrial proteins encoded by genes within the deleted region function during neurodevelopment to establish brain structure and function. This research will define mechanisms underlying neurodevelopmental disorders and provide new avenues for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Merlin protein is notably lost in advanced breast tumor tissues, in particular, those cases with metastases. There are no specific targeted agents for Merlin-deficient tumors (even those of the nervous system). We will test therapeutically translatable strategies to disable invasive, immunosuppressive, and metastatic attributes of Merlin-deficient mammary tumors using multiple model systems of Merlin-deficient breast cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To prevent morbidity and mortality in older women and enable medical advances, the defense mechanisms that protect the female genital tract (FGT) from infection and are impaired with aging need to be identified. This proposed research will investigate defense mechanisms that exist in neutrophils. The identification of targetable mechanisms that improve protection against infections in the FGT will open new pathways for the development of prevention strategies for all women as they age.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Tumor-associated macrophages are major components in the tumor microenvironment and play critical roles in tumor immunosurveillance. This study aims to understand the role of protein tyrosine phosphatases in macrophage-mediated cancer cell phagocytosis and evaluate the antitumor efficacy of targeting inhibitory protein tyrosine phosphatases. Identification of such mechanisms will facilitate the development of effective macrophage-based cancer immunotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: FAM72A is a mammalian protein that helps antibodies to achieve optimal effectiveness by binding an enzyme, UNG2, and promoting antibody "maturation". FAM72A reduces the activity of the enzyme and also promotes its degradation. In this project we will determine whether the inhibition of activity of UNG2 by FAM72A is sufficient for antibody maturation, or it is necessary for UNG2 to be degraded to achieve optimal immune response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Older adults, particularly frail older adults have greatly increased susceptibility to skin disorders and infections. We will investigate how the skin microbiome modulates skin immunity in healthy and unhealthy aging. This work will lay the foundation for modulating the microbiome-immune axis for therapeutic or prophylactic approaches, and identify risk factors for a range of skin disorders in older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Currently used therapeutics for intraocular bacterial infections include antibiotics (which kill organisms) and anti-inflammatory drugs (whose value for these infections is controversial). This proposal will test the utility of blocking key innate immune pathways to eliminate damaging inflammation during intraocular bacterial infections. The proposed experiments are novel, high-impact, translationally relevant, and will identify whether targeting innate immune pathways with antibiotics is a feasible strategy for treating the eye during intraocular infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative High risk forms of acute myeloid leukemia arise when hematopoietic progenitors acquire stem cell-like gene expression programs but the molecular mechanisms underlying these transcriptional changes remain incompletely defined. Recently, I uncovered an essential gene expression program regulated in part by the transcription factor MECOM that drives leukemia and is associated with very poor patient outcomes. Now I seek to define critical co-factors that help regulate the expression of these genes and identify and functionally characterize the indispensable downstream effectors of MECOM signaling in AML to uncover new therapeutic vulnerabilities in high-risk leukemia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The long-term health risks of childhood cancer therapy have been known for decades, yet adherence to lifelong survivorship care is poor and inequitable, and this leads to health disparities. Communication among young adult childhood cancer survivors, parents/caregivers, and clinicians is essential for survivors to learn to manage their care, but it is complex and even more challenging for families who prefer a language other than English. This project will address these gaps by partnering with a community organization to develop, pilot test, and refine the first culturally and linguistically tailored family-centered communication intervention for Latinx young adult childhood cancer survivors and their parents/caregivers, working toward the goal of improving survivorship care in this population at risk for health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE When host white blood cells, called macrophages, are infected or injured, a series of signals may cause the macrophage to commit a form of cellular “suicide” called necroptosis. This cell suicide can promote a response of the human immune system called inflammation. We have discovered a new means by which necroptosis suicide may cause inflammation in the body by causing the dying cell to produce molecules called lipids which drive inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The proposed research seeks to gain a deeper understanding of the genetic programs that regulate the development of specialized areas within the human cerebral cortex. Abnormalities in this process can result in neurodevelopmental disorders including autism spectrum disorder, epilepsy, intellectual disability, and neuropsychiatric diseases. By exploring the mechanisms behind the development of distinct cortical areas, this research has the potential to provide valuable insights into the causes of these disorders and inform the development of new treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATION It seems obvious that when our body is low in energy we will eat, however, it is not known how the sensation of the bodily energy state transforms into the movements of chewing and biting. This interplay of signals reflecting the state of the body and control of muscles and movement that make up behavior is a tightly regulated process, and any decoupling will result in either obesity or eating disorders. Thus, this proposal aims to determine the computations that a simple brain circuit performs to control biting and chewing of food with respect to changes in energy state of the body.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Radiation optic neuropathy (RON) is a devastating complication of radiation-based cancer treatments that can lead to blindness, and there are currently no effective treatments to prevent this. Development of a relevant animal model is essential to better understand this disease. The proposed experiments will both develop an animal model of RON and take the first steps toward novel treatment approaches to reduce blindness and maintain quality of life for radiation-treated cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Clonal hematopoiesis of indeterminate potential (CHIP), which refers to the presence of detectable recurrent genetic mutations in blood cells, is a common condition of aging. CHIP is significantly associated with many diseases with a strong inflammatory component and is also typified by increased and/or dysregulated inflammatory signals. This proposal seeks to understand how the NLRP3 inflammasome, a central regulator of inflammation, promotes Tet2-mutated clonal hematopoiesis and how it may be targeted therapeutically.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Humans and other animals learn the value of foods based on their postingestive effects and thereby develop preferences for the taste of foods that are nutrient-rich and aversions towards those that produce illness. This taste learning process is critical for survival but can become maladaptive in eating disorders and obesity and in clinical settings such as during chemotherapy. This proposal will uncover the brainwide neural representations of flavor and test how those representations are reconfigured by the arrival of postingestive feedback from the gut to ultimately shape our preferences and aversions for specific tastes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Progressive Supranuclear Palsy (PSP) is a severe brain disease of aging that is usually fatal within five to seven years after diagnosis. PSP has no cure, but because it shares a key biological feature with Alzheimer’s disease (AD), accumulation of tau protein in the brain, new treatments developed for AD and other neurodegenerative diseases might be equally or more effective to treat PSP. Building on recent advances in drug development and clinical trial methods, this project will test the ability of three new therapies to slow clinical disease progression and brain volume loss in PSP and will create a large amount of new data to share with other researchers to help develop new PSP diagnostic tests and therapies in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative: ABO(H) blood group antigens were the first human polymorphisms described and corresponding anti-ABO(H) antibodies continue to be the most common immunological barrier to transfusion and transplantation. However, despite their discovery over a century ago, the factors responsible for anti-ABO(H) antibody development remain relatively unknown. Using a series translational studies coupled with a new preclinical model of anti-blood group antibody formation, I will leverage my existing training in transfusion immunology with training in glycobiology to define key factors that influence the overall levels and specificity of anti-ABO(H) antibodies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Social avoidance behavior (SAB) plays a key role in the development and maintenance of internalizing disorders such as Major Depressive Disorder and Social Anxiety Disorder, but is largely resistant to current treatments. IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fetal growth restriction (FGR) is a leading cause of perinatal morbidity and mortality, yet current diagnostic approaches do not allow for individualized risk assessment. We propose to develop individualized models for fetal growth potential and risk of perinatal morbidity using maternal genetic data and a novel explainable artificial intelligence technique. This will generate new insights and lay the groundwork for a shift to personalized fetal growth assessment, assisting clinicians and improving care for women and infants by reducing uncertainty.

PHR: Project Narrative In this proposal we will investigate the in vivo efficacy of an anti-GITR antibody utilizing a novel, engineered Fc domain that induces spontaneous hexamerization upon cell surface binding without inducing immune effector functions. IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Breastfeeding provides health benefits for infants and mothers, but the specific effects of the numerous components of human milk are largely unknown. This project represents a comprehensive genetic and genomic analysis of human milk composition, which will improve our understanding of the genes and biological pathways underlying milk composition and enabling future studies of the health consequences of variation in milk components. This study also leverages multi-omic data integration to assess the effects of milk composition on the infant gut microbiome and infant immune development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Type 2 diabetes (T2D) and cardiovascular diseases (CVD) are serious public health problems that disproportionately affect persons of color and families facing economic hardship. Attention to the role of mental and behavioral health in the prevention of T2D and CVD, prioritization of community-engaged research with diverse stakeholders, and application of dissemination and implementation science are critical to developing significant and innovative preventative interventions to reduce population-level T2D and CVD health disparities. The training and research aims of this K24 proposal leverage Dr. Shomaker's current clinical trials in patient- oriented research on T2D and CVD risk prevention in adolescents and families to train the next generation of clinician investigators in mental/behavioral health and T2D/CVD prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Brain capillaries are the site of nutrient and waste exchange throughout the entire brain. Ubiquitous coverage of brain capillaries allows them to sense brain activity and modulate blood flow. Here I test the novel hypothesis that brain capillary pericytes and endothelial cells are equipped with KATP channels and are electrically coupled allowing them sense hypoxia and regulate blood flow.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Hippocampus is an important brain region for learning and memory, and is frequently impacted in common neurological diseases such as Alzheimer's disease and epilepsy, causing memory impairments. In this project, I propose to use state-of-the-art large-scale electron microscopy imaging techniques followed by reconstruction to map the connectivity between cells in the hippocampus. The results can provide important insights into the neural mechanism of learning and memory in the hippocampus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Failure of transferred immune cells to travel to and infiltrate tumors is a leading cause of failure for adoptive immune cell therapies. Here, we will engineer immune cells to express “homing” molecules to direct these cells to colorectal cancer and overcome this limitation. We will use laboratory models to see if this approach is safe and effective in animal models with the long-term goal of creating a safe and effective therapy for colorectal cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The onset of periodontitis involves an influx of immune cells and a cascade of inflammatory biomolecules in response to a dysbiotic microbiota. Interleukin-37, an anti-inflammatory cytokine, is dysregulated in severe forms of periodontitis; however, its role in the disease’s pathogenesis remains poorly defined. The proposed research will begin to unravel the complex processes that interleukin-37 employs during periodontal inflammation with emphasis on regulatory mechanisms required for its bioactivity in the innate immune response by the periodontium.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) is a growing clinical problem costing the US healthcare system >$30 billion annually by 2030, and characterized by severe exercise intolerance (EI), exertional fatigue, disability, and increased mortality. The proposed research will develop a new MRI-based tool to simultaneously measure skeletal muscle energy metabolism and blood flow, two potentially important contributors to EI in HFpEF, and utilize modern wearable health technology devices to assess EI during activities during daily living. These new tools will also be utilized to examine whether skeletal muscle energy metabolism, blood flow, and activities of daily living improve following administration of a metabolic modulator medicine (sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 inhibitors) in HFpEF patients, the results from which will provide new understanding and possible treatments to improve muscle metabolism and decrease disability in HFpEF patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Narrative Our long-term goal is to produce highly skilled UNC alumni to diversify the biomedical workforce leadership. We have established a comprehensive, personalized, start-to-finish program led by a team of dedicated PhD-trained Directors to develop, recruit, and empower PhD students from groups that are under-represented in the sciences, particularly at key transition points. We implement programs and activities that foster scientific identity, self-efficacy, leadership skills, and a supportive community to equip students to thrive in future scientific careers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A subgroup of bladder cancer patients who are treated with immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICI) develop and succumb to hyperproliferative immune-related adverse events (HP-irAEs), for reasons that are unknown. I discovered a genetic and metabolic signature for HP-irAE that seems to pre-condition the tumor environment for HP-irAE before ICI treatment. By understanding how the genetic and metabolic pathway is differentially activated in tumor and immune cells within the tumor microenvironment, we will be able to better stratify bladder cancer patients before ICI treatment, and identify new opportunities for future drug discovery and precision medicine efforts to minimize HP-irAE in ICI-treated patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Social animals depend on vocal communication for survival in many contexts, and the brain must extract information from acoustic features of calls and communicate with circuits for appropriate behavioral responses. Depending on the call meaning, this processing must occur over time scales needed for guiding various behaviors. The research proposed here tests the overall hypothesis that top-down circuits in the auditory system facilitate vocalization-guided behaviors across contexts, using multiple methods for monitoring and manipulating activity in neurons and ensembles to dissect the circuits involved in driving behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pathological synaptic connectivity is implicated in a number of neurological disorders, including devastating neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's disease. Tools for characterizing the function and synaptic structure of neural circuits in both the healthy and diseased brain are therefore critical for understanding the etiology of such neurological disorders. This proposal thus focuses on developing computational methods for holographic optogenetics to enable large-scale yet precise control and monosynaptic mapping of neural circuits.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed study is a secondary data analysis of administrative hospital discharge data to examine environmental risk factors for pediatric acute respiratory disease. The project will utilize participant data that has already been collected as part of the New York Department of Health Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) dataset. The overall objective of the proposed work is to examine the independent and combined effect of ambient air pollution and neighborhood-level characteristics on pediatric acute respiratory disease hospitalizations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: The Baylor College of Medicine Initiative for Maximizing Student Development (BCM- IMSD) will mentor underrepresented graduate students (UR) in science and medicine to be successful in research-intensive biomedical Ph.D. programs and pursue research and research-related careers. The training includes support for mentoring, original research in a laboratory, science writing and oral presentation skills, analysis of the scientific and medical literature, critical thinking and evaluation, responsible research conduct, and scientific rigor and reproducibility principles. The BCM-IMSD student scholars will develop knowledge and experience in foundational science and clinical and translational research, ask critical questions supplemented with mentorship and training in leadership, teamwork, and communication skills that foster confidence and independence, and serve as role models for UR students, colleagues, and the broader diverse communities about biomedical research and healthcare.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pulmonary Hypertension (PH) is a lethal disease with no effective treatment due to a limited understanding of the underlying mechanisms that cause extreme vascular proliferation and remodeling in the pulmonary circulation. Our data indicate that mitochondrial dysfunction leads to increased expression of Aminopeptidase N in vascular cells - pericytes, causing them to proliferate and contribute to severe vascular remodeling in PH. This discovery has crucial clinical significance, potentially leading to new treatments targeting excessive vascular proliferation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  The incidence of prostate cancer, the most common malignancy and the second leading cause of cancer- related mortality in men in the United States, increases substantially over 50 years of age and in parallel, the prevalence of hip replacement surgery also increases in that age group. Multiparametric magnetic resonance imaging (mpMRI) plays an important role in the diagnosis and disease management of prostate cancer, however, mpMRI is challenging in men with hip implants due to severe image distortions and signal loss. In this study, we will establish a robust mpMRI using our novel acquisition and reconstruction strategy that can be widely implemented across all MR scanners for better management of prostate cancer patients with hip implants and subsequently improve their quality of life and overall survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The ability generalize learned knowledge to different contexts is crucial for effective navigation in the world, and impairments in generalization are hallmarks of many disorders, including autism, schizophrenia, and post-traumatic stress disorder. This research aims to expand our understanding of how the hippocampus, a brain structure critical for contextual learning and memory, can encode task information in various contexts. To investigate how the hippocampus can generalize learning, we will record and perturb hippocampal and downstream structures' activity during learning tasks performed in diverse environments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. Social bonds with friends and loved ones are critical to our physical and mental health; however, we currently lack a basic understanding of the neural circuits that underly this fundamental human behavior. In this study, we use cutting-edge spatial transcriptomics and circuit manipulations to understand how the hippocampus, a region critical for social memory, contributes to social attachment in the monogamous prairie vole. We will test the role of the social neuropeptide oxytocin in this region and uncover new signaling mechanisms underlying hippocampal regulation of behavior, ultimately driving us towards mechanistic therapies for numerous psychiatric disorders that are accompanied by the deterioration of social interactions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Despite multiple clinical trials of immunosuppressive and anti-fibrotic agents, there are no FDA-approved drugs to treat the severe skin fibrosis caused by systemic sclerosis (SSc). Preliminary studies suggest there is a subset of patients who harbor activated fibroblasts and immune cells in their skin, and those patients may be most likely to benefit from immunosuppression. The overarching study goal is to unravel immune cell-fibroblast interactions in SSc and Very Early Onset of Systemic Sclerosis (VEDOSS) to map disease phases where treatment may be of most benefit, test a histology-derived model for classifying patients most likely to improve, and yield insights into the very earliest phases of SSc.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The incidence of acute pulmonary embolism is high (~400,000 cases per year), and residual shortness of breath (Post-PE Syndrome), primarily driven by deconditioning and anxiety, is common. This study will examine whether a specific, daily set of exercise instructions (by text or email) for 8 weeks can decrease disability after hospital discharge for acute pulmonary embolism. By studying this cost-effective intervention, we will learn whether a home-based rehabilitation program could reduce disability, improve quality of life, and decrease healthcare utilization (costs).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Overreliance on habit strategies can be driven by environmental factors, like stress exposure, or genetic disruptions, and contributes to a range of psychiatric conditions, including autism. However, the mechanisms by which stress promotes habit is unknown. This project will identify the cell-type- and subregion-specific effects and interactions of stress and autism-associated genetic alteration on the striatal circuitry that controls habits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sepsis is a major cause of death among immune-compromised cancer patients such as those undergoing chemotherapy. The proposed study investigates acupuncture, a novel modality in management of sepsis, for its role in reducing death or intensive care unit admission among those patients. This research can potentially give us a new tool for how we prevent and treat sepsis, a common treatment-related toxicity in cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: This predoctoral training program is designed to train the next generation biomedical researchers, hence it is directly relevant to public health. The mission of this program is to address the critical need to equip experimental biologists with quantitative and analytical capabilities, effective communication, and leadership skills in the data-rich field of biomedical sciences. Trainees graduating from this program are expected to adopt well to the rapidly changing landscape of big data in experimental research and thrive well as biomedical scientists.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We continue to lack vaccines for many pathogens of public health importance, including herpes simplex virus-2 (HSV-2), human immunodeficiency virus-1 (HIV-1), and tuberculosis (TB). In many infections of public health importance, the mucosal barrier is the portal of pathogen exposure, yet the regulation of mucosal immunity is incompletely understood. Completion of this proposal will provide insight into regulation of the anti-viral mucosal immune response and how pathogen clearance can be achieved while preserving barrier tissue integrity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Less than a third of United States youth meet physical activity guidelines, with lower activity levels found among girls, racial minorities, and those living in rural areas. The proposed research aims to develop, tailor, and examine the impact of a tailored Boys & Girls Clubs (BGC) sport sampling and physical literacy intervention on rural girls’ physical activity levels. This work is significant in that addressing barriers to physical activity and sport via BGC can reduce gender, racial, and geographic disparities in youth activity levels.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative:  Recent work has emphasized the importance of RPE metabolism in retinal function and health. However, little is known about the cell biology of mitochondria and its interaction with other organelles and cytoskeleton network in the RPE. The proposed study aims to employ state-of-the-art methods, including high-speed live-cell imaging to investigate how RPE mitochondrial dynamics and organelle interaction change in health and in disease.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Gulf War Veterans’ Illnesses (GWVI) is a multi-symptom illness that plagues a section of the veterans who were deployed during the Persian Gulf War named as Operation Desert Shield and Desert Storm. The veterans complain of a persistence of gastrointestinal disturbances, chronic fatigue, pain and cognitive defects that has been difficult to manage at the clinics. The goal of this clinical trial is to determine if a Butyrate formulation that consists of butyric acid as calcium and magnesium derivatives in a single oral capsule taken twice a day is effective in increasing the quality of life for veterans with GWI. The secondary outcome will focus on the drug's role in (a) restoring gut microbiome and virome (that have been found altered in GWI veterans),(b) decreasing gastrointestinal disturbances (constipation, diarrhea, pain) (c) decreasing chronic fatigue , (d) decreasing systemic inflammation such a blood levels of proinflammatory cytokines and (d) a decrease in neurocognitive deficiencies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal is relevant to public health because, while many pathologies of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) have long been studied, effective treatments remain elusive. Abnormalities in motoneuron excitability remain the most tightly linked to disease pathogenesis, yet both HYPER- and HYPO-excitability changes have been seen in motoneurons at various disease stages and in multiple lines of ALS mice. The proposed work will investigate how the under-studied hypo-excitability mechanisms contribute to the unstable MN environment, in order to fill an important gap in knowledge and verify a novel drug target for stabilization of motoneuron excitability and prevention of motoneuron death.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Chemical modifications to DNA impact biological function, and when they deviate from the norm, it can lead to disease. This study aims to develop biotechnological methods to precisely map these epigenetic DNA modifications under challenging scenarios, when either sample amount is limited or diverse modifications within a sample are clustered. These methods will advance our understanding of developmental biology and lay the groundwork for future applications in the study of disease progression.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The COVID-19 pandemic has painfully demonstrated that K-12 school safety during a respiratory viral pandemic has a crucial role in community viral transmission control, children’s and teachers’ welfare, and optimal social functioning. With the overall objective of understanding K-12 school experience and safety strategies during the pandemic, we aim to identify and review the current research on the topic by performing a scoping review (Aim 1); to examine school stakeholder (individuals-level) and school administrative (institutional-level) perceptions, concerns, and experience through stakeholder longitudinal surveys (Aim 2A) and administrator interviews (Aim 2B); to examine the implementation outcomes of an institutional-level Bluetooth Digital Contact Tracing intervention through questionnaires and focus group interviews (Aim 3). With COVID-19 unlikely to vanish, and schools constantly threatened by respiratory viruses, the proposed study offers holistic insights into how to effectively keep schools safe during the current and future pandemics.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In light of unsettlingly high rates of adverse newborn outcomes – such as perinatal mortality, low birthweight, and preterm birth – in the United States, evidence-based approaches to improve maternity care are vital. Medicaid provider incentives for provision of immediate postpartum long-acting reversible contraception and antepartum fetal surveillance offer two potential strategies to enhance outcomes via improvements in birth spacing and early detection of fetal distress, respectively. In the absence of a robust evidence base, the proposed research will rigorously estimate the impact of each strategy on newborn outcomes to inform data- driven clinical practice around postpartum contraception and antepartum surveillance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Myelin is essential for proper neuronal function and health, and disruption of myelin leads to neurological symptoms in diseases such as multiple sclerosis and peripheral neuropathies. Mounting evidence has demonstrated that the endocannabinoid system can serve as a potential target for future therapeutics, through its role in regulating myelination. This proposal will uncover the specific roles of the cannabinoid receptors in the biology of the cells that make myelin, using genetic and pharmacological approaches as well as innovative photopharmacological tools in zebrafish.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The proposed project is relevant to Veterans’ health by addressing two important conditions that affect Veterans: diabetes and viral infections. Existing research resources from the Million Veteran Program (MVP) will be used to identify relationships between genetic differences and risk of diabetes and infections. New information will be obtained from this existing genetic data that will help identify new factors related to diabetes and infections, including COVID-19. These data can then be used by other researchers in the future. This study will lead to new ways to understand risk for diabetes and infections in Veterans, and will inform future studies of new ways to prevent and treat these conditions.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: This proposal is relevant to Veterans because it is the first study of a new treatment to help Veterans struggling with mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI), impulsivity and [suicidal ideation]. These three conditions have been shown to be linked [and all are associated with problems functioning]. First, this study will make sure the new treatment, intermittent theta burst stimulation (iTBS), which involves a high-powered magnet placed directly on the forehead, is safe and easy for Veterans to tolerate. Second, this project will also test to see if the treatment improves Veteran community functioning, [lessens suicidal ideation] and lessens impulsivity. Finally, Veterans enrolled in the study will get brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) before and after the treatment to determine how iTBS changes Veterans’ brain connectivity to make them function better. Completing this research will improve Veterans’ health through the development of a new treatment for impulsivity and suicidality following mTBI.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Plant-based nitrates metabolize to bioactive nitrite and to putative capacity to enhance skeletal muscle mitochondrial respiration. We propose to study benefits of nitrate-rich beetroot juice to improve physical function in Veterans afflicted with long COVID. In a randomized, placebo- controlled trial, a two-week regimen of daily beetroot juice is used in combination with physical therapy. Trial endpoints include novel indices of fatigability and walking efficiency as well as peak oxygen utilization (VO2), VO2 at anaerobic threshold, 6-min walk distance, short physical performance battery, and pulmonary function. Skeletal muscle respiration is also assessed. Overall, this proposal is highly significant as it addresses a major Veteran healthcare challenge, and aligns with the Rehabilitation Research and Development’s mission to maximize Veterans’ functional independence, quality of life and participation in their lives and community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Enamel formation is a staged process principally involving secretory and maturation-stages, each associated with major changes in gene expression and cellular function, that results in an architecturally and mechanically complex hydroxyapatite-based bioceramic material devoid of most of the organic material that is essential in its making. Cellular activities that define the maturation-stage of amelogenesis include calcium, bicarbonate, chloride, proton and phosphate transport, and the strict control of intracellular and extracellular pH. This application seeks to fully understand the cellular activities that regulate and maintain an enamel extracellular matrix pH conducive to enamel mineralization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC) is a neurogenetic disorder with high rates of epilepsy and autism spectrum disorder due to dysregulation of the mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) pathway. We have preliminary data suggesting that the transcription factor, EGR1, is down-regulated downstream of mTOR dysregulation in certain types of pyramidal neurons with loss of TSC2. We propose to characterize the mechanisms and consequences of this interaction in human neurons derived from induced pluripotent stem cells from patients with TSC, which will provide novel insight into the pathways underlying neurological symptoms in TSC. !

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sex specific social interactions are a fundamental feature of the human experience and are crucial for individual and societal well-being. Moreover, several neuropsychiatric disorders such as Autism, Schizophrenia and Depression are characterized by sex differences in their prevalence, age of onset and severity. Understanding the molecular and neural circuit basis for the development and expression of behavioral sex- specificity is thus critical to understanding social behavior in normal and pathological contexts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement. Insulin secretion is impaired in both major forms of diabetes, afflicting > 25 million Americans. This project investigates novel biochemical mechanisms of glucose-stimulated insulin secretion and potential therapeutic targets within those pathways.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Peripheral nerve diseases are very common and cause debilitating symptoms that include muscular weakness and atrophy, joint deformities, pain and sensory disturbances. We study the cells that form myelin in peripheral nerves, and showed that they need proteins called laminins, Rac1, Yap and Taz to myelinate. Here we seek to understand how these molecules work during myelination and if they are altered in human peripheral neuropathies, with the goal to promote re-myelination in patients.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Advancements in neurotechnology are shaping the future of medical care for those suffering from neurological illness, disease, and injury. Unfortunately, it can take decades to bring such advances from the benchtop to the bedside in service of our Veterans. Translational success of implantable neurotechnology is constrained by the time, money, and personnel resources required to transition from benchtop demonstrations to preclinical and clinical evaluation of implanted medical devices. Development ecosystems are either highly flexible and necessitate significant redesigns before moving to final form; or highly specialized and prematurely limit the integration of new technologies. Here, we create an ideal solution that would provide maximal flexibility, simple integration of new components, and require minimal redesign for translation to preclinical and clinical studies. The central focus of this research program is to create a hardware and software platform that reduces the cost, time, and risk of device development, while maintaining component and design flexibility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our goal is to improve music and speech perception for cochlear implant users. Presently, most cochlear implants discard the temporal fine structure of sound, which is information that is widely believed to contribute to both music and speech perception. The proposed work examines perceptual and physiological changes that occur once this information is provided to cochlear implant users in a clear and consistent manner.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: WINIFRED MASTERSON BURKE MED RES INST
PHR: Motor circuits such as corticospinal circuits are essential for skilled movement, and spinal interneurons mediate the information to motor neurons. In humans, interruption of motor circuits caused by spinal cord injury, stroke, or other disorders results in severe deficits in most fine motor skills. Therefore, understanding the cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying motor circuits including spinal interneurons will provide important information for developing new therapeutic avenues for addressing diseases and injuries related to motor or spinal circuits in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Severe congenital heart defects like transposition of the great arteries are common birth defects requiring corrective newborn open heart surgery. With medical and surgical advancements, survival has improved for these children, though they continue to face significant neurodevelopmental challenges across the lifespan as a result of early abnormalities in the heart-brain connection. In this proposal we aim to understand the heart- brain connection beginning before birth and in the immediate newborn period in order to identify interventions that can optimize neurodevelopmental outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative The ability to use sensory information to guide our actions is crucial for survival, yet we know remarkably little about the underlying brain mechanisms. This project aims to reveal a conceptual model for how sensory learning influences the activity of motor command circuits to guide behavior. These results will further our understanding of how learning influences the development of sensory-driven motor behaviors relevant in both health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Of the 1.4 million annual visits to US emergency departments (EDs) for acute heart failure (AHF), nearly 90% lead to hospitalization, although many stable patients can be discharged from the ED and continue to recover at home. This proposal seeks to develop novel, patient-centered strategies to optimize hospitalization decisions for AHF, building upon extensive work to derive evidence-based clinical risk scores. My aims are to examine patient and clinician perspectives to better understand reasons for hospitalization, compare outcomes between low-risk patients who are hospitalized to those who are discharged from the ED, and pilot the implementation of a clinical decision support tool that encourages ED clinicians to perform comprehensive risk stratification for patients with AHF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Social and economic stressors are increasingly recognized as important factors that shape the development of cardiovascular disease particularly among Latinos, who experience a disproportionate burden of these factors across the life course. However, the pathways through which social and economic stressors affect the biological pathways related to health disparities are not fully understood, particularly at the cellular level, and little research to date has examined how these factors impact cardiovascular markers early in the life course. We propose to address these gaps by examining how social and economic stressors experienced in childhood impact DNA methylation (e.g. DNA methylation age, genome-wide methylation) and mtDNA damage, among a diverse sample of Latino youth living in the US, as well as how these factors may impact their cardiometabolic health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on characterizing poorly understood brain diseases caused by the immune system, known as autoimmune encephalopathies, through identification and validation of new antibodies as disease biomarkers. Once this work has been completed, these biomarkers have the potential to be informative in clinical practice for early diagnosis and immune treatment decisions, and disease mechanism research. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH's mission that pertains to reducing illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Novel deep learning frameworks for predicting nucleosome-binding proteins Nucleosome-binding proteins play an important role in development and organogenesis, but the experimental techniques used to identify them are insensitive, expensive or time consuming. This proposal aims to develop a novel two-stage transfer learning framework to predict these proteins by combining sequence and structural information. It will also implement a new transfer learning-continual learning framework that not only predicts the nucleosome binders in a species-specific manner, but also accommodates progressively available nucleosome- protein interaction data without forgetting previously learned knowledge.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Relevance: Eukaryotic parasites such as N. fowleri, “the brain-eating amoeba”, are responsible for devastating central nervous system (CNS) infections. Lack of effective therapies results in nearly 100% fatality and novel clinical approaches are needed. There is evidence that the host immune response can slow or prevent fatal disease, and yet this fails in patients. We will determine how immune responses against extracellular parasites can be tuned for maximal efficacy within the CNS, while preserving neurological function. Using antibody isotype variants we will generate a clinically relevant understanding of how antibodies can be target CNS parasites for destruction and lay the groundwork for identifying potential immunotherapeutic options for treatment of CNS parasitic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Stroke is the leading cause of adult disability and no current treatments exist beyond physical therapy. This proposal explores the development of a biomaterial based therapy to promote recovery after stroke. The material promotes revascularization and synapse formation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS RIO GRANDE VALLEY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The brain White Matter (WM) and its characteristic component myelin have emerged as active participants of the brain plasticity necessary for high order functions including learning and memory; consequently, WM/myelin disruption cause multiple neurological issues and it is believed to underly neurodevelopmental conditions includ- ing Learning Disabilities (LD). To discover the links between subnormal learning and defective myelin, I use mouse models of Costello Syndrome (CS), a neurodevelopmental disease caused by mutations in a single gene (HRas), in which most patients present with LD in correlation with WM/myelin abnormalities. Preliminary results indicate that myelin defects caused by a CS mutation negatively impact the ability of mice to learn fine motor skills; therefore, this project aims to describe cellular, molecular, and brain connectivity abnormalities underlying subnormal learning.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Cardiac arrest is an important cause of mortality and poor neurological outcome in children, with approximately 16,000 arrests occurring each year in the US. Unfortunately, there are currently no drugs available in the United States to improve outcome and quality of life following cardiac arrest in children. The proposed studies will characterize the response of childhood brain to cardiac arrest and demonstrate that puberty provides insights into enhanced recovery observed in children compared to adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative This project will examine the effects of a large-scale poverty reduction program on health risk among older and younger adults in rural Malawi. It extends a longitudinal randomized control trial of a national cash transfer program and integrates new measures of infection, diseases and cognitive capacity to identify the biological and behavioral pathways through which poverty affects health and mortality risk. Results will contribute to knowledge on the structural, biological and behavioral pathways that affect healthy well-being at two points in the life-cycle, with implications for public policies designed to address the multi-faceted consequences of poverty.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Public Health Significance Currently, there are approximately 50,000 individuals living with upper limb loss in the US. Upper extremity amputations most commonly occur in working age adults as a result of trauma, and frequently affect the dominant extremity, leading to significant impacts on activities of daily living. Despite the enormous investment of resources in the development of new multi-articulated upper limb prosthetics, a large proportion (35-45%) of upper extremity amputees discontinue use of their prosthesis, mainly due to limited functionality and usability, and there is a significant unmet need to develop better technological solutions to improve function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Over 100,000 Acute Kidney Injury (AKI) patients receive continuous renal replacement therapy in the US each year. We are developing a new blood filter with that will operate for at least seven days without anticoagulation. The use of the new blood filter will improve AKI patient outcomes while reducing the complexity, costs, and complications associated with continuous renal replacement therapy with anticoagulation therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The collective migration of epithelial cells plays key roles in tissue morphogenesis, intestinal turnover, wound repair, and metastasis. For an epithelium to migrate, the cell migration machinery that powers each cell’s movement must become aligned across the tissue. The goal of this research is to use the genetic tractability of fruit flies to determine :(1) how epithelial cells become organized for collective motility, and (2) how this motility can be harnessed to structure extracellular matrix over which the cells migrate.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Binocular vision impairments are generally associated with a number of functional deficits that can severely impact the quality of life of the patients in their everyday life, affecting simple yet fundamental everyday actions like walking, grasping an object or reading and also adversely impact socio-economic opportunities. The proposed study is basic science research into the mechanisms of sensory and motor binocular vision impairment and is relevant to Public Health for three primary reasons: 1) it aims to provide a proof of concept for translating eye tracking and 3D stereo technology into the clinical practice related to binocular visual dysfunction including oculomotor deficits (such as strabismus and vergence insufficiency) and perceptual deficits (such as amblyopia, diplopia, stereo blindness and suppression); 2) it seeks to develop effective quantitative methodologies for the measurement of binocular impairments, both with synthetic stimuli and in natural environments and to quantify the distribution of depth information across the visual field in healthy and impaired visual systems; and 3) it seeks to develop the evidence base for non-invasive rehabilitation for binocular eye alignment disorders, with the aim of preventing the development and progression of binocular visual dysfunction and, when intervention is required, to augment existing therapies with rehabilitation to assist in the maintenance of binocular oculomotor control.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: abundance of genome sequence data, dissecting how genetic variation controls phenotypic diversity and disease predisposition remains challenging. This study employs high-throughput genome editing and phenotyping assays to uncover functional genetic variants across a panel of genetically and ecologically diverse wild isolates of budding yeast. This work will identify functional variants and how they interact with each other, the environment and genetic background, to give rise to complex multigenic traits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Older adults are currently the fastest growing group of cannabis users in the U.S, and they are more likely to use cannabis for medicinal purposes (e.g., pain, trouble sleeping, depression/anxiety) than for recreational purposes, despite having little data to guide their decisions about what type of product to use. This project will utilize a patient-centered observational design to recruit and assess older adults who are interested in using cannabis compared to a control group who is not interested in cannabis use. We will gather data on both the beneficial and harmful effects of edible cannabis of varying composition (THC-only vs. CBD-only vs. THC+CBD), and will examine the process by which older adult cannabis users decide what type of cannabis product they prefer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Undergraduate research experience improves retention of underrepresented students in STEM disciplines, but most research programs target undergraduates in their sophomore year, leaving a group of students who do not want research experiences until later in their training with few options. The Building Research Independence by Developing Goals and Hands-on Experiences (BRIDGE) program addresses this barrier by providing paid summer research experience, professional development opportunities, and mentoring to underrepresented students with no prior research experience going into their senior year. Importantly, the BRIDGE program will increase diversity in biomedical fields.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative DIPG is one of the most lethal pediatric brain cancers, affecting children aged 5-9 yrs old, without a current cure or significant improvement in the efficacy of treatment over the past 3+ decades. With the promise of improving quality of life, improving the safety of radiation, or increasing length of survival for children with DIPG, nanoparticle-enhanced radiation therapy first requires validation in a pre-clinical DIPG model, and additional mechanistic investigation. The included project proposal is focused on the pre-clinical development and refinement of this technique.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Healthy aging is associated with a striking paradox: As adults age, they typically have better control over their emotions while also simultaneously experiencing decline in cognitive functions and brain systems that have been associated with emotion regulation. This study will investigate the brain basis of emotion regulation in middle- and older-age adults, and how a history of depression might impact the typical pattern of age-related improvement in emotional control. Ultimately, the proposed research will help to improve quality of life for healthy older adults, while also providing treatment targets to prevent recurrence of depression for those with a depression history.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The University of Washington Developmental AIDS Research Center for Mental Health, based in Seattle, catalyzes new mental health and HIV research and develops new research leaders across the multidisciplinary spectrum of clinical, epidemiologic, statistical, behavioral, and implementation science expertise necessary to bend the curve of the global HIV epidemic. Our team blends expertise in HIV prevention, care and treatment, management of complex patients with HIV and co-morbidities, models of mental health care delivery in primary care, user-centered design for effective deployment of evidence-based psychological interventions in diverse care settings, care for co-morbid traumatic stress and substance use disorders, management of co-occurring mental disorders and other medical conditions, and rigorous quantitative methods for social science research. We bring experience in the conduct of impactful research with partners in regional and global HIV care settings and through the work of our four Cores we aim to catalyze and support innovative and impactful research to curb the HIV epidemic, with a focus on integrated intervention strategies that address HIV and mental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Breast cancer patients undergoing trastuzumab treatment are at risk of heart function decline or heart failure symptoms, but it is unknown if, when, and for how long cardiovascular protective strategies, e.g. with a beta- blocker, could help. This study randomly assigns those taking curative-intent trastuzumab to the beta-blocker carvedilol—either when significant heart function decline or subtle early signs of heart injury (either by elevation of a cardiac blood biomarker, i.e. cardiac troponin, or by an abnormal heart ultrasound marker, i.e. global longitudinal strain) are noted, or preventatively before beginning trastuzumab therapy. This study will further randomly assign those patients on carvedilol to either discontinuation at the end of trastuzumab therapy or continuation for another year, providing much needed clinical trial data on what the best strategy (“tactic”) for those at risk of cardiotoxicity with trastuzumab therapy is.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Optic neuropathies due to heritable diseases, glaucoma, trauma or inflammation are a major cause of blindness in humans, but no effective treatments exist for the vision impairment that occurs with them. The goal of this project is to advance the speed and efficiency of research to improve retinal ganglion cell function, the cells damaged with these diseases, by developing a new nonhuman primate model of autosomal dominant optic neuropathy. This new and better animal model will speed the development and testing of innovative therapies by our team and others that will reduce the morbidity caused by optic neuropathies in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Many biomedical researchers use high-throughput DNA sequencing to study human disease and biology, and to do so they rely heavily on the human genome sequence and its annotated genes. The analysis of these very large, complex sequence data sets requires highly sophisticated, efficient software that can assemble DNA fragments to reconstruct a genome or assemble RNA sequences to identify genes and gene isoforms. This project will develop new algorithms, software, and data that will provide researchers with the necessary tools to address relevant biological questions in humans and a wide range of other species.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Breast MRI has a high false positive rate which is a clinical concern that has questioned its use in many breast indications. As a result, significant opportunities exist to augment the diagnostic information derived from breast MR, especially if new data were generated that is coregistered with the MR image volume and seamlessly acquired during the same procedure with adjunctive technology that is relatively low in cost. The proposed project will develop an innovative multi-modality breast imaging platform that performs simultaneous Microwave and Magnetic Resonance Imaging (sMMRI) to address this need. If the studies proposed are successful, a new multi-modality breast imaging system will be realized by the end of requested funding period that is ready for use in larger statistically-powered clinical studies of its diagnostic performance in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project will investigate novel diagnostic methods and potential treatment in animal models of twp macular degenerations: the RPE mitochondrial dysfunction model, and the Doyne Honeycomb Retinal Dystrophy model. As a result of this proposal, novel optical methods will be available for translation to diagnose retinal degenerations in human patients, including inherited and age-related macular degeneration (AMD). This study will also continue to lay a foundation for novel locally, light-activated drug delivery in human ocular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) has a notoriously high death rate due to a lack of early detection and early intervention. We identified CCL9 as new downstream of KrasG12D-mediated acinar-to-ductal metaplasia (ADM), the initial step of PDAC development. We will dissect the mechanisms of KrasG12D/CCL9 axis in regulating pancreatic ADM using 3D organoid cultures, and verify them in mouse models. Outcomes from this study will provide the essential groundwork for future studies on the potential use of CCL15, the human orthologue of CCL9, as one of the biomarkers for early detection in the clinic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Regenerative medicine in the retina is an attractive solution for improving quality of life in patients affected by neurodegenerative diseases and depends on our knowledge of retinal development. Polycomb-group (PcG) complexes are evolutionarily conserved, powerful epigenetic machineries that regulate cell-fate decisions, and here, we identified retinal multipotency genes as novel targets of the PcG protein BCOR. Decoding how BCOR epigenetically regulates retinal neurogenesis may have wide implications for new targets in regenerative strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Organ transplantation is a life saving therapy for individuals with end stage organ failure, but all transplants eventually fail due to a process called chronic allograft rejection. In this research proposal, we plan to evaluate the function of Neuropilin-2, which may serve as a novel co-inhibitory receptor to regulate the alloimmune response and thus prevent transplant rejection. We will perform in-depth mechanistic studies addressing the molecular basis for its function in immunity and we will determine if its biology can be a basis for future therapeutic development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This project responds to the research need of more diverse cohorts, more participants, more variables, and more occasions of measurement to advance progress in the epidemiology of cognitive resilience and decline. We will develop advanced models for causal mediation analysis based on Bayesian machine learning approaches along with computationally efficient and user-friendly R packages to integrate rich longitudinal data on exposures and health markers and account for biases inherent in observational data from life-course studies. The proposed approaches will enable causal inference on joint exposure effects and time-to-event and longitudinal mediators to inform policy for environmental exposures and cardiovascular health in mid and late life to prevent Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Disorders in diverse populations.
