IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE: Vertebrate vision starts with a photochemical isomerization reaction involving proteins known as visual pigments that contain retinaldehyde as their chromophore. Despite the fundamental nature of the process and its relevance to human physiology and disease, many of its properties remain poorly understood. Here, we employ a host of new approaches enabled by the development of novel experimental tools to address critical questions pertaining to the functioning of the visual pigments as well as their abnormalities in retinopathies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The research and training in this application will provide additional training and experience applying advanced intensive longitudinal statistical techniques to the study of aging and dementia. Outcomes in aging and Alzheimer disease (AD) research rely critically on the measurement of cognitive change and the innovative approaches described herein will provide novel and more sensitive analyses of longitudinal change. Ultimately, we will provide new cognitive endpoints for use in AD studies which will help establish the efficacy of candidate treatments.

PHR: NARRATIVE The goal of this project is to develop a new instrument (w-DiFC) for optically detecting and counting rare circulating tumor cells continuously and non-invasively in awake, freely-moving mice. We will use this instrument to study CTCs during metastasis development and in response to radiation therapy in mouse models of cancer. We expect that w-DiFC will provide unique insights into metastasis biology and response to anti-cancer therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Project Narrative (Public Health Relevance Statement): Huntingtin’s disease (HD) is based on a mutation in a gene called huntingtin. Huntington’s disease is inherited as autosomal dominant, which means that an affected parent would have a 50:50 chance of passing the gene to a child. All who inherit the mutation will eventually develop the disease, with impaired cognition (dementia), depression and apathy, and abnormal movements. Patients will need to receive long-term skilled nursing for many years. We discovered an advanced, modified small interfering RNA that can lower the mutant huntingtin that causes HD, setting the stage for this CREATE proposal. Advantages of this therapeutic are long-term activity (about six months) to lower huntingtin after a single injection into cerebrospinal fluid and, critically, widespread distribution and neuronal uptake over the entire non-human primate brain. Our discoveries will set the stage for a new paradigm of therapeutics for an array of neurological diseases, including those with increased numbers of repeats of sequences in genes, such as HD, other CAG repeat expansions, and brain diseases with dementia and movement problems (C9ORF based amyotrophic lateral sclerosis and frontal-temporal dementia). Our program has public health relevance. Diseases marked by dementia and severe movement limitations are expensive to society, by requiring high level nursing care. Patients are removed from the active work force, thus lowering their earning capacity. These diseases reduce the gross national product. The stress on public health for HD is that the disease affects individuals in the prime of their lives – magnifying the economic burden while intensifying family hardship. Reversing HD or delaying its onset will have economic as well as health benefits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE Eating disorders have one of the highest mortality rates of any mental illness and affect an estimated half million American children and adolescents. Yet, it is exceptionally difficult for parents to find effective treatment for this condition as only 66 providers are certified to provide Family-Based Treatment, considered the most effective outpatient treatment for adolescent restrictive eating disorders. This study will determine whether a novel intervention that uses FBT strategies, Family Based Treatment for Primary Care (FBT-PC), designed for delivery by a primary care provider in the primary care setting, is feasible and could potentially address some of the widespread issues with access to evidence-based treatment for restrictive eating disorders in children and adolescents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The anterior cingulate cortex (ACC) is necessary for emotional processing and social cognition, but how it encodes stimuli relevant to both processes is unknown. This proposal will provide much needed insight into how distinct neural representations are embedded within ACC excitatory and inhibitory subcircuits, and how this impacts encoding of diverse stimuli and cognitive function in rodents. This work contributes to our understanding of how the cortex encodes information across diverse contexts and provides insight into the complexity of neural processes involved in anxiety and social behavior.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative West Africa is highly burdened with several vector-borne diseases, especially malaria, yet have very little research capacity, therefore, this training program offers the chance for a multi-site training of PhD and junior scientists/faculty who will become future research leaders. The proposed program will lead to the building and strengthening of local investigator capacity. Successful malaria and other vector-borne diseases control needs capacity building in disease endemic countries to establish a cadre of local scientists who can address the ongoing and evolving challenges in vector-borne diseases and control.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Clinically used anesthetics primarily act upon GABAA receptors in the central nervous system to achieve hypnosis, amnesia and analgesia but they also induce profound changes in peripheral physiology. It has been long assumed that these peripheral physiological effects were mediated by neural outflow from the central nervous system but many peripheral tissues have been found to express GABAA receptors that can be directly modulated by GABAergic anesthetics. An understanding of GABAergic anesthetics’ functional effects on peripheral organs will not only allow mitigation of detrimental physiological changes during anesthesia but will identify novel therapeutic targets for hypertension, bronchoconstriction and immune disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative: The proposed research aims to develop, translate, and validate innovative in-vivo imaging technologies to improve imaging and studying the development of the human fetal brain before birth. The technology will enable and improve studies on the development of the brain in fetuses with congenital disorders or fetuses at risk of having neurodevelopmental issues later in life. This in-turn is expected to result in timely and more effective treatments and therapeutic interventions that will lead to vastly improved patient outcomes in both the short- and long-term, effectively reducing the burden of human disabilities arising from congenital disorders.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: POST-TRANSLATIONAL MODIFICATION OF CX43 REGULATES MYOMETRIAL QUIESCENCE Preterm labor leads to preterm delivery of an underdeveloped fetus in 50% of cases and there are no FDA-approved medications available to prevent preterm delivery. The research planned in this application will employ tissues and cells from pregnant women. We will examine the role of endogenous nitric oxide, which relaxes the muscle of the term, but not preterm human uterus, in regulating the formation of gap junctions that couple the tissue electrically and coordinate labor contractions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: While most older adults exhibit cognitive decline as they age, there are exceptions to this rule; certain elderly individuals actually show no age-related decrease in memory. Based on our previous research with a group of these remarkable older adults, we hypothesize that a motivation to engage with, rather than withdraw from, high arousal states associated with challenging tasks is an important protective factor in aging, including in people with Preclinical AD. In the proposed research we will examine neural, physiological, and motivational patterns associated with persistence in the face of challenge, in order to identify potential biomarkers of successful aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Social virtual reality has the potential to improve not only the treatment of pain and other burdensome symptoms in older hospitalized patients, but also the overall experience of hospitalization. The planned study aims to establish the feasibility, acceptability and usability of SVR; these data will support a future R01 application. Given documented high rates of trauma-related pain we target older adult trauma patients. However, in the long term we expect this type of intervention will have broad utility for other populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative / Relevance The role of anti-aging protein Klotho in neurodegeneration and impaired cognition is poorly understood. The proposed research will determine who are the mediators of the effects of physical exercise at gene and cell level in brain the role of Klotho and how the Choroid Plexus epithelial cells facilitate the communications between peripheral muscles and brain through Blood CSF Barrier. We will investigate the role of Klotho using mice with global deletion of Klotho, complex mice expressing human APP expressing one only allele of Klotho, and procedures to isolate and profile extracellular vesicles, primarily exosomes, from plasma and CSF. The in vitro models proposed will address the question if, and how the aging brain with lower expression of Klotho, and the aging muscles with lower Klotho in exosomes released in response to physical exercise affect the brain function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE This study addresses a high-priority public health need by leveraging technology to reduce distress for family members caring for those with moderate to late stage Alzheimer's disease or a related dementia. The proposed study tests the feasibility, acceptability and efficacy of the video-conference-based Tele-STELLA intervention, using a novel dissemination vehicle, across three sites (Oregon, Kentucky and Georgia). The overarching goal is to increase access to Tele-STELLA, which has the potential to help reduce the stress of the 16 million care partners in the US providing care for a family member with dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE People living with substance use disorders and people from racial and ethnic minority groups make up a disproportionate share of new HIV infections in the United States, and once diagnosed, they are less likely to achieve and maintain viral suppression. These disparities reflect complex social and structural determinants of health, which can be addressed by existing medical and social services only if they are accessible, culturally appropriate, and delivered to patients when and where they are needed. This project will test the effectiveness of a combination of strategies, including an evidence-based mobile health app and peer mentoring, that can be integrated into an HIV clinical practice to improve viral suppression and retention in care for vulnerable patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative SLC9 family of membrane transporters play key roles in pH and salt homeostasis in all living cells and genetic mutations in these proteins have been linked to a variety of pathological conditions such as epilepsies, autism, digestive disorders, male infertility, etc. In this proposal we will determine high resolution structures and investigate functional mechanisms of a unique SLC9 family member, SLC9C1. This will advance our understanding of how this protein is regulated by physical and chemical stimuli and guide developments of new intervention strategies to treat pathophysiological conditions arising from disfunction of these proteins.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The proportion of the US population aged 65 years and older and the number of aged minorities is increasing rapidly; with this demographic shift, significant racial/ethnic disparities remain in age-related conditions such as cognitive impairment, Alzheimer’s Disease, physical disability, and frailty. There is a great need to ensure that the research workforce in aging is representative of the US population. The Hopkins USTAR will provide mentored research experiences, research education, and career development skills in MSTEM areas related to research in aging for underrepresented undergraduates who are interested in research careers in health disparities and minority aging as it relates to age-related diseases.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative This project will generate evidence on the process of empowerment and its effects on sexual and reproductive health behaviors for boys and girls as they transition from very young adolescence to young adulthood. Programs to encourage empowered decision-making can have a significant impact during this critical developmental time-period, leading to improved life- long outcomes, but there is currently little research conducted on empowerment in this age group. Project results can directly inform interventions that increasingly aim to empower girls, engage with boys, and address harmful gender norms.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hyperpolarized MR is an emerging molecular imaging method to monitor enzymatic conversions through key, previously-inaccessible biochemical pathways. In this renewal project, this center aims to collaboratively develop new technology with broad geographic and scientific diversity to advance this field in order to better identify and understand human disease and to translate and disseminate these techniques for new clinical trials and ultimately improved patient care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project will provide a detailed understanding of how prostate tumors at the cellular level appear on macroscopic imaging by examining post-surgical prostate tissue samples aligned with clinical MRI scans. We will develop computational algorithms that recognize patterns in MRI scans (i.e. radio-pathomics), which can then be applied to patients to more fully understand the status of prostate tumors prior to surgery and during treatment. We expect that clinical decision-making will improve dramatically as a complete picture of pathomic features underlying prostate cancer with high metastatic potential emerges from this proposal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to examine the influence of contextual-level neighborhood characteristics and person-specific neighborhood experiences on trajectories of cognitive aging and Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias. The study will also examine neighborhood factors influencing cognitive health disparities. The expected outcomes will guide sustainable behavioral interventions and population-level interventions to promote cognitive health especially among vulnerable populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hematopoietic stem cell (HSC) transplantation is a potential cure for several malignant and non-malignant blood disorders. However, delayed/impaired hematopoietic reconstitution due to myeloablative conditioning induced bone marrow damage, and limited availability of donor HSC often causes fatal complications. This project seeks to understand how myeloablative stress-induced alternation of NPY signals in the bone marrow contributes to hematopoietic defects after transplantation, and whether modulating NPY signaling can improve HSC transplantation efficacy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative: This study aims to explore some of the fundamental cellular mechanisms that underlie human language using advanced micro-electrode recording, neurophysiologic and computational techniques. Studying these processes is essential to many contemporary theories in neurolinguistics and will provide an important new framework for investigating higher-cognitive processes in humans. This proposed research has the potential to advance not only our understanding of core linguistic processes at the basic cellular level, but also our understanding of how language may be impaired in disorders such as dyslexia, aphasia or autism spectrum disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: There is a tremendous need for the discovery of new pathways of energy metabolism to address the growing burden of obesity and type 2 diabetes. This project is relevant to public health because our work may lead to therapeutics that reduce the burden of obesity and type 2 diabetes in people’s health and improve their quality of life. This proposal will uncover the regulation and function of a new bioactive lipid pathway that regulates energy expenditure.

PHR: Project Narrative: Parkinson’s Disease Dementia and Dementia with Lewy Bodies are defined by aggregates of the protein alpha-synuclein. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Attitude toward advance directive (AD) and AD completion are key factors affecting end-of-life (EOL) care among older Americans, especially older Chinese Americans. Although Chinese Americans are one of the largest and fastest growing older minority populations, research aims to understand key factors associated with attitude toward AD and AD completion among this population remains lacking, leaving a critical gap in the minority aging literature and contributing to unsatistfactory EOL care among older Chinese Americans. Therefore, using Andersen’s Health Service Utilization Model and Transtheoretical Model for Behavioral Change, we propose a mixed methods study to evaluate factors associated with older Chinese Americans’ attitude toward AD and AD completion through cross-sectional survey and focus groups.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Central nervous system (CNS) injury such as spinal cord injury (SCI) is refractory to repair, attributed to the reduced neuronal intrinsic regeneration capacity and an inhibitory microenvironment largely constituted by the reactive glial cells. Understanding the mechanisms that inhibit or promote neural regeneration is relevant to public health because it may ultimately lead to treatments for neural injury and neurological diseases. Our study demonstrates that reprograming the reactive glial cells via metabolic rewiring promotes CNS axon regeneration and functional recovery, providing a new concept for treating CNS injuries such SCI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to the public health because the blood-brain barrier poses a significant obstacle for treating diseases of the central nervous system, representing an enormous national cost as measured by both patient suffering and economic burden. Upon completion of this research, we will understand the genetic factors that regulate the formation and function of the blood-brain barrier. These discoveries will provide new opportunities for the treatment of neurological diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE This proposal seeks to develop a new molecular strategy to limit subretinal fibrosis in blinding eye disease. PFKFB3 (6-phosphofructo-2-kinase/fructose-2, 6-bisphosphatase isoform 3) is a critical regulator/activator of glycolysis. The proposed studies are designed to use Pfkfb3 deficient myeloid cells and mice to investigate the involvement of glycolysis in myeloid cells in subretinal fibrosis and to define the underlying mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While one of the main therapeutic uses of cannabis is to relieve chronic pain, little is known about the underlying mechanisms. We propose using an innovative artificial intelligence (AI) approach to deconvolute the complex mixture of cannabinoids, terpenoids, and flavonoids that comprise cannabis and its extracts and test these in cell and animal models. When we are successful, we will have provided insight into the use of cannabis in pain and validated this paradigm for understanding a variety of other complementary and integrative (natural products) approaches to health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Leishmania donovani cause the fatal human disease visceral leishmaniasis for which the treatments are often toxic, ineffective, and are facing resistance. This proposal seeks to develop a versatile genetic tool that can be used to identify proteins that are important for parasite survival or that cause the parasites to resist drug treatments. The information gleaned from these studies could be useful in developing new drugs to treat these devastating diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Hematopoietic stem cell transplant (HSCT) is an essential procedure in treating patients with leukemia and other cancers. However, the transplant also temporarily reduces the number of neutrophils, an essential white blood cell population necessary for protection against infections with invasive fungi like Candida albicans. This project will help develop new tools to measure the function of neutrophils directly in HSCT patients and determine how fast neutrophil functions return to normal and restore the protection against invasive fungi.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: HEALTH RELEVANCE The ability to move the eyes to find objects, and the ability to use information about depth is critical to the safe execution of everyday tasks that require eye-hand coordination and navigating through the environment safely. Comprehensive rehabilitation of individuals with central field loss could have dramatic results in helping them achieve a full independent lifestyle. Our findings will lay the groundwork for therapies that maximize residual visual function and help create an important intervention for the successful rehabilitation of individuals with AMD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study will advance knowledge on racial health disparities by quantifying and characterizing the health consequences of black–white disparities in exposure to death from extended kin and household members. This research has the potential to initiate new substantive and methodological avenues to further investigate how improvements to black life expectancy may not only benefit individuals, but also have positive effects on the health of other social network members. Further, identifying mechanisms linking early and multiple exposures to death to later adverse health outcomes will promote adoption of multilevel interventions targeting social determinants of health to mitigate this potential intergenerational driver of inequality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Health Relevance For people who are blind or visually impaired, a serious barrier to employment, economic self- sufficiency and independence is insufficient access to a wide range of everyday objects needed for daily activities that require visual inspection on the part of the user. Such objects include printed documents, maps, infographics, appliances and 3D models used in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM), and are abundant in schools, the home and the workplace. The proposed research would result in a powerful camera-based smartphone app to provide increased access to such objects for the approximately 10 million Americans with significant vision impairments or blindness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The concept of overall well-being provides an important perspective for thinking about public health. Within the study of well-being, assessing which individuals have higher well-being and which individuals have lower well-being is crucial in order to use cross-sectional data to study the determinants of well-being and in order to study inequality in well-being. This project develops methods for comparing overall well-being across individuals even when individuals differ in how they use response scales and well-being has many aspects, and uses those methods to study how well-being varies across individuals and over time, including how it varies across different stages of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative Tumor-associated macrophages (TAM) are responsible for supporting an environment that promotes cancer progression and invasion. The goal of our project is to understand the underlying mechanisms of how function, differentiation and tumor infiltration of TAM are regulated by a cell stress regulator, CNPY2, within tumor microenvironment. The results from this study will be used to design TAM-targeted cancer immune therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The PI3K/Akt signaling is frequently hyperactivated in cancer. The goal of this grant application is to find ways to inhibit Akt effectively for the therapy of cancer and cancer metastasis, and to mitigate adverse consequences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Building a model of the neural basis of natural, real-world social vision is a fundamental goal of social neuroscience. Natural social vision depends critically on an active process of information gathering and the intricate interplay among many brain regions that rapidly adapt in response to the properties of the social environment. Understanding the neural basis of natural, real-world social vision will directly inform our understanding of the neural basis of neurological and psychiatric disorders that involve aberrant social processing, such as mood disorders, anxiety disorders, autism spectrum disorders, schizophrenia, traumatic brain injury, Parkinson’s disease, and post-traumatic stress disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative As an increasing number of older adults are suffering from Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI), Alzheimer's disease (AD) and AD-related dementias (ADRD); providing them with quality care in long term care (LTC) facilities is becoming problematic due to resource limitations, nursing shortage and high turnover among LTC nursing personnel. A novel approach to utilize socially assistive robotic systems that can meaningfully engage this group of older adults through physical, cognitive and social activities is proposed in the hope that such smart technology will be able to augment, and not replace, the current system of care. This study will contribute to the development of improved intelligent technology as an effective approach to engage older persons with dementia with the long- term goal of enhancing their function and quality of life as well as improving LTC staff satisfaction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative De no!ID haplotype-resolved genome assembly is the most comprehensive solution to understand genomic sequences. This proposal aims to develop cost-effective computational methods for high-quality haplotype-resolved assemblies by utilizing multiple sequencing technologies. The new assembly algorijhms in this proposal not only could be used by large-scale sequencing consortiums such as the Human Pangenome Reference Consortium (HPRC) and the Genome in a Bottle (GIAB), but also could pave the way to personal genome assembly for genomic research and clinical applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The purpose of this grant is to study a model of mental health navigation for African American and Latinx children in high poverty urban communities focused on reducing key parental attitudinal barriers to care. The study will examine the effectiveness of two types of navigators: paraprofessionals who have strong community knowledge, and case managers who are trained to access formal community services. Two community boards, one focused on promoting inter-agency communication and support to enhance navigators’ effectiveness, and the other focused on implications for state and federal policy, will meet annually with the goal of identifying key findings with the potential to influence local, state, and national priorities for children’s mental health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Project Narrative As an organism experiences its world, neural circuits remodel such that a subset of synaptic connections between neurons are removed, while others are maintained and strengthened. The current proposal will shed new light on how glial cells (astrocytes and microglia), another 50% of brain cell types, communicate to selectively remove a subset of synapses, while sparing others. Long-term, these findings have important implications for understanding why some synapses are more susceptible to aberrant removal in a broad range of neuropsychiatric disorders, such as schizophrenia, to neurodegenerative diseases, such as Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative As you walk, you coordinate movements in your arms and legs. Neurons with long connections up and down the spinal cord are responsible for this coordination. In this proposal, we will map the connections between different types of spinal neurons to understand how local and long-range connections are different. With computational models based on these results, this work will help explain coordination along the spinal cord.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Despite efforts to prevent suicide, US rates are climbing, and suicide is the second leading cause of death amongst youth. Digital tools, especially personal smartphones, are promising avenues to address these issues and can be used to provide a unique understanding of proximal risk factors, including psychological distress, anhedonia and behavioral withdrawal, and sleep disturbance amongst high-risk individuals. This Fast-Track SBIR proposal will enhance the effectiveness of the delivery of preventative health care to youth at risk for suicide by developing and testing a comprehensive digital platform that allows practitioners to integrate objective mobile sensing and HIPAA compliant client communication tools into their management of these young people.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health, because although memory dysfunction is a frequent and persistent symptom of traumatic brain injury (TBI), there are currently no effective treatments available for this persistent deficit. In addition, the neurophysiological basis of these deficits remains unknown, making rational treatment design difficult. The project is relevant to the NINDS mission because knowledge of why TBI induced memory disorders persist, and how neuromodulation alleviates them in animal models, will allow for clinical treatment development that will reduce the burden of these deficits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Each year, 50,000 women are diagnosed with ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) in the US; and although DCIS is classified as non-invasive, some DCIS will progress to invasive breast cancer. Currently, it is impossible to predict this progression meaning all DCIS patients are treated with the same invasive therapy, causing thousands of women with DCIS to be overtreated and undergo surgery and therapy they do not need. These overtreatment measures risk harmful side effects and add a significant psychological burden to patients, while using valuable resources in healthcare systems. This project aims to identify biomarkers to predict whether DCIS stays non-invasive or becomes invasive and life-threatening by studying the dynamic behavior of DCIS cells using advanced microscopy technologies and labelling techniques.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: 2. PROJECT NARRATIVE Though childhood victimization is an endemic phenomenon, our collective knowledge of how and why such experiences translate into enduring mental health difficulties remains stubbornly underdeveloped, particularly in relation to the underlying neural mechanisms. In children, neural maturation of brain function manifests as a progressive reorganization of networked brain regions exhibiting correlated (or anti-correlated) activation, and alterations in this developmental process may be a biomarker of the protective or potentiating effects of ecolog- ical influences such as victimization or parenting practices. Establishment of functional network dynamics and development as a malleable mechanism linking adversity to impairment in transdiagnostic biobehavioral domains (e.g., difficulties with emotion regulation) can inform development of targeted, evidence-based clinical ap- proaches for vulnerable populations of victimized youth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: Powassan virus (POWV) is a tick-borne virus that causes a 10% fatal brain disease, and a new tick POWV isolate, LI9, was found to cause highly lethal brain damage in aged mice, a finding that mimics POWV disease in elderly patients. In contrast, an attenuated POWV, LI9-P, fails to cause brain damage in mice and is a potential vaccine that differs in its ability to regulate antiviral responses of cells that form brain barriers. Paired lethal and attenuated POWVs, and our unique ability to modify POWVs, permit us to propose defining determinants and mechanisms of POWV entry into the brain and antiviral interferons as potential inhibitors of brain damage applicable to elderly POWV patients.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative Gut Bacteroides require an array of cell surface lipoproteins to survive in the host, yet how lipoproteins are synthesized in these bacteria is poorly understood. Here we will determine how a newly discovered N- acyltransferase plays a key role in lipoprotein maturation and fitness in the model gut symbiont Bacteroides thetaiotaomicron. This work will reveal molecular details of a conserved lipoprotein synthesis pathway that is unique to Bacteroides and provide new and selective ways to manipulate these host-associated bacteria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Vascular risk factors (particularly hypertension and obesity) are important contributors to Alzheimer’s disease, working with amyloid pathology in individuals without symptoms to accelerate the buildup of abnormal tau proteins and drive cognitive decline. This study will provide important missing knowledge about how early and over what age range this interaction takes place and therefore can be intervened upon, and whether imaging or blood measures of tau pathology can detect this early and silent partnership between vascular risk and Alzheimer’s disease in midlife. Outcomes from this project will inform the design of prevention trials targeting both amyloid and hypertension or obesity in asymptomatic Alzheimer’s disease, by identifying individuals who are at risk and are most likely to benefit from early intervention, and by determining whether we can use blood measures of tau pathology to improve accessibility and diversity of these clinical trials.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The objective of the proposed mentored research career development award is to facilitate the transition of the application to an independent scientist career investigating the physiologic processes regulating food intake to better treat obesity. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cardiac arrhythmias (abnormal heart rhythms) remain a leading cause of death in the United States in part due to abnormal calcium cycling in the heart. This project seeks to gain new insights into how mitochondria impact calcium cycling to contribute to arrhythmogenesis. Information learned from these studies will provide useful guidelines for the development of new therapies for the treatment of heart disorders, especially calcium- dependent arrhythmias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Despite high and rising rates of adolescent depression and suicidal thoughts and behaviors, racial and ethnic minoritized (REM) youth are significantly less likely to remain in mental health services than their White peers. Measurement-based care (MBC) is an evidence-based practice that holds promise to promote mental health treatment engagement, but has not been tailored for REM youth. Scientific discovery about how to retain REM youth with depressive symptoms and/or suicide risk in treatment by using a culturally-tailored approach to MBC could reduce disparities in mental health treatment access and outcomes, reducing suffering among this vulnerable population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Externalizing disorders are a leading cause of morbidity and mortality in the United States, and the development of novel prevention and therapeutic intervention efforts for these illnesses will require a deeper understanding of their etiological bases. Motivated by recent discoveries implicating early life as a critical risk window, the proposed research will characterize the developmental neurogenomic pathways that confer liability for externalizing psychopathology by combining cutting-edge methods from genomics, neuroscience, and informatics. Findings will provide an integrated, systems-level understanding of the complex molecular underpinnings of externalizing disorders, thus laying the foundation for improved risk stratification, drug discovery, and other translational efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although cancer immunotherapy has drastically changed the course of the disease and favored a durable remission in many patients, some tumors remain resistant to immunotherapy. We propose to study a novel target for cancer immunotherapy called ILT3 (LILRB4) that is highly enriched in macrophages that infiltrate the tumor. Since ILT3 inhibits macrophages, we have developed a blocking antibody that will release macrophages from inhibition, promoting their response and tumor regression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project Narrative  New strategies to prevent breast cancer are urgently needed because: i) breast cancer incidence rates keep rising by half percent per year and about 13%, or 1 in 8, of US women are going to develop invasive breast cancer in their life time; ii) prevention strategies for estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer do not reduce patient mortality and prevention strategy for estrogen receptor-negative breast cancer is still not available. Our proposed study aims to intercept breast cancer development by reinforcing antitumor immune response via H1-antihistamines, many of which are over-the-counter drugs to treat seasonal allergies. If the results are promising, our findings could be rapidly translated into clinic trials for immunoprevention of breast cancer, especially, in women at high-risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Innovative diabetes technologies may offer substantial benefits to older adults with diabetes, yet they remain underutilized. This proposal seeks to generate high-quality, real-world evidence for the use of continuous glucose monitoring (CGM) in adults ≥65 years with diabetes requiring insulin. The study will leverage medical record data linked to Medicare claims to (1) describe patterns of CGM use in routine care; (2) characterize the clinical effects of long-term use; and (3) evaluate the economic impacts of scaling CGM in this age group, propelling new strategies to increase uptake and realize the benefits of CGM for older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE People spend most waking time within a few hours of eating, and how efficiently the body metabolizes nutrients is an emerging marker of overall health. We will study the blood’s chemical response to a standardized meal that was administered to a large population of individuals in a community setting. Our research may offer novel biological insights into the body’s response to food that will spur future work in precision nutrition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Ultra-high dose rate radiation therapy has the potential to reduce the radiation damage seen in normal tissues, but most studies have been done with mice with the delivered plan drastically different from that in clinical treatments. The main goals of this study are to develop treatment planning system for the Mobetron® FLASHIQ for clinical and advanced FLASH-RT planning and evaluation, with deliveries validated via UHDR dosimetry for realistic cases. This study will advance the state-of-the-art in FLASH-RT by bridging the extensive gap between the basic science of FLASH and the clinical needs of FLASH for translation to human trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cell-cell interaction plays a crucial role in many biological processes, including cell differentiation, inflammation, wound repair and oncogenesis. Current methods for identifying cell-cell interactions are mainly through low-throughput manual techniques, leaving a disconnect between advancements in high-throughput methods and the identification of biologically meaningful interactions. This proposal aims to bridge this gap by creating computational frameworks that comprehend the impact of external signals on a cell's internal transcription factor activity using a combination of single-cell multiome and spatial transcriptomics data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Despite all progress in the neuromuscular field, there is no permanent cure for spinal muscular atrophy (SMA), and all current available therapies have important limitations. This study will develop strategies to permanently edit the SMN2 gene to produce full-length Survival Motor Neuron (SMN) protein by applying CRISPR technologies. The study will provide pre-clinical evidence towards the development of a lasting single-dose genetic treatment for SMA.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Severe problem behavior (e.g., aggression, self-injury) among individuals with intellectual and developmental disabilities can greatly impair functioning, produce injury, and lead to placement in restrictive settings. Behavior-analytic treatments, which are the current gold standard for reducing severe problem behavior in this population, are predicated on identifying effective and durable reinforcers for use within behavioral interventions. The current proposal will examine a novel method for identifying reinforcers to enhance behavioral interventions by making them more effective and durable in the face of common treatment challenges.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative  The proposed research aims to design and develop a virtual reality (VR)–based cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) system for treating stimulant use disorder (StUD). StUD, which includes the misuse of drugs like methamphetamine, cocaine, and other amphetamines, is associated with serious health consequences and is the leading cause of overdose death in many western US states. Currently, there is no pharmacological treatment available for StUD and psychosocial interventions, such as CBT, are considered the standard treatment. However, traditional CBT has high relapse rates and treatment dropout, suggesting that more robust approaches are needed. The proposed VR-CBT system has the potential to improve treatment outcomes and reduce relapse rates by providing patients with a safe and immersive environment to practice coping strategies and build communication skills.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This proposal addresses a topic that is severely understudied, mosquito taste, in a species that is also understudied, Aedes albopictus, despite its being one of the most dangerous mosquito species. Here, we propose a multidisciplinary approach to investigate how Aedes albopictus senses tastants to guide biting behaviors. This study is designed to aid in the development of biologically and environmentally safe agents to control these mosquitoes and the diseases that they transmit including dengue, yellow fever, Zika, and Chikungunya.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Viral and bacterial infections result in transient neuroinflammation and are a common occurrence throughout life, yet how or why temporary inflammation increases the risk of developing neurodegenerative disease (ND) remains elusive. Similarly, despite the key role of astrocytes in neuron function and modulating the immune response, they are often overlooked in the study of ND. The proposed research will address these outstanding questions and provide fundamental insight into how transient astrocyte reactivity affects future insults and how this impacts on ND.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The proposed studies are directed at understanding how the replication of human papillomaviruses (HPV) is regulated by DNA repair pathways. Our previous studies show that activation of the homologous recombination repair pathway, ATM and ATR, are required for viral replication. Our recent work show that two members from the related non-homologous repair pathways are also activated in HPV positive cells and at least one of these regulates viral replication. This proposal seeks to understand how these two additional pathways contribute to replication of HPV genomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative (relevance of this research to public health): Our laboratory is studying recently discovered molecules that contribute to thrombosis—the formation of life- threatening, unwanted blood clots inside arteries or veins. These basic science studies have the potential to lead to new insights into how unwanted blood clots occur in heart attack, stroke and deep vein thrombosis. These studies may allow us to develop new treatments for diseases like thrombosis and fibrosis that are caused or influenced by improper functioning of the blood clotting system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Retinitis pigmentosa (RP) encompasses a large and heterogenous group of inherited eye diseases characterized by irreversible vision loss and blindness due to the death of the light-sensing photoreceptor cells of the retina. Despite affecting over 1.5 million individuals worldwide, treatment options for RP remain limited. This proposal uses three-dimensional stem cell-derived retinal organoids to model human retinal development and investigate why retinal cells are primarily, and often exclusively, susceptible to certain genetic mutations, particularly in genes that are universally expressed in cells throughout the body.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is the most common inherited cardiac disorder. Cardiac fibrosis is a key feature of HCM, is associated with adverse outcomes, but there is no medical therapy that prevents fibrosis. HCM is a state of deficiency of C-type natriuretic peptide (CNP) and augmenting CNP signaling is a novel approach to target fibrosis in HCM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) is moving forward with its groundbreaking plan to reduce tobacco-related death and disease by lowering nicotine in combusted cigarettes to minimally addictive levels. To maximize the benefits of this potentially life-saving policy, we developed messages about reduced nicotine and the health risks of using different tobacco products. We will test the effects of these messages on behavioral outcomes in priority populations in the context of using very low nicotine content cigarettes, approximating the initial implementation of a national nicotine reduction policy accompanied by a communication campaign.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Heart failure from ischemic heart disease is the leading cause of morbidity, mortality, and healthcare expenditure worldwide. The long-term goal and the clinical significance of this K08 grant is to provide the basis for the development of a novel therapeutic factor for the treatment of ischemic heart disease that promotes adult fibroblast to cardiomyocyte reprogramming following myocardial infarction. The results from these studies will deepen our understanding of mechanisms that drive reprogramming and serve as an important pre-clinical platform for the advancement of cardiac reprogramming therapies in patients suffering from heart failure and ischemic heart disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cancer recurrence is a major problem in the clinical management of most types of cancer, but its mechanism remains unclear. Anastasis is a newly discovered cell recovery mechanism that dying cancer cells could adopt to escape cell death-inducing cancer therapy by reversing apoptosis and therefore contribute to the recurrence, but it is technically challenging to test this iconoclastic hypothesis, because at the present time there is no practical way to identify anastatic cancer cells. Here, we will apply a novel biosensor to detect and track anastatic cells – an essential tool to examine the contribution of anastasis in cancer cells to the recurrence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT) Sexual and gender minority (SGM) caregivers of persons living with with Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) and AD Related Dementias (AD/ADRD) face complex and overlapping challenges to engaging in regular physical activity (PA), based on identity-related and role-related stressors. Following the NIH Stage Model, this research seeks first to explore unique barriers and facilitators to regular PA engagement faced by SGM AD/ADRD caregivers (Stage 0), then co-design (Stage Ia) and test feasibility (Stage Ib) of a novel intervention to meet these distinct needs. This research will provide timely understanding of unique, intersecting needs of SGM AD/ADRD caregivers and inform creation of a culturally relevant, feasible, and sustainable PA intervention designed to meet specific challenges faced by this vulnerable population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Specific Aims of this translational collaborative R61/R33 application will evaluate the disease-modifying potential of the selective blood-brain barrier penetrant Nrf2 activator, dimethyl fumarate (DMF), in an etiologically relevant rat model of drug resistant epilepsy. The novel studies proposed herein will: 1) optimize oral dosing of DMF to male and female rats when delivered in an innovative medication-in-food paradigm; 2) assess the ability of DMF to prevent or modify the development of chronic epilepsy and/or associated comorbidities when administered at the time of status epilepticus onset; 3) determine whether adjunctive oral DMF therapy reduces seizure burden and improves pharmacosensitivity when combined with the antiseizure medicines levetiracetam and lamotrigine in rats with established epilepsy. The studies proposed herein are novel as they aim to inform on the development of a first-in-class therapy to preserve cognitive function, limit disease progression and improve pharmacosensitivity in the patient with epilepsy that results from severe status epilepticus or other brain insults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  In this study, we developed a first-in-class small-molecule inhibitor of EZH2, a histone methyltransferase that has been demonstrated by a myriad of studies to drive cancer development and progression. Instead of the C-terminal catalytic domain that current EZH2-targeting drugs interfere with, our compound binds to an N- terminal domain that is essential for the gene activation activity and methyltransferase-independent oncogenic effect of EZH2 in estrogen receptor a-negative (ERa-) breast cancer cells. Therefore, our prototype compound downregulated a group of genes that promote cancer cell migration and inhibited the malignant phenotypes of ERa- breast cancer cells that are insensitive to present EZH2 inhibitors. Results from our work will yield a new class of anticancer agents that specifically target a totally different functional domain of EZH2, which hold promise for broader clinical applications than current EZH2-targeted therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Enhanced neuronal activity is a major mechanism facilitating the progression and therapeutic resistance of glioblastoma (GBM), the most lethal form of primary brain tumor. The objective of this proposal is to enlighten the molecular mechanisms driving the activation of the neuronal program at recurrence of GBM and to address whether and how the tumor cells shape their microenvironment to support glioma invasion through integration of multi-omics with protein interaction networks, prioritization of targetable proteins and integrative analysis of spatial and single cell transcriptomics. The successful completion of this proposal will elucidate the key molecular drivers prompting the increased neuronal activity at recurrence and the dynamics of the functional links between malignant and non-malignant cells during the progression of GBM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed study seeks to 1) Investigate whether in-utero exposure to antihypertensive treatment is associated with offspring subclinical cardiovascular disease risk factors (i.e., oxidative stress, inflammation, and arterial stiffness) and 2) Examine whether neighborhood deprivation (i.e., a composite measure of environmental exposures) influences the association of in-utero exposure to hypertensive disorders of pregnancy on offspring vascular outcomes. Successful completion of this study will enhance the candidate’s career development and inform the planning of a future intervention to improve vascular outcomes among children born to mothers with hypertensive disorders of pregnancy. This project leverages an experienced multi-disciplinary mentorship team and is a single-site ancillary study within a larger follow-up study of a chronic hypertension treatment trial funded by the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute (NCT02299414).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The recombination of domains that are structurally and functionally distinct is a fundamental mechanism that drives the expansion of function in protein families. In this proposal, I develop a combined computational-experimental approach to study the interactions between domains that enable them to productively work in tandem to drive the emergence of a new function. Insights from this work will advance basic and applied biology by providing techniques for understanding the acquisition of new function in protein families as well as the design principles that can help to more efficiently generate synthetic proteins through domain fusions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The product of this research effort will be new scientific insight into mechanisms of activity of a novel synthetic oleanane triterpenoid (SOT), known as CDDO-2P-Im or ‘2P-Im’, and a clear demonstration of the capacity of 2P-Im to enhance the response radiation. The success of this effort will define an approach to increasing survival of pediatric patients with a rare cancer, Diffuse Intrinsic Pontine Glioma (DIPG) and other pediatric high-grade gliomas (HGG). The multidisciplinary research team utilizes established preclinical models of DIPG, which remains a significant unmet medical need as less than 1% of patients survive 5 years (the median survival is only 9 months).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Deficiency of elastin, the major component of elastic fibers in blood vessel walls, leads to excess vascular smooth muscle cells, which characterizes normal closure of the ductus arteriosus in neonates as well as a number of diseases (e.g., supravalvular aortic stenosis). I recently discovered that the protein sphingosine kinase 1 plays a key role in how defective elastin leads to excess smooth muscle cells. I propose to use human cells and tissue samples as well as mouse models to study underlying mechanisms and thus, delineate concrete steps towards developing novel therapeutic approaches for vascular diseases, especially those afflicting children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hyperphosphorylation of microtubule (MT) associated protein Tau is tightly correlated with Alzheimer’s disease progression; however, studies of isoform-specific effects of Tau function and dysfunction are largely unexplored. I discovered that phosphorylation differentially regulates adult and fetal Tau isoforms: Tau isoforms have distinct phosphorylation patterns in neurons, and specific phosphorylation sites impact Tau-MT interactions in an isoform-dependent manner. I uniquely propose to use high-throughput pooled optical CRISPR screening and CRISPR prime editing to contrast the effects of Tau phosphorylation (AIM 1) and regulators of Tau-MT interactions (AIM 2) on its function and dysfunction between fetal and adult Tau isoforms, thus providing insight into both loss-of-function and toxic gain-of-function mechanisms in Alzheimer’s disease and other related dementias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: Project Narrative Both genetic association studies and expression profiling analyses have suggested a role of Piwi-interacting RNAs (piRNAs), a new small noncoding RNA family, in tumorigenesis. The proposed study aims to develop a novel piRNA-based diagnostic method for the early detection of ovarian cancer. This exploratory study will provide proof of concept for future large population-based studies to further investigate the translational role of piRNAs in ovarian cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE HBV chronically infects approximately 300 million people worldwide but the currently approved antiviral therapies rarely cure HBV infection. The elimination of HBV persistent cccDNA genome in infected patients is considered to be essential for a cure to hepatitis B, and is the ultimate goal in treatment of this disease. This application aims to discover novel cccDNA inhibitors using an innovative high throughput screening assay, followed by preclinical drug development, which will aid the global effort to eradicate HBV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding the social brain, the neural basis of our ability to interact socially, is a fundamental step toward addressing cognitive disorders that have been linked to disruptions in social cognition, such as autism and schizophrenia. Familiarity, the ability to tell if we know someone, and recollection, the detailed recall of past social episodes, are two fundamental building blocks of social cognition; however, it is still unknown how the brain implements these processes, which have different and conflicting computational requirements. Here, I will use recordings from animal subjects, human patients, and machine-learning models to shed light on how the memory system in the brain implements familiarity and recollection, and how these processes are combined to achieve social memory.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The abnormal deposition of bone-like mineral in the valve and vasculature, also known as vascular calcification (VC), increases with age, vascular and valvular disease, diabetes and chronic kidney disease (CKD). Calcification of these organs leads to loss of compliance, stiffening and increased tendency to rupture, contributing to declining cardiovascular function and heart failure. There are no drug therapies for VC. The proposed research provides a foundation for future translational and clinical studies aimed at identifying effective biomarkers and targets, as well as developing therapeutics to prevent and/or treat VC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARATIVE Chronically elevated sympathetic tone in heart failure leads to b-adrenergic receptor desensitization, calcium overload, and increased risk of ventricular arrhythmia. Heart failure incidence and outcomes are strongly sex dependent; females have a lower incidence of arrhythmia than men, yet the mechanistic differences are not fully understood. By combining new whole-heart, cellular, and sub-cellular imaging approaches, this project aims to uncover novel mechanisms that underlie sex differences in b-adrenergic signaling and may promote sex- dependent outcomes in heart failure, with potential therapeutic implications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Using an innovative multi-stakeholder approach, this study will contribute essential and timely data, new methods, and ethical analyses to first investigate stakeholders’ (i.e., social and behavioral genomics (SBG) researchers, journal editors, journalists, members of industry, parents, and K-12 educators) roles in the conduct and translation of SBG and their perspectives on SBG’s downstream harms/benefits. It will then determine stakeholders’ roles in producing, mitigating, and/or promoting the downstream harms benefits of SBG for the purpose of locating social responsibility. Finally, the proposed research will identify – through multistakeholder engagement – strategies for mitigating the harms and promoting the benefits of SBG.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Racial, ethnic, and socioeconomic disparities in type 1 diabetes management and outcomes are poorly defined. Using data from a large administrative claims database, this project will rigorously characterize inequities in the use of diabetes technology, the attainment of glycemic control, and the burden of major morbidity and mortality among children and adults with type 1 diabetes. These data will identify critical gaps in the management of type 1 diabetes and inform efforts to reduce social disparities in the population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative The periphery-to-center progression of tissue fibrosis is the hallmark of Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF), of which the cellular and molecular basis is poorly understood. My preliminary data reveal that a rarely characterized population of fibroblasts in the subpleural region contribute to fibrogenesis. This proposal will investigate the characteristics and functions of subpleural fibroblasts in the setting of progressive fibrosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is highly relevant to public health because identifying feasible, acceptable, and effective interventions offers the possibility of reducing depression, anxiety, and stress for students at U.S. colleges and universities, the majority of whom experience mental health problems but the minority of whom who receive adequate mental health support. By studying the extent to which a multi-modal supplement boosts effects for a mindfulness-based intervention (and systematically comparing both to an active health education control program) to reduce depression, anxiety, and stress, the proposed research is highly consistent with NCCIH’s mission to rigorously investigate complementary and integrative health interventions and their roles in improving health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity is a serious, and costly chronic disease in the United States. Emerging evidence points to a critical pathogenic link between lymphatic vessel dysfunction and obesity. I will investigate the impairments in lymphatic endothelial Ca2+ signaling in obesity and provide strategies to protect lymphatic barrier function and in turn, improve body weight regulation in obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. Biological nitrogen fixation by nitrogenase sustains life on Earth through the production of metabolically available nitrogen for incorporation into essential biomolecules. The proposed research targets select aerobic and anaerobic diazotrophic bacteria with emerging cryoET methodologies to answer key questions about the nitrogenase enzymatic mechanism in the cellular context. Examining the structure function relationships of nitrogenase in this context will inform on other metalloenzyme mechanisms enzymes relevant to human health, and on the design of synthetic systems for the sustainable production of ammonia for agriculture.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Germ cells must maintain their identity for the entirety of a species reproductive lifespan, a task that can last more than forty years in humans. This unique challenge raises the question: What underlying molecular processes govern germ cell identity and protect germ cells from reprogramming towards a somatic cell fate? Using the fruit fly Drosophila melanogaster, I will answer this fundamental question by (i) characterizing the germline transcriptional program and probing cell autonomous vs nonautonomous mechanisms for transcriptional activation (ii) identifying regulatory factors that are instructive for germline specification, (iii) uncovering how the conserved translational repressor Nanos protects germ cell fate by repressing somatic transcription in germlines from flies to humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Anorexia nervosa (AN) is a deadly psychiatric disorder and yet current treatments for AN show only moderate efficacy. Interoceptive processing dysfunctions (i.e., how the brain receives and processes body afferents), contribute to body image disturbance (BID), a core feature of AN associated with poor treatment outcomes. The proposed project works to establish (1) how interoceptive processing dysfunctions contribute to BID and (2) how the use of a nonpharmacological experimental therapeutic targeting interoceptive processing affects BID with the larger goal of improving treatment for BID in AN.

PHR: Alzheimer’s disease patients may have offline processing deficits that contribute to memory issues. I will use a mouse model of Alzheimer’s disease to determine cortical network impairments during the offline processing in sleep and to modulate neuron and glia networks during sleep to improve memory retention. The completion of this preclinical project may lead to the innovation of novel diagnostics and treatment options for the millions of Americans that suffer from Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The emergence of immune-evasive SARS-CoV-2 variants poses an urgent threat to public health, necessitating the development of updated vaccines, but the optimal boosting strategy in previously vaccinated individuals remains unknown. The proposed research will employ controlled immunization studies in a humanized mouse model to elucidate the impact and molecular basis of immune imprinting due to previous vaccination on subsequent humoral responses to viral variants. Understanding imprinting responses to viral variant antigens will inform novel vaccine strategies for SARS-CoV-2 and other antigenically variable pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Hospitalized patients with diabetes face increased risks of morbidity and mortality due to high and low glycemic excursions during acute illness. The current standard of administering multiple daily injection insulin therapy to manage diabetes in the hospital is often inadequate and results in unacceptably high rates of both hyperglycemia and iatrogenic hypoglycemia. This proposal aims to examine and optimize the use of automated insulin delivery systems in the hospital by evaluating their effectiveness, identifying barriers and facilitators to their use in the hospital, and developing implementation strategies to improve glycemic control for hospitalized patients with diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Neurons rely on mechanisms of RNA-localization and local-translation for many aspects of their biology such as axonal growth and synaptic plasticity. RNA binding proteins are essential for regulating these processes and are frequently mutated in neurodegenerative disease. This project aims to understand how the molecular interplay between RNA binding proteins control activity- dependent local-translation, to enhance fundamental knowledge about the molecular underpinnings of learning and memory.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Antibiotic resistant bacterial pathogens have become a leading cause of death globally and doctors are left with few remaining treatment options. To overcome this emerging threat, new antibiotics need to be developed, but few are currently in the clinical pipeline. The aim of this proposal is to better understand the function and therapeutic potential of a rare class of macrocyclic antimicrobial peptides with beta-hairpin secondary structure using high-throughput screens followed by biochemical, computational, and mechanistic analyses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In order to protect public health from a rapidly changing climate through preventive patient care and public health policies, it is essential for the medical community to understand the impact of temperature, precipitation, and its extremes on respiratory health, particularly in those disproportionately impacted by climate change, such as individuals with asthma and COPD, and Black and Latinx communities. The results of this study will provide valuable data to understand relationships of temperature and precipitation with asthma and COPD. This data will support future investigation of interventions, such as air purification and community cooling centers, to build resiliency and adaptation to a rapidly warming world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Elevated phospholipid biosynthesis is a metabolic hallmark of cancer. Our proposal aims to determine whether deuterium metabolic imaging of phospholipid biosynthesis enables longitudinal assessment of brain tumor growth in vivo. Clinical translation of our studies will provide physicians with a much-needed tool to monitor response to therapy in a timely manner in brain tumor patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Antiviral therapeutics approved by the FDA or currently in clinical trials for treatment of chronic hepatitis B can efficiently suppress the replication of hepatitis B virus (HBV), reduce viral load and improve liver pathology, but fail to cure the chronic infection of HBV. This is because those drugs cannot eliminate the most stable HBV replication intermediate, covalently closed circular DNA (cccDNA), in the nuclei of hepatocytes, and viral replication rebounds after discontinuation of treatment. This project addresses the pressing need for the cure of chronic hepatitis B by elimination and/or permanent inactivation of cccDNA with our proprietary chemically ligated guide RNA (lgRNA)-based CRISPR/Cas9 gene editing technology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Neural-immune pathways play a critical role in neurodevelopmental processes and growing evidence suggests that neural-immune gene expression is dysregulated in schizophrenia and other neurodevelopmental, psychiatric disorders. This project will (a) integrate gene expression and genotype data to generate a genome- wide resource for individual-level prediction of neural-immune gene expression, and (b) characterize the impact of genetically predicted neural-immune gene expression on longitudinal trajectories of structural brain development and change in dimensional measures of mental health relevant to psychosis in children and adolescents. Results will significantly expand our understanding of the genetic mechanisms regulating gene expression in the human brain and the developmental etiology of mental illness, thereby informing the development of targeted biologically-based treatments to reduce the burden of disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Current treatment options for liver cancer, the third leading cause of cancer-related death, provide only limited survival benefits, in part due to challenges in targeting genetically distinct liver tumors. With this proposal, as a potential therapeutic strategy, we will identify and target the metabolic changes imposed by oncogenic alterations on cancer cell mitochondria, the central biosynthetic hub for cellular metabolism. Combining genetic in vivo liver tumorigenesis models, mitochondrial metabolomics and CRISPR-based functional screens, this proposal will assess oncogene-dependent metabolic limitations of tumor growth in vivo and, provide unprecedented opportunities to exploit metabolic intervention strategies targeting liver cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Prostate cancer relies on androgen for growth and is therefore sensitive to androgen-deprivation therapy and antiandrogens. However, the disease can develop therapeutic resistance by transforming from a prostate lineage to a stem cell-like state. This project seeks to characterize the molecular drivers of lineage transformation and resistance to antiandrogens, with the goal to develop an effective therapeutic strategy to target these drivers and suppress the growth of stem cell-like prostate cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Epilepsy is a chronic, debilitating neurological disorder that affects millions of people across the globe. Epilepsy due to head injury, known as post-traumatic epilepsy, represents an opportunity to understand the changes in the brain that lead to epilepsy. This research will help us understand the unique structural and functional changes in the brain leading to post-traumatic epilepsy and develop tools for epilepsy risk stratification after head injury—a prerequisite for feasible clinical trials of therapies for the prevention of epilepsy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is a life-long neurodevelopmental disorder of which there are currently no effective treatments for due to a limited understanding of the underlying pathophysiology. This work focuses on understanding how ASD risk genes converge in the dendrites of pyramidal neurons in the prefrontal cortex, a brain region implicated in ASD etiology. This project will shed light on the cellular processes that contribute to ASD and may reveal new therapeutic strategies to rescue cellular and network functions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This career development award proposes a multi-omic systems biology approach to elucidate the roles of the vaginal microbiome and psychological stress in progression of precancerous cervical lesions to cancer, notably, in the known disparities between Black and White women. The proposed plan will accelerate this early-stage investigator’s career trajectory to independence by providing targeted bioinformatic, statistical and molecular biology training to analyze microbiome and stress experience data, using an integrative systems biology framework to inform future clinically relevant prognostic biomarkers, risk stratification protocols, and interventions to intercept cervical cancer development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal aims to investigate how stochastic neuronal circuit is built during development by using Drosophila color vision circuit as a model. Our work will reveal general principles coordinating stochastic cell fate choice and synaptic partner matching during circuit assembly. The molecules underlying synaptic connectivity during development identified here will also provide insights into the regenerative mechanisms and novel therapeutic approaches for neurodegenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  A multi-lineage, transcriptional, and epigenetic understanding of alveologenesis and re-alveologenesis upon injury is a timely response to the burden of pulmonary diseases and leverages latest single-cell technology. The proposed project leverages our expertise in multiple lung cell lineages, single-cell genomics, mouse genetics, and bioinformatics; tackles fundamental questions of cell fate, plasticity, and signaling; relates to pulmonary diseases during development and upon injury; and opens the door to single-cell functional genomics applicable to any organ.

PHR: Project narrative Lymphatic dysfunctions are associated with many cardiovascular and metabolic diseases such as obesity, atherosclerosis, lymphedema, and immune suppression, which have limited or no clinical approaches to treat. Restoring impaired lymphatic vessels and maintaining a proper lymphatic drainage plays a crucial role in lipid metabolism and cholesterol transport. The proposed studies in this project are significant as a better understanding of these processes may enable the development of novel therapeutic treatment for cardiovascular and metabolic diseases.
