IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Factors that promote microbial colonization in complex and dynamic communities such as the human gastrointestinal microbiome are poorly understood, but knowledge of their functions could lead to therapeutic interventions that reverse dysbiotic states. We predict that rapid gene diversifiers, such as Diversity Generating Retroelements (DGRs), provide bacteria with selective fitness advantages through rapid evolution of ligand binding proteins that facilitate colonization within the gut microbiome. By testing this prediction, we expect to generate a toolkit for engineering adaptative systems in beneficial microbes that allow efficient engraftment in the gut microbiome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Targeted strategies to combat enteric infections are needed to overcome deficiencies with conventional antibiotic treatment such as access and stability in the GI tract, antibiotic resistance, and collateral damage to the native microbiome. Within this proposal, I will (1) define and expand the expression capacity of Saccharomyces cerevisiae var. boulardii (Sb)-produced anti-infective therapeutics in conditions mimicking the gut environment, and (2) establish tolerability and treatment outcomes of engineered Sb carrying a variety of anti-pathogen payloads as single agents or in combination. This work will generate innovative engineered probiotic therapies that can directly and safely mitigate the specific pathogens Clostridioides difficile and enterotoxigenic Bacteroides fragilis from the mammalian gut.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The prevention of asthma development in children is a pressing, unmet need of utmost priority. There is also a need to identify periods of susceptibility to persistent environmental chemical exposures in children. The proposed research will determine if perfluoroalkyl substance (PFAS) exposures are associated with aeroallergen sensitization, a known precursor to asthma development, in young children (aged 24-47 months) risk for developing asthma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) is a public health priority and is well-established as a health disparity for some racial and ethnically minoritized groups. Transgender and gender diverse (TGD) people (i.e., those with a gender identity that differs from their sex assigned at birth) are a marginalized group that share many of the same psychosocial stressors and adverse health conditions linked to ADRD risk among cisgender adults (i.e., non-TGD) from minoritized ethnoracial communities; yet little is understood about the epidemiology and risk of ADRD among TGD adults. This proposal will determine the extent of ADRD disparities and ADRD risk among TGD adults, characterize TGD-specific experiences (e.g., TGD status disclosure) and psychosocial stressors (e.g., anti-TGD discrimination, social isolation) expected to influence cognition, and explore associations between cognitive function, TGD psychosocial stressors, and ADRD risk and protective factors among a cohort of middle-aged and older TGD adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dysfunction of lymphatic vessels can lead to lymphedema and no-healing ulcers, affecting over 250 million people worldwide. Here I propose to examine the role of repair and immune-modulatory functions of lymphatic vessels in the control of wound repair to further our understanding of the cellular and molecular factors that underlie this complex process. My studies will uncover novel targets aimed at modulating lymphatic vessels, immune cells, and epidermal stem cells to advance therapeutic approaches in pathological tissue repair.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: The proportions and patterning of photoreceptor subtypes in the retina generate many primate-specific features of vision, including trichromatic color vision and high-acuity spatial vision. Disruption of photoreceptor specification results in disorders causing blindness. To unravel the temporal signaling mechanisms that specify primate photoreceptors, I will compare development in human and marmoset retinal organoids, "mini retinas" grown from primate stem cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative  Amyloids are a hallmark of neurodegenerative diseases and systemic amyloidoses. The examination of patient-derived amyloid structures reveals a correlation between the amyloid assembly and clinicopathology, but the role of amyloids in these illnesses is still largely unknown. The capability to design proteins that exhibit specific epitopes of amyloids would allow for the identification of pathological biomarkers and the development of effective treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Genetic studies involving thousands of individuals have identified many genes associated with glaucoma risk, though this has not yet translated to personalized approaches for diagnosis, monitoring or treatment of this common, blinding disease. This mentored clinician-scientist career development proposal will investigate the clinical impact and underlying disease mechanisms for glaucoma-associated genes that function in the mitochondria, the energy-producing parts of our cells. The approach is designed to help pave the way for personalized glaucoma care for individuals whose disease is driven by mitochondrial gene variants; the methodologies employed in this proposal can also be readily applied to other genes and pathways in the future to lay the foundation for precision glaucoma care.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Bruising in young children is a frequent indicator of physical abuse and can have significant medical, legal and social consequences if identified. It is vital that we have an objective means of identifying bruises in children, as doing so can impact proper healthcare utilization, diminish unnecessary child welfare investigations, and minimize racial disparities in medical, social (i.e., child welfare) and legal invesigations.

PHR: Ankylosing Spondylitis (AS) causes decreased physical functioning and disability due to aberrant bone formation and damage of the spine. In this proposal we will develop tools that can help prognosticate AS patients’ risk of severe spinal disease through molecular profiling and biomarker identification. Furthermore, the results will provide a foundation for studies investigating the pathophysiology of AS spinal disease and enhance recruitment in clinical trials studying treatments for this disease-specific outcome.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE With clinically-available genetic testing, the majority of patients with suspected monogenic muscle diseases lack a genetic diagnosis which impedes medical management. The goal of this project is to develop best practices for combined analysis of genome (DNA), transcriptome (RNA), and proteome (protein) research technologies to identify novel variants and genes and improve the diagnostic yield for patients with muscle disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Appropriately responding to environmental perturbations is key to proper genome function, but how genetic variation affects these responses is poorly understood. This project uses comparative genomic approaches to understand the gene regulatory mechanisms underlying variation in the response to immune stimulation (a well understood environmental perturbation) among humans and other primates. The results will yield a detailed molecular understanding of gene-by-environment interactions across cell types, conditions, and species, providing insight into the mechanisms shaping complex traits, genome function, and human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Obligately intracellular tick-borne disease agents, those that can only replicate inside a vertebrate or tick host cell, are a severe and growing threat to human and animal health world-wide. Studying gene function of bacterial pathogens using mutational analysis in which genes are inactivated by insertion of an interruptive sequence such as a transposon, is an important step towards designing treatments and preventive strategies such as vaccines, but this approach has been very difficult to implement with obligately intracellular bacteria, including those transmitted by ticks. We have pioneered large-scale mutagenesis of tick-borne Anaplasma phagocytophilum in human cells, demonstrated that mutant Rickettsia parkeri are safe and effective vaccinogens, and we now propose to expand on these previous achievements by generating a library of A. phagocytophilum mutants in which the function of mutated genes can be easily restored to verify mutant and wild-type phenotypes, and to test the effect of mutations on mouse infectivity and tick transmissibility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The hexosamine biosynthetic pathway synthesizes UDP-GlcNAc that is necessary for a wide range of glycosylation reactions, and inhibition of this pathway has shown promise as anti-cancer treatment. We propose to identify how the hexosamine pathway promotes the storage of lipids within tumor cells and evaluate if simultaneous inhibition of hexosamine biosynthesis and lipid metabolism improves therapeutic outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: The efficacy and durability of anti-tumor immunity and immunotherapies for cancer are limited by insufficient development of memory CD4+T cells, which mediate immunological memory and maintain immune responses. Although safe and effective methods to increase memory CD4+T cells have been lacking, we recently discovered that oral administration of the dietary sugar L-fucose increases anti-tumor immunity and the abundance of memory CD4+T cells inside melanomas, suppressing tumor growth and enhancing durable responses to immune checkpoint blockade. In this application, we propose to delineate the underlying molecular mechanism(s) and test how L-fucose may enhance immunological memory and suppress tumor recurrence.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The current project aims to delineate how neural circuits change before and immediately following birth, corresponding to rapid formative growth and transition from the womb to a sensory-abundant world. We will also explore how preterm birth and maternal inflammation may interact with maturational processes during this time. This work holds the potential to uncover novel mechanisms underlying common disorders of early human development, which may, in turn, inform development of new, biologically-informed, targeted therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: NARRATIVE  Use of multiple tobacco products is becoming increasingly prevalent in the United States, with dual use of cigarettes and e-cigarettes representing the most common combination. The Food and Drug Administration Center for Tobacco Products has announced plans to implement a nicotine-limiting product standard for cigarettes and policy makers at the state and federal levels have proposed limiting the amount of nicotine in e- cigarettes. We propose a 12-week double-blind randomized controlled trial to investigate how a nicotine-limiting standard for cigarettes affects smoking among adult dual users and whether these effects are impacted by constraints on e-cigarette nicotine content.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Helicobacter pylori chronically colonizes the stomach of more than half of the global population and is the strongest known risk factor for the development of gastric cancer. The proposed studies will explore the mechanisms by which H. pylori delivers microbial DNA into gastric cells trigger innate immune signaling. These investigations will advance our understanding of how an important bacterial carcinogen regulates host immunity to promote chronic inflammation and stimulate the development of stomach malignancies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Young people with chronic kidney disease (CKD) have a high lifetime risk for cardiovascular disease, including heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF). However, youth with CKD have been largely excluded from studies that improve detection of HFpEF at the earliest stages and from trials of medications that prevent heart disease in adults with CKD. This study will leverage insights developed in adults with CKD to better define early and subtle changes in heart function in youth with CKD and to begin to test the reversibility of these changes using an interventional study.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE This proposal focuses on Mycoplasma genitalium (MG), a sexually transmitted bacterium of men and women that is highly resistant to antibiotics. We recently discovered that MG is susceptible to nitroimidazole antibiotics, adding a possible new therapy to the short list of effective treatments. This study will identify which nitroimidazoles are most effective against MG, how these antibiotics kill MG, and how MG becomes resistant to these drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Asthma affects 25 million patients in the United States; however, the effects of asthma are inequitably experienced with asthma disproportionately burdening patients living in lower-resource communities. In this career development award, the candidate and his mentoring team will partner with a network of federally qualified health centers in St. Louis, Missouri to assess if the single maintenance and reliever therapy (SMART) implementation bundle improves providers’ prescription of guideline-recommend SMART (Aim 1, 1° effectiveness outcome) while concomitantly using the RE-AIM framework to evaluate implementation outcomes including adoption (Aim 2, 1° implementation outcome). The potential impact of this study is high for the scientific community, local community health centers, and the applicant as it provides the mentored training needed to prepare him to subsequently lead an R01-level hybrid effectiveness-implementation trial for guideline-recommend SMART therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative It is imperative that less cardiotoxic drugs and drug combinations be developed for patients at highest risk of developing treatment-associated cardiomyopathy, especially children, adolescents, and young adults with sarcoma. This study will bring together experts in pediatric oncology and cardiology to address this need. The team will use innovative animal models to investigate novel cancer therapies that hold promise as effective but less cardiotoxic treatment regimens, focusing on combining epigenetic drugs with minimally cardiotoxic anthracyclines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronological age is the most important risk factor for disease progression in multiple sclerosis (MS), but the role of biological aging in MS is poorly understood. This proposed study aims to determine the associations of biological aging with outcomes and immune dysregulation in MS. Results linking accelerated biological aging to worse MS outcomes may lead to future studies using biological age as a predictive biomarker in MS or trials of anti-aging therapies to mitigate disability progression in MS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Perinatal depression affects an estimated 13% of pregnant people in the US. While effective interventions exist to prevent perinatal depression, access to facility-based in-person interventions is limited. This proposal will refine a digital group adaptation of an evidence-based prevention intervention, and evaluate its preliminary effectiveness and implementation outcomes through a pilot randomized controlled trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Anal cancer is a major source of morbidity in people living with HIV. Screening has been demonstrated to prevent anal cancers but current procedures are suboptimal. The objective of this study is to validate a novel genomic panel for identification of high-risk anal pre-cancers and find genomic biomarkers associated with anal cancer recurrence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Blood cancers account for approximately 10% of all malignancies and allogeneic bone marrow transplantation (BMT) is a preferred curative therapy due to the graft-versus-leukemia (GVL) effects, in which donor T and NK cells eradicate host malignancy. Although recently, the types of APC that induce and enhance GVHD have been elucidated, the presence and nature of GVL-specific APC remain unknown. In this proposal, we will focus on identifying GVL-dependent APC in order to generate new therapeutic approaches to enhance GVL within bone marrow that do not exacerbate GVHD.

PHR: NARRATIVE STATEMENT This project is designed to address the problem of low cancer immunogenicity by evaluating the capacity of a combination of epigenetic inhibitory agents to eliminate breast tumor cells by enhancing the antitumor immune response. Studies will include the optimization of novel inhibitors to epigenetic remodeling complexes to achieve improved effectiveness in animals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Glioblastoma (GBM) is the most common malignant primary brain tumor in adults, and carries a dismal prognosis that has improved little in recent decades. The goal of this study is to identify effective drug combinations tailored to the unique composition of each tumor by (1) identifying and isolating the distinct cell populations that comprise individual glioblastoma tumors, and (2) testing the drug sensitivities of each cell population. This approach has the potential to change the way this disease is studied and treated by establishing a pipeline for the identification of personalized, combinatorial drug treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Microplastic contamination of the environment is ubiquitous with human exposure likely occurring though air, drinking water, food, and personal care products. Microplastics can be absorbed across cell membranes and may pose significant risks to human health. The proposed research will develop methods for measuring and characterizing microplastic exposure among the general pregnant population, which in turn will allow us to begin understanding sources of exposure and investigating human health risks associated with exposure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: TRANSLATION OF NONINVASIVE METABOLIC BIOMARKERS TO TARGETED THERAPY FOR CANCER PROJECT NARRATIVE  Genetic mutations in cancer alter chemical processes modifying the tumor content of substances called me- tabolites. In this program, we want to assess the possibility of measuring these metabolites using magnetic resonance spectroscopic imaging (MRSI). Using MRSI, we could measure treatment-related changes in tumor metabolites in cancer patients without obtaining tumor pieces, using injections or radiation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Narrative There is a dearth of research investigating associations between prenatal exposure to pesticides in urban settings and lung function and respiratory outcomes in children in Latin America, including how associations differ by child sex. Environmental health literacy will be crucial to intervention efforts, however little is known regarding household pesticide use and exposure risks. The aims of this proposal will be met through completion of a rigorous professional development and training program and conducting mentored research examining prenatal pesticide exposures and child lung function and asthma outcomes, while developing and administering an environmental health literacy scale with dissemination of associated outreach materials with long-term goals of delineating risk factors and preventing adverse respiratory outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Circadian-driven clock genes cause time-of-day dependent changes in dopamine release and dopamine receptor activity in the Nucleus Accumbens. Changes in Nucleus Accumbens activity are known to alter response to stressful, aversive stimuli. Using ex vivo and in vivo approaches, we aim to assess how circadian- driven changes in the clock gene expression alter Nucleus Accumbens neuronal physiology through the dopamine 1 receptor and determine how these fluctuations vary neurobiological response to aversive stimuli.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: NARRATIVE Tens of thousands of children are hospitalized each year with sepsis, many of whom subsequently develop new supplemental oxygen or mechanical ventilator dependence. Currently, little is known about the timing of and risk factors for its development. The overall objective of this study is to determine when (in-hospital or after discharge) new oxygen or ventilator dependence develops and risk factors for its development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Clear Cell Renal Cell Carcinoma (ccRCC) is a devastating disease that is projected to affect 81,800 individuals within the USA in 2023, with a complete response rate to current treatments being only 16%. Over 90% of ccRCC patients harbor genetic alterations of the von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) tumor-suppressor gene. In this proposal we aim to assess a compound that inhibits cyclin dependent kinase 9 (CDK9) as a therapeutic to selectively target ccRCC with VHL alterations.

ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Telomere length (TL) tracks across the life course and is a consequential trait for human health. It is critical to understand environmental factors contributing to the wide inter-individual TL variance at birth. The proposed research will leverage a large birth cohort study to investigate how prenatal exposure to phthalates, a class of endocrine-disrupting chemicals (EDCs), relates to TL, telomerase expression and activity, and cellular markers of replicative senescence in the placenta-newborn unit.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Inborn errors of immunity are broad group of genetic defects of the immune system that lead to human disease. We have identified patients with susceptibility to infection due to abnormal antibody responses and B cell maturation. In this application, we will identify how immune cell function is altered in these patients, and test a specific gene that we have identified as altered in patients but not healthy individuals, thus having the potential to define a new human disease and provide important insight into how the human immune response is regulated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Transcription factors (TFs) play a central role in regulating gene expression and cell identity. As DNA replication removes TFs from DNA and occludes TF binding sites, it is unclear when and how TFs reassociated with nascent DNA. This proposal outlines a series of experiments to determine the kinetics, modality, and impact of TF binding to newly synthesized DNA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative More than 80% of human protein coding genes are alternatively spliced, effectively increasing the proteome in comparison to the total number of genes. While transposable elements have been largely recognized to provide alternative promoters and enhancers, their contribution to the protein coding sequences is still debated. The goal of this proposal is to understand how transposable elements shape the evolution and diversification of vertebrate proteomes, as well as which events and mechanisms promote their origin and affect their expression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative / Public Health Relevance Statement Suicide is the third leading cause of death among youth ages 12 to 17 in the United States, and emergency department visits by youth for suicidal thoughts or behaviors are increasing over time. There is a critical need to implement evidence-based interventions to prevent youth suicide during the high-risk period after an emergency department visit. To fill this gap, this study will determine the feasibility and acceptability of delivering Caring Contacts (brief messages of care and concern) via text message to adolescents with suicidal thoughts or behaviors after an emergency department visit to reduce suicide risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rickettsiales are a diverse order of obligate intracellular bacteria, including many pathogens vectored to humans by arthropods. A lack of genetic tools for rickettsial agents has long hindered molecular dissection of the host- pathogen interactions that allow these bacteria to cause disease. In our project we are introducing systems into the rickettsial pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum to enable the identification and characterization of infection determinants.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many stroke survivors experience movement impairment on one side of the body, which we believe is caused by alternative neural pathways being recruited to produce movements when the normal pathways connecting the brain and body are injured. Ideally, we want to develop rehabilitation interventions to preferentially strengthen the normal pathways, but we do not currently have a method to assess what pathways a given intervention is using. To address this, our project uses functional MRI to map neural activity in the brain, brainstem, and spinal cord, to determine how different neural pathways contribute to hand movement following stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: RELEVANCE Survivors of Hodgkin Lymphoma (HL) have an elevated risk for chronic cardiopulmonary health conditions, cerebrovascular problems, and late-onset neurocognitive impairment. This research aims to determine if radiation and chemotherapy, which can cause damage to the cardiopulmonary system, are also associated with reduced cardiopulmonary functional reserve, and dysregulated cerebral blood flow (CBF). The findings from this study could lead to the development of improved screening, risk assessment, and interventions to improve brain blood flow, cardiopulmonary function, neurocognitive outcomes, and quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Little is known about the vocal communication of minimally-speaking individuals – they lack quantitative measures designed to specifically capture their subtle vocal development over time, limiting our ability to meaningfully measure their skills, monitor their growth during clinical trials, or create vocal-based augmentative technology for this exceptional population. This proposal aims to generate a sensitive, quantitative metric of vocal communication for minimally-speaking individuals using a novel remote and highly personalized data collection methodology. The results of this work will allow us to determine sensitive vocal communication milestones for profoundly affected minimally-speaking individuals and appropriate outcome measures for clinical trials and interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative  The opioid epidemic has emerged as a major public health crisis, characterized by high relapse rates and adverse side effects that compromise the effectiveness of existing treatments. EvoDenovo proposes to develop novel, non-opioid-based therapies that dissociate the behavioral and analgesic effects of opioids. We will optimize small molecule inhibitors of a new anti-opioid target for their efficacy in modulating opioid effects in mouse models. Successful completion has the potential to reduce healthcare costs and fulfill the unmet need of OUD sufferers. EvoDenovo RFA-DA-23-021 / PI: Sid A. Labed Project Narrative - Page 1 of 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Craniofacial deformity often involves cranial sutures, and adequate understanding of the molecular mechanism underlying cranial suture development is urgently demanded for exploring new diagnostic and therapeutic methods for cranial diseases, such as craniosynostosis and sutural agenesis. Neural crest cells, a multipotent stem cell population during embryonic stage, make great contributions to cranial suture development, especially frontal (metopic) suture. I proposed a multipronged approach to understand how the neural crest-derived cranial suture is coordinately regulated by the complicated signaling network, and how this contributes to the cranial suture development and related diseases, in order to explore novel and critical factors for the diagnostic and therapeutic of cranial suture diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative We propose to develop mRNA therapy using lung-targeting lipid nanoparticle, for lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM), a destructive lung disease caused by inactivating mutations in TSC1 or TSC2. We will reprogram LAM cells with a TSC2 mutation back to a “normal” state without affecting normal tissue, and can re-normalize the LAM immune microenvironment. The success of this study will open a new therapeutic paradigm of mRNA therapy for LAM with the potential of durable effect and complete remission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative There is no consensus on preferred format or regime to maximise responsiveness towards influenza vaccines in older adults. We will leverage our existing biobank of a completed randomised control trial of enhanced influenza vaccines to comprehensively define immunity at the cellular, antibody and transcriptional level to derive how enhanced vaccines benefit older adults. This will provide mechanistic insights into innate and adaptive immune changes that occur during the aging process and the functional consequences to vaccine responses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed Looking and Language Project (LoLa) will test the theoretical model that looking to the mouth of a speaker in infancy influences later language via caregiver-child engagement and prelinguistic vocal complexity via a longitudinal correlational study and an intervention study. In the K99 phase, I will evaluate conduct the longitudinal correlational study, evaluate the feasibility of a novel intervention that encourages looking to the mouth of a speaker, and conduct a qualitative study to learn about caregivers’ attitudes and perceived barriers towards interventions for infants with autistic older siblings (Baby Sibs), who are highly likely be diagnosed with autism or developmental language disorder. In the R00 portion, I will conduct a randomized controlled trial to assess (a) the effect of the novel intervention on caregiver strategy use, looking to the mouth of a speaker, caregiver-child engagement, prelinguistic vocal complexity, and language and (b) the acceptability of the intervention approach to interested parties in the autism community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The population of the world is aging. Age impacts the body’s response to vaccines by reducing the quality and quantity of antibodies which are the main way vaccines provide protection from infectious disease. This proposal will study how aging affects B cells, the cells that make antibodies, therefore allowing the development of better vaccines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative  Immune-cell memory induced by prior exposure to a pathogen or vaccination provides enhanced protection against a subsequent infection with the same pathogen; yet the molecular mechanisms by which immune cells “remember” previous exposures – over the course of a lifetime – are poorly understood. Here, we combine experimental measurement with mathematical modeling to uncover the epigenetic mechanisms by which immune-cell memory is maintained. The resulting models will provide new insights of value to human health, as immunological memory not only underlies pathogen defense but is dysregulated in many diseases, including autoimmune, allergy and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This project deals with natural killer (NK) cells which are immune cells that can control infections and tumors. NK cells have potent mechanisms to attack and destroy abnormal cells and promote inflammation, processes that must be controlled, termed tolerance. Here the Yokoyama laboratory presents preliminary evidence using novel experimental tools that will be used in the current proposal to study how NK cells are prevented from inadvertent attack.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Physical activity is a cornerstone of the prevention and management of type 2 diabetes, but recommendations still need to be optimized. Our preliminary data suggest that performing multiple short bouts of activity (5 minutes) throughout the day to frequently interrupt sedentary time may be even better to control glucose than the standard approach of single daily continuous bouts of physical activity. We propose to examine whether and how breaking up prolonged sitting, a potential practical strategy, improves glucose control (independent of physical activity) in adults with prediabetes, a population that is at high risk of developing type 2 diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Environment, social factors and sex are variables that influence vulnerability, maintenance, withdrawal and treatment outcome in human drug addiction. The research proposed in this application will examine all three phases of addiction with a focus on the kappa opioid receptor (KOR) system and extend behavioral (cocaine self-administration), pharmacological (long-term cocaine exposure) and brain changes (using positron emission tomography), in socially housed female and male monkeys. Results from these studies should aid in the development of personalized medicine strategies for drug addiction and the implementation of the KOR system across the addition cycle.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative People differ in their initial behavioral responses to psychomotor stimulant drugs in ways that affect risk for future use or abuse. One source of individual differences may be variation in the brain circuits that mediate the drugs' effects, the same circuits that process other types of reward. In this study, we will examine individual differences in responses to a single dose of methamphetamine on the brain reward circuit in healthy adults, and determine the relationship of these effects to the behavioral rewarding effects of the drug.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Mutations in the leucine-rich repeat kinase 2 (LRRK2) gene are a common cause of autosomal dominant, familial Parkinson's disease (PD) and the LRRK2 gene contributes to the risk of sporadic PD. Our studies aim to explore novel mechanisms by which mutant forms of LRRK2 lead to neuronal damage in cultured neurons and rat models of PD by elucidating the contribution of enzymatic activity. These studies will have important implications for understanding the molecular pathophysiology of LRRK2-associated PD and for therapeutic drug discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Prostate cancer (PCa) remains an incurable disease once progression to the metastatic castration-resistant (mCRPC) state occurs, a state in which we have identified fibroblast activation protein (FAP) as a key feature of the PCa-supportive, immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment permissive to disease progression that is upregulated on the surface of tumor-associated macrophages (TAMs), mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs), and carcinoma-associated fibroblasts (CAFs). The objectives of this proposal are to identify PCa disease states most likely to respond to FAP-targeted therapy as well as evaluating the efficacy, specificity, and toxicity of a novel first-in-class FAP-activated mitochondrial protoxin in advanced preclinical model systems that accurately recapitulate key clinical features of human PCa. Short-term benefits include a greater understanding of how FAP+ cells contribute to PCa pathophysiology particularly with respect to their interaction with the immune system, while providing the necessary preclinical proof-of-principal data needed to translate this innovative therapeutic platform into the clinic over the longer-term.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Carbon ion radiotherapy (CIRT) is currently the world’s most advanced radiotherapeutic technique; compared with traditional photon radiotherapy, it has unique physical characteristics and biological advantages. It is better at protecting the normal tissue and organs surrounding the tumor and is more effective at killing tumor tissue and particularly tumor cells that can normally resist photon radiotherapy. While X-ray therapy using photons travel through our body, carbon ion is like a dart. It stops at a depth inside our body and releases all its energy in the form of a peak dose in the tumor. Since the track stops at a depth, the particle beam does not go through the body, thereby causing less harm to surrounding normal tissues. Since the particles cause DNA damage and the irradiated cells behave as if they are infected by a DNA virus and increase the body’s anti-viral defense system. We are looking into possible immune activating role of CIRT that possibly helps us fight cancer. We are going to look into the immunological consequences of CIRT for the treatment of pancreatic cancer, a devastating disease where we are losing our battle. Our goal is to determine the immunological effectiveness of CIRT compared to XRT (X rays) in mouse pancreatic cancer models for the treatment of both primary and metastatic cancer. If successful, this will allow us to bring a very sophisticated therapy for our cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human health relevance: Some humans inherit a harmful genetic mutation, yet they somehow buffer the effects of the mutation and do not show signs of genetic disease. We generated a zebrafish model of buffering to understand how some individuals who should have gotten sick are able to live normal healthy lives. Understanding the naturally occurring mechanisms of buffering is the first step toward new therapeutic strategies capitalizing on innate protective mechanisms in some individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The prevalence of obesity and metabolic disease continue to rise, and are thought to develop in part due to excessive consumption of carbohydrate-rich diets and impaired communication between the gut and the brain. We have previously shown that glucose infusion directly into the gut rapidly modulates the activity of feeding circuits in the hypothalamus and inhibits subsequent feeding, but the mechanism remains unclear. Here we propose using cutting-edge neuroscience and genetic techniques to determine the hormonal and neural mediators of these gut-brain dynamics, and to understand how obesity alters these pathways.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative To better understand the genetic basis of adaptive traits in ethnically diverse African populations, we propose to integrate genomic, metabolic, microbiome, epigenomic, and transcriptomic data with detailed phenotype data. We will perform field studies to collect novel biological samples as well as detailed phenotypic data from multiple ethnically diverse African populations. We will incorporate high coverage whole genome sequencing and SNP array data to study African evolution and identify targets of natural selection and to look for genetic associations with anthropometric, gene expression, microbiome, cardio-metabolic and immune related traits. We will use functional genomics approaches, such as high-throughput luciferase assays and Crispr-Cas9 technology to identify causal regulatory variants and characterize their impact on gene expression in vitro and in vivo in model organisms. This study will have important implications for understanding human evolution history and the genetic basis of complex traits of biomedical relevance in populations of recent African descent.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: National studies show that there is more rapid increase in the use of all drugs of abuse by women compared with men, comprising a unique public health concern in the US. However, an overrepresentation of males in neuroimaging studies, and a paucity of studies that explicitly target sex comparisons in addicted populations, contributes to an absence of a clear understanding of sex specific neurobiological mechanisms underlying drug addiction. The study of sex differences (and menstrual cycle/hormonal effects) in the neural underpinnings of reward processing, inhibitory control and cue-reactivity could advance basic neuroscience studies of drug addiction and save resources by minimizing cost and adverse effects during future clinical (medication) trials. Ultimately, results could contribute to the development of individually tailored (gender-based) precision medicine interventions (e.g., to reduce craving).

The application of new computational approaches has sparked life into challenging projects and now allows difficult questions relating to viral receptor usage and integration to be addressed. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Older adults often fear loss of independence and the inability to stay in their homes as they age. There is a need to identify the mechanisms behind this loss of function and to evaluate interventions which could help older adults maintain their autonomy. Thus, this proposed pilot clinical trial will: 1) intervene to minimize the impact of frailty using a home-based exercise program, administered through a meal delivery service, in homebound older adults, and 2) explore possible specific frailty biomarkers to target for early interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Older cancer survivors are at 46% greater risk of being physically frail compared to those without a history of cancer and older Black cancer survivors are at 18% greater risk of being frail compared to older white survivors. An Epigallocatechin-3-gallate (EGCG) intervention is a safe, feasible, and promising intervention to reduce physical frailty in older cancer survivors. The proposed study will evaluate the preliminary effect of the EGCG intervention on physical frailty and Tumor Necrosis Factor-alpha (TNF-α) and related immune markers, explore if baseline TNF-α and related immune markers and DNA methylation age are associated with physical frailty, and explore the effect of the EGCG intervention on physical frailty and TNF-α and related immune markers in older Black compared to white cancer survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative: Our proposed studies will identify cellular and molecular markers to better predict immune checkpoint inhibitor (ICI) responses in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma patients treated with different combinations of ICIs. Our studies would facilitate finding novel mechanisms of differential ICI responses by examining differences in distinct T cell populations that harbor different T cell receptors. A unique strength of our proposal is integration of human clinical trial samples and mouse models as a more powerful platform to uncover mechanistic insights that are translatable into the clinical setting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Symbiotic protists can promote several different immune responses in the intestine, which protect their hosts from enteric pathogens but can exacerbate inflammatory bowel disease. Whether these varied immune responses are due to specific differences in protist species remains unclear. In this proposal, we will identify the protist genes and immune mechanisms that control the intestinal immune response to two symbiotic protists that elicit opposite immune responses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The functional role of phase transitions in biology are not well proven, but cancers exist that are caused by mutations in or mistargeting of phase-separating chromatin-binding proteins. I will utilize my understanding of these biophysical processes to mechanistically understand this previously undescribed class of oncogenic transformations and work toward building synthetic systems that can rescue defects in chromatin localization, enzymatic functionality and phase behavior of nuclear condensates seen in cancer progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative The lining of the gastrointestinal tract plays an important role in immune defense, which can be significantly compromised by conditions such as inflammatory bowel diseases, ischemia, mechanical injury and surgical procedures. This grant will address mechanisms that control epithelial barrier function, determine the impact of inflammatory mediators on mucosal barrier function and investigate how the mucosal lining heals after injury. Knowledge gained from these studies in the short term will provide a better understanding of basic mechanisms that control epithelial barrier function and wound healing, and in the long term, these studies will aid in the development of new therapeutic strategies aimed at strengthening the barrier and in promoting mucosal wound repair.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sanaria has developed highly effective Plasmodium falciparum sporozoite (PfSPZ) vaccines to protect individuals against malaria that are intended also for use in eradicating malaria from defined geographical areas; the first is a live attenuated whole organism vaccine called Sanaria® PfSPZ Vaccine, the second is a live infectious vaccine administered with an antimalarial drug, a vaccine called Sanaria® PfSPZ-CVac, and the third is a late arresting replication competent genetically attenuated vaccine, PfSPZ-LARC2. All these vaccines require the production of PfSPZ in aseptic female Anopheles stephensi mosquitoes. This proposal aims to increase the efficiency of aseptic mosquito rearing by genetically modifying mosquitoes such that immature male mosquitoes are killed by conditional expression of a lethal gene. Successful implementation of this project will reduce cost of vaccine manufacture by ~15%, thereby making the vaccine available at lower cost.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project engages innovative approaches to study individuals recovering from alcohol use disorder using the International Quit & Recovery Registry. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity is common, expensive, and resistant to current treatments despite being a focus of intense research. In our preliminary data we have found that high dose dietary vitamin D signals to preferentially allocate calories to muscle instead of fat. Here our goal is to determine which form of vitamin D is responsible for this preferential calorie allocation and to identify the signaling underlying this preferential allocation, thereby identifying novel therapeutic approaches to exploit to decrease both negative effects and incidence of obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed work will generate monoclonal antibodies to treat catheter-associated urinary tract infections (UTI) and deplete the vaginal reservoir that harbors bacteria and contributes to UTI recurrence. The success of monoclonal antibodies as treatments for other diseases as well as significant preliminary data demonstrating the protective effect of immunity to bacterial adhesins, which mediate UTIs, suggest that this will be a highly effective strategy. These studies have the potential to directly contribute to the arsenal of antibiotic-sparing therapeutics for UTIs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is currently no effective treatment for the cognitive dysfunction characteristic of aging and exacerbated in Alzheimer Disease (AD). Administration of extracellular vesicles (EVs) containing NAMPT, an enzyme critical to cellular NAD+ production, can extend lifespan and ameliorate age-related deficits such as activity levels in mice. This study will evaluate a role for NAMPT in mediating the ability of EVs to target the brain and rescue age- and AD-related cognitive decline, potentially establishing the use of EVs as a viable therapeutic strategy to treat these conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE It is imperative to engage older adults with mild cognitive impairment who are at risk for Alzheimer's Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD) in advance care planning before they develop end-stage disease and lose the capacity to make informed decisions. This proposal has unique public health importance because (1) it will increase the mentoring of clinical investigators interested in conducting patient-oriented research concerning the rapidly growing population of older persons with cognitive impairment and caregivers of persons with cognitive impairment or ADRD; (2) it will inform the adaptation of evidence-based advance care planning interventions for older persons with cognitive impairment and caregivers of persons with cognitive impairment or ADRD; and (3) it will help to reduce health disparities in advance care planning for patients and caregivers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Approximately 24% of the world's population is infected with one or more helminths; on the other hand, the incidence of inflammatory bowel disease in developed countries continues to rise. There is an urgent need for effective and safe treatments for intestinal infections and inflammation; however, our understanding of host defense mechanisms is far from complete. The proposed study will reveal a new regulatory cascade within the intestinal epithelium that enables the host to mount antihelminth immunity and control gut inflammation, thus providing new avenues for the treatment of parasitic infections and inflammatory disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative: Antiretroviral therapy (ART) during HIV-1 infection suppresses viral replication and prevents immunodeficiency but does not cure the infection. We have developed a novel genetically encoded humanized mouse model system that enables us to distinguish latent cells from bystander cells and are now characterizing latent cells using single cell genomic profiling of cells, to reveal an unprecedented unperturbed view HIV latency. We propose here to use single cell genomics, live dynamic imaging and spatial transcriptomics to probe how latent cells survive stimuli that can activate the virus and the immune system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lung cancer is the most common and most deadly non-AIDS defining cancer in the HIV(+) population and smoking alone cannot explain the significantly higher rate of lung cancers in HIV(+) individuals. The main focus of this project is to determine the causal role of human papillomavirus (HPV) in HIV associated lung cancers and elucidate the unique mechanism through which HPV contributes to this deadly disease. The discovery of this work is expected to be particularly significant for future patient care and disease management.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The burden of Alzheimer's disease and related dementias (ADRD) is increasing nationally and globally, with disproportionate impacts on lower-income, lower-education, and minority race/ethnic older adults. Presence of and inequalities in neighborhood factors (e.g. social context or physical and built environments) may affect cognitive decline and be key for intervening on ADRD risk and disparities at the population level. In this study, researchers collect, process, and link extensive neighborhood data to the Multi-Ethnic Study of Atherosclerosis (MESA), creating an unprecedented 25+ year dataset that can expand evidence on the role of residential contexts in impacting comprehensive cognitive health outcomes within a national, multi-ethnic cohort.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This research plan will design, fabricate, and test a replacement regenerative vein valve to treat patients with diseased valves that cause blood to pool in their legs. The valve is grown from a donor’s skin cells directly on a stent for minimally invasive delivery via a catheter and then decellularized for implantation into any patient without an immune response. Computer-aided design will be used to identify the optimal valve design, and after extensive bench-top testing, the valve will be tested in the iliac veins of sheep, then the FDA engaged regarding the clinical approval process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative We will develop new high-resolution anatomical imaging methods that provide detailed biochemical information on G protein coupled receptor (GPCR) signaling in the brain. The methods will be useful for measuring changes in GPCR function that occur in response to chronic drug taking, chronic stress, or chronic pain. They will enable new discoveries that can accelerate the development of pharmacological interventions for substance use disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Scalable single-cell workflow for multiomic analyses of chromatin interactions, accessibility, gene expression and cell surface proteins to unravel mechanisms of cellular diversity Arima Genomics Project Narrative Precise regulation of genes is essential for establishing cellular diversity and functionality throughout the human body, and mis-regulation of genes causes human disease. To regulate expression, cells utilize regulatory regions embedded within chromatin, as well as the physical interactions between regulatory regions and genes contained within the three-dimensional (3D) nuclear milieu of each cell. Most genomics assays to study 3D chromatin interactions, including ones developed by Arima, analyze samples in “bulk” – where measurements of chromatin interactions are averaged across all cells in the population, failing to capture the ever-important dynamic chromatin interaction landscape in each cell within a larger tissue or organ system. Lately, academic assays have been developed to analyze chromatin interactions in single cells, but these assays remain inefficient, and complex. Improved and standardized assays are critically needed. Via a self-funded phase-1 project, Arima has overcome these challenges to develop a kit-based solution for efficient mapping of chromatin interactions in single cells. To truly inform gene regulatory mechanisms, chromatin interactions cannot be studied in isolation – instead, it needs to be captured alongside regulatory and gene expression information. Building off the phase-1 kit, Arima proposes to develop a scalable kit-based solution for concurrently mapping all three modalities within individual cells. The development of our new single-cell multiomic solution aims to build new inroads for delineating mechanisms governing cell diversity and function in heterogeneous disease microenvironments, toward ultimately improving the human condition via enhanced discovery, diagnosis, and therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal seeks to understand the impact and mechanisms by which trained immunity, adaptive immunity, and gut dysbiosis impact uropathogenic E coli (UPEC) infection of the bladder and reservoir formation in the gastrointestinal tract (GIT) using: i) advanced mouse models of urinary tract infection (UTI); ii) GI colonization; and iii) a primary urothelial cell culture system. In this way, this proposal investigates: i) the impact of epigenetic remodeling of the bladder urothelium on inflammation dynamics and disease outcome upon UPEC infection; ii) the mechanisms by which adaptive immunity modulates susceptibility to recurrent infection; and iii) the mechanisms by which the gut mucosa restricts UPEC colonization. This is particularly important since UTls are very common and highly recurrent, and increasingly caused by antibiotic resistant strains.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Alcohol consumption (alcohol quantity x frequency/AQF), Alcohol Use Disorders (AUDs) and posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) often co-occur, and there is emerging evidence that shared genetic risk may partially account for the high rates of this co-occurrence. This project seeks to clarify the shared molecular genetic underpinnings of the PTSD-AQF/AUD co-occurrence, while testing two key laboratory-based phenotypes (i.e., distress tolerance and anxiety sensitivity) as potential predictors, and socioeconomic status and social support as moderators of genetic effects. This K01 award will provide the candidate with the necessary training to become an independent, federally-funded investigator in the intersection of traumatic stress-related outcomes, laboratory-based paradigms, and psychiatric and statistical genetics.

PHR: Development of small molecule inhibitors of metabolic enzymes as broad spectrum anthelmintic drugs Project Narrative Parasitic intestinal nematodes, notably hookworms, roundworm and whipworms, infect more than two billion people and are a leading cause of human morbidity and the maintenance of poverty. The main goal of this project is to conduct drug discovery and development of novel small molecule drugs that selectively target nematode metabolic enzymes for control of these devastating parasites, and to reduce their associated morbidity and mortality. Compounds targeting conserved pan-phylum metabolic enzymes, essential for their survival, will be optimized for increased potency, nematode selectivity and in vivo efficacy with broad spectrum activity. 2

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) affects approximately 16% of the veteran population. COPD is the fourth most prevalent disease in the VA population and one of the most costly to the VA health care system. Over 500,000 service-connected respiratory disabilities have been diagnosed in veterans and 6.5% of all Gulf War service-connected disabilities are respiratory system related. Operation Enduring Freedom and Operation Iraqi Freedom Veterans have been exposed to chemicals known to cause acute and chronic respiratory conditions including CARC paint and chromium dust. Other veterans have experienced acute lung failure from blast injury, smoke inhalation, or COVID-19. Over 2.3 million veterans reported having some form of “lung trouble” in the 2001 National Survey of Veterans. This project has the potential to revolutionize the rehabilitation of Veterans suffering from lung disease through the development of a truly portable, biocompatible, artificial lung prothesis.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA SALT LAKE CITY HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: There is a rapidly increasing clinical demand for bone grafting materials for use in osseous regeneration and repair surgeries. Although autografts (from self) and allografts (cadaver) are the currently preferred options, each has its own drawbacks, including limited resources. A potential solution to overcome this graft material shortage is to develop equivalent engineered bone substitutes. This study is designed to test the efficacy of one such bone substitute, a fluoridated calcium phosphate-based bioceramic. In our initial studies, fluorapatite was shown to enhance in vitro differentiation of osteoblasts and stem cells into the osteogenic lineage, but more importantly, resulted in ~90% new bone formation in both, in vivo rat and pig models. The proposed study is designed to develop an autograft-like bone scaffold by incorporating a FA scaffold with a recipient’s own stromal vascular fraction cells—derived from a recipient’s fat tissue—to fill critical-size bone defects. If proven, this combination approach may become “off-the-shelf” autograft-like bone scaffolds for orthopedic and dental applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Enteric viruses are highly infectious human pathogens that cause significant morbidity and mortality worldwide and rotavirus infection alone leads to an annual death of 215,000 people. The proposed study on the molecular interactions between an interferon-stimulated gene SAMD9 and rotavirus-encoded NSP1 will provide new information on host inhibition of enteric virus replication and viral counteraction strategies. The long-term objective of this study is to facilitate the rational design of efficacious interferon-based therapeutics and the development of an optimized, third-generation rotavirus vaccine, thereby reducing the overall global disease burden. !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As youth, especially those orphaned by HIV/AIDS, transition into young adulthood, they are faced with limited social support and opportunities for education and employment, which elevates their vulnerability to poverty, poor mental health functioning and other negative life outcomes, including risk-taking behaviors exposing them to HIV/AIDS and poor health outcomes. The proposed Bridges-Round 2 study will extend the recently completed efficacious Bridges to the Future study to examine the longitudinal impact of a family-based economic empowerment intervention on the developmental and behavioral health outcomes, and transition milestones for young people orphaned by AIDS in Uganda. Findings from this large longitudinal dataset may contribute to the scientific knowledge on the potential value of investing modest economic resources in poor and vulnerable boys and girls during early adolescence and how these resources may offer long-term protection against known HIV and mental health risks—two public health issues impacting millions of young people in low-resource communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE It has been suggested that many retinal diseases are mediated by abnormalities in retinal synaptic circuits, such as rod and cone dystrophy in retinitis pigmentosa, macular degeneration, congenital stationary night blindness (CSNB) and glaucoma. Our multi-cellular analysis of retinal circuits will provide important new insights into how synaptic abnormalities contribute to various retinal disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The immune system is able to recognize and eliminate pathogen infected cells and newly arising tumors. However, certain pathogenic infections are not efficiently cleared and lead to chronic infections that often lead to dysfunctional pathogen-specific CD8 T cells. The identification and characterization of why certain viral and bacterial infections are not cleared and how they promote T cell dysfunction is a major goal of this application.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative With the increase in auto-immune diseases and emerging concerns of compromised immunity in our aging culture and vulnerable children, understanding T cell signaling, metabolic processes, and the resources required for proper immune response and functioning is extremely relevant to public health. This project explores how metabolism is controlled in T cell immune responses at the level of precise biochemical reaction and molecular interactions, which are amenable to pharmacologic and dietary manipulation. This proposal will enable developing novel therapeutic interventions by targeting the metabolic pathways for T cell-mediated inflammatory and autoimmune diseases, which aligns with the NIAID’s and NIGMS’s mission to conduct and support basic and applied research to better understand, treat, and ultimately prevent infectious, immunologic, and allergic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE  Immunotherapies can augment T cells for potent responses against some cancers, yet are ineffective against others. We propose several experiments to identify the molecular details of transcriptional programs that limit, and those that could enhance, T cells responses in tumors. These analyses will deﬁne transcriptional control of anti-tumor immune responses and identify potential targets to improve immunotherapies against diverse cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project will determine the mechanisms that control pancreatic -cell endoplasmic reticulum (ER) Ca2+ (Ca2+ER) handling and their importance regulating islet hormone secretion. Results from this project are expected to provide significant insights into how glucose-stimulated-cell Ca2+ER handling becomes disrupted in T2D and perturbs islet hormone secretion. Thus, the proposed research project will generate fundamental knowledge about human islet -cells that will help reduce the burden of human illness in the context of diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The root cause of systemic failure to identify and treat childhood TB worldwide is the challenge of accurate diagnosis. Two novel biomarker approaches, based on host blood RNA signatures and a simplified T cell Antigen-Specific Activation assay that target complementary aspects of the host immune response, have been discovered and validated in adults and offer promise as biomarkers of childhood TB. We will evaluate diagnostic and prognostic performance of these biomarkers for pediatric TB disease, to inform feasibility and potential impact of biomarker-targeted TB screening strategies for children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: OTHER PROJECT INFORMATION – Project Narrative Invalid drug patents, particularly invalid patents on secondary drug features (e.g., routes of administration) have the potential to prolong effective patent lives and delay widespread patient access to longevity-improving drugs. This project will explore the effects of increasing the resources to U.S. patent examiners—mainly, the time allocated to patent examiners—on the rate of issuance of invalid drug patents, while also exploring the efficiency of screening valid from invalid drug patents at the administrative-agency level relative to doing so via the courts. In the process, this project will construct novel databases on both small- and large-molecule drug patents that will prove valuable both to our investigation into strengthening ex ante review of drug patents and to the broader community researching drug patents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative We seek to clarify the interactive effects of COVID-19 biopsychosocial stressors, alcohol use and neurobiobehavioral decline in drinkers aged 65-75 of both majority and minority race/ethnicity. Towards this end, applying a multi-method/multi-modal approach, we will ascertain alcohol use patterns, psychological stressors, neurophysiology and cognitive function across a 3 year period. This work will yield novel findings regarding the impact of the prolonged COVID-19 pandemic on stress measures, alcohol use and neurobiobehavioral stability across a critical period of transition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This application seeks to answer the fundamental questions of which initial, first-line weight loss intervention should be offered to older adults with obesity and multiple chronic conditions and how to address the high non- response rates observed with most conventional strategies. A sequential, multiple assignment, randomized trial design will permit the evaluation of treatment combinations that maximize weight loss and will provide data on constructing a future tailored, adaptive intervention. If successful, these findings will identify interventions that could markedly improve health and quality of life of these older adults, reduce long-term disability, and lower healthcare costs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Organ transplantation has become a life-saving strategy for patients with irreversible organ diseases. However, ischemia reperfusion injury (IRI) of the transplanted organ occurs inevitably following the operation and augments inflammatory responses within the organ markedly, leading to transplant rejection. This project seeks to unveil the mechanisms by which IRI induces this immune response and harness this knowledge to develop novel therapies that will improve transplant outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative Healthy speech perception can be limited through a variety of causes, including brain tumor, stroke, cochlear implant usage, and age-related hearing loss. The brain's major mechanism for compensating for degraded speech processes is to integrate auditory-visual speech signals (e.g., lipreading), which restores some hearing abilities. We propose to study the functional mechanisms that support this process and enable the restoration of speech perception abilities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: THE ROLE OF EFFEROCYTOSIS IN INFLAMMATORY ARTHRITIS Narrative  Dying cells can be detected in inflamed joints of human patients and animal models of Rheumatoid arthritis (RA), a chronic inflammatory disease which affects 1 in 100 people globally and millions in the US alone. The current dogma suggests that persistence of dying cells in tissues indicates pathology, as these cells are usually promptly removed by their live neighbors in a process called ‘efferocytosis’. In this application, we present surprising data showing that there are unappreciated benefits of reduced efferocytosis in arthritis and propose to test the dogma and explore the therapeutic potential of this process, which could open new avenues in therapeutic designs for the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Following our novel findings in diabetic patients with impaired kidney function, we propose a multi-disciplinary study to assess the role of circulating miRNAs and axon guidance pathway (AGP) proteins in the development of early progressive kidney function decline (PKFD) in patients with normal kidney function and to learn about the mechanisms through which circulating AGP proteins may damage the kidney. Three complementary studies will be conducted. One will examine the hypothesis in an observational study of patients with diabetes, the second will examine the same hypothesis using kidney biopsies from patients with diabetes and in non- diabetic controls, and the third will examine mechanisms of early kidney damage through genetic manipulation of circulating levels of miRNAs and AGP proteins in mice model of diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TOLEDO HEALTH SCI CAMPUS
PHR: Project Narrative  One intriguing function of neutrophils is their ability to expel their DNA in the form of a cobweb-like structures known as neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) decorated with their granular antimicrobial proteins. We have obtained evidence that mice deficient in peptidyl arginine deiminase-4 (Pad4KO, aka NETs deficient) are highly susceptible to inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). This proposal seeks to address the mucoprotective roles of PAD4 mechanistically in murine models of IBD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lip, oral cavity, and pharyngeal cancers are a significant health problem afflicting approximately 530,000 people globally every year. This multi-institution prospective longitudinal cohort study will assess for the first time the performance of a point-of-care oral cytology tool (POCOCT) for its use in both secondary and tertiary care settings, where high risk patients will be longitudinally monitored and their risk trajectory established over time using personalized cellular image signatures. This effort has potential for more accurate oral lesion diagnosis while improving patient survival and overall quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The proposed research will help elucidate how histone variant H2A.X is incorporated into chromatin in response to DNA damage and how ubiquitylation of H2A and H2A.X by RNF168-UbcH5c triggers the recruitment of several DNA damage response proteins to damaged chromatin. This work has relevance to public health because it will provide a molecular level understanding of several factors that promote homologous recombination (HR) DNA repair and are essential to the maintenance of genome integrity and tumor suppression. Targeting HR-promoting factors for inhibition could in principle be used to potentiate poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase inhibitors (PARPi) in killing ovarian and breast cancer cells and counteract acquired resistance to PARPi treatment developed by cancer patients.
